an amalgamation of spiritual practices, traditions, and beliefs created by enslaved Africans in North America that were held in secret from slaveholders. Hoodoo is a mixture of African and Native American folk practices.
A center which offers legal information, advice, referrals, and, in some cases, brief services.

A modern Pagan religion which developed in England during the first half of the 20th century and was introduced to the public in 1954 by Gerald Gardner, a retired British civil servant. Wicca draws upon a diverse set of ancient pagan and 20th-century hermetic motifs for its theological structure and ritual practices.
Any of various centers which offer advice.
A branch and theory of legal studies which holds that traditional legal systems protect the interests of the establishment, rather than promote social justice.

A philosophy and religious tradition founded in the early 20th century by the esotericist Rudolf Steiner that postulates the existence of an objective, intellectually comprehensible spiritual world, accessible to human experience. Followers of anthroposophy aim to develop mental faculties of spiritual discovery through a mode of thought independent of sensory experience.
A center which aims to provide access to the workforce and opportunities for employment.
The study of law and legal systems.
A religious and esoteric tradition based primarily upon writings attributed to Hermes Trismegistus ("thrice-greatest Hermes").
A health center which treats pregnant people and very young children.
The acquisition of knowledge about one's culture or cultures.
An esoteric and occult social or spiritual philosophy and new religious movement developed in the early 1900s by Aleister Crowley, an English writer, mystic, and ceremonial magician.
A center which provides advice regarding health or raising awareness about any of various health issues.
The view that every entity does not have a set of attributes that are necessary to its identity and function. the opposite of essentialism. opposition to essentialism.

A religion established in the United States during the late nineteenth century. It was founded primarily by the Russian immigrant Helena Blavatsky and draws its teachings predominantly from Blavatsky's writings.
Any of various organizations which act as repositories for documentation about LGBTQIA+ persons, or concerning such persons.
Forms of mysticism (and descendant practices) derived from Neoplatonist philosophy, deriving mainly from the Enneads of Plotinus.
Any of various organizations which act as repositories for documentation related to, or otherwise concerning, HIV/AIDS.
An organization, building or complex that promotes culture and arts. Cultural centers can be neighborhood community arts organizations, private facilities, government-sponsored, or activist-run.

Any of various theories which utilize race as a proxy to "correct" or "adjust" some value. Theories of race correction have been utilized widely in health care, and have also been used to adjust test scores. Both practices have been connected with and compared to eugenics and pseudoscientific racism, because the supposed proxy related to these changes is unclear at best, and unduely malicious at worst.

Any of various pseudoscientific movements which purport that masking does not help prevent the spread of disease, or are some sort of conspiracy-related government plot, among other inane explanations. Anti-mask movements gained traction alongside anti-vaccination movements during the COVID-19 pandemic.

An approach to justice in which one of the responses to a crime is to organize a meeting between the victim and the offender, sometimes with representatives of the wider community. The goal is for them to share their experience of what happened, to discuss who was harmed by the crime and how, and to create a consensus for what the offender can do to repair the harm from the offense. This may include a payment of money given from the offender to the victim, apologies and other amends, and other actions to compensate those affected and to prevent the offender from causing future harm.
In vitro fertilization with subsequent transfer to an unrelated surrogate.
Subgroup within a community which has been racialized. alternatively a subgroup within a community which belongs to a socially constructed racial category.

term: in vitro fertilization with intracytoplasmic sperm injection
comment: An in vitro fertilization (IVF) procedure in which a single sperm cell is injected directly into the cytoplasm of an egg. This technique is used in order to prepare the gametes for the obtention of embryos that may be transferred to a maternal uterus. With this method, the acrosome reaction is skipped.
An arrangement, often supported by a legal agreement, whereby a woman (the gestational carrier) agrees to bear a child for another person or people, who will become the child's parent(s) after birth.

The religious beliefs and practices adhered to by the Iron Age people of Western Europe now known as the Celts, roughly between 500 BCE and 500 CE, spanning the La Tène period and the Roman era, and in the case of the Insular Celts the British and Irish Iron Age.
A process where one person, who did not provide the egg used in conception, carries a fetus through pregnancy and gives birth to a baby for another person or couple.
Any of various religions originating among the Celtic peoples.
A person who is associated with sex work in some sense.

Surrogacy in which a surrogate agrees to be artificially inseminated with sperm of a biological father, to gestate the fetus, and then, after birth, the surrogacy is terminated and the surrogate gives up her parental rights in favor of the intending parent or parents.
The religion practiced by the Germanic peoples from the Iron Age until Christianization during the Middle Ages.
Typically, a person nineteen years old or younger who has given birth to a child with which there is some relationship.
The practice of traveling to another country or jurisdiction for fertility treatment, which is regarded as a form of medical tourism.
A political and moral philosophy based on liberty, consent of the governed and equality before the law.
The religious beliefs, myths and ritual practices of the Slavs before Christianization, which occurred at various stages between the 8th and the 13th century.

Any of various theories which utilize race as a proxy for other characteristics. For instance, calling race a social determinant of health, rather than racism, the actual underlying social determinant. The usage of race corrections in health care and "race-norming" could also be considered forms of race proxy theory. However, the original usage of the phrase "race proxy theory" was to describe how white people often use neighborhood racial composition as a proxy for various "social problems" (such as crime).
The political philosophy which emphasizes the moral worth of the individual.
Any of various religions originating among the Slavic peoples.
A healthcare facility that provides comprehensive, high-quality primary health care services for children.
The religion practiced by the Baltic peoples until the period of Christianization, in the 15th and 16th centuries.
Any of various organizations which act as repositories for particular kinds of documentation.
A political ideology and a branch of liberalism which advocates civil liberties under the rule of law with an emphasis on economic freedom.
Any of various religions originating among the Baltic peoples.

A reclaimed or reappropriated word is a word that was at one time pejorative but has been brought back into acceptable usage, usually starting within its original target, i.e. the communities that were pejoratively described by that word, and later spreading to the general populace as well.
Racism which is endemic and especially widespread within a particular society, group, and/or area.

A modern Pagan religion developed in Europe during the early 20th century. Its practitioners model it on the pre-Christian belief systems adhered to by the Germanic peoples of the Iron Age and Early Middle Ages.
An organization where a specified activity is concentrated. A place where a particular activity or service is concentrated.

A concept in the environmental justice movement, which developed in the United States throughout the 1970s and 1980s. The term is used to describe environmental injustice that occurs within a racialized context both in practice and policy. In the United States, environmental racism criticizes inequalities between urban and exurban areas after white flight. Internationally, environmental racism can refer to the effects of the global waste trade, like the negative health impact of the export of electronic waste to China from developed countries.

A religion which arose primarily from the 18th century Romanticist movement in Britain, which glorified the ancient Celtic peoples of the Iron Age. The early neo-Druids aimed to imitate the Iron Age priests who were also known as druids.
Organizations organized by type, such as associations, collectives, cooperatives, trade unions, etc.
A email list in which any subscriber may post.
A type of justice accessible primarily or assisted primarily through digital means. alternatively, social justice within digital environments.

The religious beliefs and practices followed by the Anglo-Saxons between the 5th and 8th centuries CE, during the initial period of Early Medieval England. A variant of Germanic paganism found across much of north-western Europe, it encompassed a heterogeneous variety of beliefs and cultic practices, with much regional variation.
Organizations organized by subject of focus.
A special use of email that allows for widespread distribution of information to many Internet users.

A Mexican person of predominantly Sub-Saharan African descent and heritage. As a single population, Afro-Mexicans includes individuals descended from Black slaves brought to Mexico during the colonial era in the transatlantic African slave trade, as well as others of more recent immigrant African descent, including Afro-descended persons from neighboring English, French, and Spanish-speaking countries of the Caribbean and Central America, descendants of fugitive slaves who escaped to Mexico from the Southern United States, and to a lesser extent recent immigrants directly from Africa.
Note that the term "Blaxican" should only be used by members identifying within that community.

A branch of Germanic religion which developed during the Proto-Norse period, when the North Germanic peoples separated into a distinct branch of the Germanic peoples. It was replaced by Christianity during the Christianization of Scandinavia.
High-risk sexual behavior during the period of adolescence.
An individual who engages with a sex worker for some form of sexual services.

A particular form of longitudinal survey that samples a cohort (a group of people who share a defining characteristic, typically those who experienced a common event in a selected period, such as birth or graduation), performing a cross-section at intervals through time.

A research design that involves repeated observations of the same variables (e.g., people) over short or long periods of time (i.e., uses longitudinal data). It is often a type of observational study, although they can also be structured as longitudinal randomized experiments.
Asexuality is the lack of sexual attraction to others, or low or absent interest in or desire for sexual activity.
Asexuality is the lack of sexual attraction to others, or low or absent interest in or desire for sexual activity.
Asexuality is the lack of sexual attraction to others, or low or absent interest in or desire for sexual activity.
An ideology which expresses perspectives on any of various aspects of history or methods utilized when constructing historical narratives.

The re-interpretation of an historical account or accounts. Historical revisionism usually involves challenging the orthodox (established, accepted or traditional) views held by professional scholars about a historical event or time-span or phenomenon, introducing contrary evidence, or reinterpreting the motivations and decisions of the people involved. The revision of the historical record can reflect new discoveries of fact, evidence, and interpretation, which then results in revised history. In dramatic cases, revisionism involves a reversal of older moral judgments.
The belief that races are biologically distinct groups with definable "essences".

A theory of intergroup relations that focuses on the maintenance and stability of group-based social hierarchies. According to the theory, group-based inequalities are maintained through three primary intergroup behaviors: institutional discrimination, aggregated individual discrimination, and behavioral asymmetry. The theory proposes that widely shared cultural ideologies (i.e., legitimizing myths) provide the moral and intellectual justification for these intergroup behaviors.
The study of the methodology of historians and the development of "history" as a discipline.

The systematic, theoretical analysis of the methods applied to a field of study. It comprises the theoretical analysis of the body of methods and principles associated with a branch of knowledge. Typically, it encompasses concepts such as paradigm, theoretical model, phases and quantitative or qualitative techniques.

A member church of the worldwide Anglican Communion and is based in the United States with additional dioceses elsewhere. It is a mainline Christian denomination divided into nine provinces. The presiding bishop of the Episcopal Church is Michael Bruce Curry, the first African-American bishop to serve in that position. The Episcopal Church was active in the Social Gospel movement of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Since the 1960s and 1970s, the church has pursued a decidedly more liberal course. It has opposed the death penalty and supported the civil rights movement and affirmative action. The church calls for the full legal equality of LGBTQIA+ people. In 2015, the church's 78th triennial General Convention passed resolutions allowing the blessing of same-sex marriages and approved two official liturgies to bless such unions.

A form of religious fundamentalism which began in the late 19th and early 20th centuries among British and American Protestants as a reaction to theological liberalism and cultural modernism. Fundamentalists argued that 19th-century modernist theologians had misinterpreted or rejected certain doctrines, especially biblical inerrancy, which they considered the fundamentals of the Christian faith.[3] Fundamentalists are almost always described as having a literal interpretation of the Bible.
Any of various sports which take place in, or on, a body of water.

A religious philosophy held by some persons (religious fundamentalists) or groups which is characterized by a markedly strict literalism as it is applied to certain specific scriptures, dogmas, or ideologies, and a strong sense of the importance of maintaining ingroup and outgroup distinctions, leading to an emphasis on purity and the desire to return to a previous ideal from which advocates believe members have strayed.
Education within an academic institution or institutions.
Theories which involve topics such as politics, liberty, justice, property, rights, law, and the enforcement of laws by authority.

An African diasporic religion that developed in Cuba between the 16th and 19th centuries. It arose through a process of syncretism between the traditional Yoruba religion of West Africa and the Roman Catholic form of Christianity. There is no central authority in control of the movement, which comprises adherents known as creyente and initiates known as santeros (males) and santeras (females).
Granuloma of the genital and/or groin regions, typically caused by infection by the bacteria Klebsiella granulomati.

A variation of essentialism which purports that differences from a "norm" of essential qualities for a group may simply be treated as slight variations and thus not disrupt the status quo of the group's qualities in question.

An ethnic group that inhabits western Africa, mainly the countries of Nigeria, Benin, Ghana, Togo, Ivory Coast, Sierra Leone, Liberia, Senegal, The Gambia and Brazil (as a cultural language in RDJ (state) and Salvador, Bahia. The Yoruba constitute around 47 million people worldwide. The vast majority of this population is from Nigeria, where the Yoruba make up 21% of the country's population, making them one of the largest ethnic groups in Africa. Most Yoruba people speak the Yoruba language, which is the Niger-Congo language with the largest number of native speakers.
Lymphogranuloma venereum caused by Chlamydia, usually one of the invasive serovars L1, L2, L2a, L2b, or L3 of Chlamydia trachomatis.
A naturalistic approach to law. It is the view that jurisprudence should emulate the methods of natural science, i.e., rely on empirical evidence.

The traditional religious and spiritual concepts and practice of the Yoruba tribe. Its homeland is in present-day Southwestern Nigeria which comprised Oyo, Ogun, Osun, Ondo, Ekiti, and Kwara as well as Lagos States, parts of Kogi state and the adjoining parts of Benin and Togo, commonly known as Yorubaland. It shares some parallels with the Vodun practiced by the neighboring Fon and Ewe peoples to the west and to the religion of the Edo people to the east.
A lymphogranuloma which is venereal in nature, i.e. caused by a sexually transmitted infection, typically by Chlamydia, and involves inflammation of the inguinal lymph glands.
Any of various theories related to law or legal systems.

A set of beliefs and practices invented by American author L. Ron Hubbard, and an associated movement. It has been variously defined as a cult, a business or a new religious movement. Hubbard initially developed a set of ideas which he represented as a form of therapy, called Dianetics. This he promoted through various publications, and through the Hubbard Dianetic Research Foundation, which he established in 1950. The foundation soon entered bankruptcy, and Hubbard lost the rights to his book Dianetics: The Modern Science of Mental Health in 1952. He then recharacterized the subject as a religion and renamed it Scientology, retaining the terminology, doctrines, and the practice of "auditing". Within a year, he regained the rights to Dianetics and retained both subjects under the umbrella of the Church of Scientology.
Granuloma of the lymphatics and/or lymph nodes.

Any religion in which the existence of extraterrestrial (ET) entities operating unidentified flying objects (UFOs) is an element of belief. Typically, adherents of such religions believe the ETs to be interested in the welfare of humanity which either already is, or eventually will become, part of a pre-existing ET civilization.
A lesion which is related to, or characterized by, granuloma.

Any of a range of spiritual or religious beliefs and practices which rapidly grew in the Western world during the 1970s. Precise scholarly definitions of the New Age differ in their emphasis, largely as a result of its highly eclectic structure. As a form of Western esotericism, the New Age drew heavily upon a number of older esoteric traditions, in particular, those that emerged from the occultist current that developed in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries. Such prominent occultist influences include the work of Emanuel Swedenborg and Franz Mesmer, as well as the ideas of Spiritualism, New Thought, and Theosophy.
A lesion which is inflammed or inflammatory in nature.

Any of various spiritual beliefs or practices (chiefly neopagan) which emerged predominantly in North America, Western Europe, Australia, and New Zealand in the 1970s, which arose from perceptions of predominant organized religion as male-dominated. Such religions usually make use of goddess worship and have a focus on gender and femininity.
A sexually transmitted disease caused by the invasive serovars L1, L2, L2a, L2b, or L3 of Chlamydia trachomatis.
A sexually transmitted disease that is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.
Radical feminist ideologies based upon exclusionary activity criteria regarding sex work and sex workers.

A critical term for types of feminism that advocate for enhancing and increasing prison sentences that deal with feminist and gender issues. It is the belief that harsher and longer prison sentences will help work towards solving these issues. The phrase "carceral feminism" was coined by feminist sociologist Elizabeth Bernstein in her 2007 article, "The Sexual Politics of the 'New Abolitionism'". Examining the contemporary anti-trafficking movement in the United States, Bernstein introduced the term to describe a type of feminist activism which casts all forms of sexual labor as sex-trafficking.

A political movement that advocates replacing policing with other systems of public safety. Police abolitionists believe that policing, as a system, is inherently flawed and cannot be reformed—a view that rejects the ideology of police reformists. While reformists seek to address the ways in which policing occurs, abolitionists seek to transform policing altogether through a process of disbanding, disempowering, and disarming the police. Abolitionists argue that the institution of policing is deeply rooted in a history of white supremacy and settler colonialism and that it is inseparable from a pre-existing racial capitalist order, and thus believe a reformist approach to policing will always fail.
A birth certificate provided shortly after birth for a newborn.

A short form of digital media production that allows everyday people to share aspects of their story. The media used may include the digital equivalent of film techniques , stills, audio only, or any of the other forms of non-physical media (material that exists only as electronic files as opposed to actual paintings or photographs on paper, sounds stored on tape or disc, movies stored on film) which individuals can use to tell a story or present an idea.

term: birth certificate after gender marker change
comment: An amended birth certificate which replaces an original birth certificate after a court-ordered (or other legal) gender marker change.
The social and cultural activity of orally sharing stories, sometimes with improvisation, theatrics or embellishment.
An amended birth certificate which replaces an original birth certificate after a court-ordered (or other legal) name change.

May refer to either (a) storytelling which aims to replace rhetorical structures of the existing social order which unfairly discriminate. or (b) storytelling as part of any of the various legal professions.

A method of storytelling which focuses on persons whose experiences are not often reflected in mainstream storytelling and/or storytelling which casts doubt on accepted myths, stereotypes, and prejudices often held by the majority in society.
An inventory which assesses an individual's knowledge in some specific area or areas.
An inventory which assesses an individual's knowledge in some specific area or areas of sexuality, sexual health, or other sexual knowledge.
Oral presentation of various forms of literature.

An African diasporic religion that developed in Haiti between the 16th and 19th centuries. It arose through a process of syncretism between the traditional religions of West Africa and Roman Catholicism.

A queer neopagan tradition founded in the summer of 2004 by seven gay men from diverse traditions such as ceremonial magic, shamanism, and pre-Gardnerian witchcraft in order to create an ecumenical neopagan tradition which serves the community of men who love men. In 2017, the Seattle Temple began a reformation within the group to expand the tradition to be "open to all queer/LBGTQIA adults" which has been accepted throughout. Fellowship theology has been modified to fit an expanded, inclusive model.

A branch of science studying formal language disciplines concerned with formal systems, such as logic, mathematics, statistics, theoretical computer science, artificial intelligence, information theory, game theory, systems theory, decision theory, and theoretical linguistics.
A Minoan tradition founded in 1976 by Lady Rhea and Lady Miw-Sekhmet, in collaboration with Edmund Buczynski, as the women's counterpart to the Minoan Brotherhood.
An infectious disease that is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

A Minoan tradition founded in 1975 by Edmund Buczynski, an elder in the Gardnerian, WICA, and New York Welsh Traditions, in order to create a tradition for gay and bisexual men—one that would celebrate and explore the distinctive mysteries unique to men who love men.
An infection that is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

A form of paganism which purports to derive from ancient Minoan religion. because little is known of that religion, however, it is not considered reconstructionist, and therefore also oftentimes incorporates a ritual framework descended from Gardnerian Wicca.
Any of various policies regarding LGBTQ rights.

The process of ascribing ethnic or racial identities to a relationship, social practice, or group that did not identify itself as such. Racialization or ethnicization often arises out of the interaction of a group with a group that it dominates and ascribes a racial identity to for the purpose of continued domination. While this ascribed identity is often born out of domination, the racialized and ethnicized group often gradually identifies with and even embraces this identity and thus becomes a self-ascribed race or ethnicity. These processes have been common throughout the history of imperialism, nationalism, and racial and ethnic hierarchies.

The religion of the Bronze Age Minoan civilization of Crete. Modern scholars have reconstructed it almost totally on the basis of archaeological remains rather than texts. Minoan religion is considered to have been closely related to Near Eastern prehistoric religions, and its central deity is generally agreed to have been a goddess. Prominent Minoan sacred symbols include the bull and its horns of consecration, the labrys (double-headed axe), the serpent, and to some extent, the ankh.
Any of various policies regarding human rights.

A concept that has been applied to prejudices and discrimination based on cultural differences between ethnic or racial groups. This includes the idea that some cultures are superior to others, and that various cultures are fundamentally incompatible and should not co-exist in the same society or state. In this it differs from biological or scientific racism, meaning prejudices and discrimination rooted in perceived biological differences between ethnic or racial groups.
A term encompassing the polytheistic religions of the Semitic peoples from the ancient Near East and Northeast Africa.

A computer server running software that allows users to connect to the system using a terminal program. Once logged in, the user can perform functions such as uploading and downloading software and data, reading news and bulletins, and exchanging messages with other users through public message boards and sometimes via direct chatting.
Racialization which is produced by inter-institutional arrangements and interactions.
Any of various computer networks used commonly with bulletin board systems.
A process by which racial groups are viewed and treated differently by a majority group or groups (or mainstream society).
An initiatory tradition of modern Pagan witchcraft. It was founded in California in the 1960s by the Americans Victor Henry Anderson and his wife Cora Anderson.
Any of various organizations which act as repositories for documentation about men, or concerning men.

Any of various neopagan traditions and/or sects which were founded by LGBTQIA+ persons, primarily include LGBTQIA+ persons among their membership, or are defined in some capacity by LGBTQIA+ acceptance.
A center which offers legal information, advice, referrals, and, in some cases, brief services, specifically for youth.

A collective term for new religious movements influenced by or derived from the various historical pagan beliefs of pre-modern peoples. Although they share similarities, contemporary Pagan religious movements are diverse, and do not share a single set of beliefs, practices, or texts.
Any of various detention centers typically designed for immigrants, or in which a majority immigrant population is in detention.
Any of various detention centers typically designed for youth, or in which a majority youth population is in detention.

A social media specific term used to refer to a form of digital Blackface in which non-Black persons change their appearance and online persona to appear Black (whether it be via makeup, spray tans, certain hair products, or even surgery).

A term used to describe a form of theatrical make-up and impersonation style used predominantly by non-East Asian performers to represent a caricature of a East Asian person. It is almost always considered to be extremely offensive.
Almost always offensive impersonation of an Asian person in any of various forms. Nearly exclusively a form of cultural appropriation and discrimination.
Almost always offensive impersonation of a Black person in any of various forms. Nearly exclusively a form of cultural appropriation and discrimination.

An act in which an entertainer who dresses stereotypically, exaggeratedly, or otherwise provocatively as a person of a different socially constructed race. Such acts are usually highly offensive, but depend on heavily on social context and power dynamics (for instance blackface is almost exclusively derogatory whereas whiteface almost always is not).

A form of Blackface involving any of various digital media, in which persons utilize or directly impersonate Black personages (whether it be mimicking a "Black" manner of speaking, usage of Black emojis or Black reaction GIFs, as well as full-on pretending to be a Black person).

A term used to describe a form of theatrical make-up and impersonation style used predominantly by non-Black performers to represent a caricature of a Black person. It is almost always considered to be extremely offensive.

A rapist who is a sadist and who for whom sexual excitement is associated with the causing of suffering upon their victim. The offender finds the intentional maltreatment of their victim intensely gratifying and takes pleasure in the victim's torment, anguish, distress, helplessness, and suffering. the offender finds the victim's struggling an erotic experience.
The term being used to describe the wearing of feathers, warpaint, etc. by non-natives which perpetuate Native American stereotypes, analogous to the wearing of Blackface.

A rapist who uses rape to humiliate, debase, and hurt their victim. they express their contempt for their victim through physical violence and profane language. For these rapists, sex is a weapon to defile and degrade the victim, rape constitutes the ultimate expression of their anger. This rapist considers rape the ultimate offense they can commit against the victim.
Any of various clothing used in the performance of drag.
Almost always offensive impersonation of a Native American person in any of various forms. Nearly exclusively a form of cultural appropriation and discrimination.

A rapist who uses rape as a way to compensate for their underlying feelings of inadequacy and feeds their issues of mastery, control, strength, authority and capability. The intent of the power rapist is to assert their competency. The power rapist relies upon verbal threats, intimidation with a weapon, and uses only the amount of force necessary to subdue the victim.
A name of a non-living thing or group of non-living things.

term: person who has been convicted of rape
comment: A person who has been convicted of a rape or rapes.
A name of a living thing, a group of living things, or something that was once living.

term: person who has been convicted of a sex crime
comment: A person who has been convicted of a sex crime or crimes.
A code which is used as part of an identification process.

term: person who has been charged with a sex crime
comment: A person who has been charged with a sex crime or crimes.
A systematic review of medical literature or a systematic review which is medical in nature.

term: person who has been charged with a crime
comment: A person who has been charged with a crime or crimes.

An individual or individuals who have been convicted of rape (as well as those in which substantive evidence, contemporary or historical, makes it extremely likely that they were or are guilty of rape).
An allied health practioner is an individual that provides specialized diagnostic, technical, therapeutic, and support services in connection with health care.

term: person who has committed a sex crime
comment: A person who is guilty of a sex crime.
A campaign which is an effort to damage or call into question someone's reputation, by propounding negative propaganda which may or may not be true.
Any of various LGBTQIA+ events related to sports.
An infectious disease by fungi of the genus Saccharomyces.
Any person who relays information between two or more groups or organizations.
People as organized by employment status.
Love letters written by members of the LGBTQIA+ community expressing any of various queer forms of love.

Digital literature which primarily utilizes hypertext, i.e. text displayed on a computer display or other electronic devices with references (hyperlinks) to other text that the reader can immediately access.
A literary medium genre consisting of works of literature that originate within digital media environments and require digital computation devices to be read.
Philosophical theories falling under the scope of the field of epistemology.
An expression of love in written form. However delivered, the letter may be anything from a short and simple message of love to a lengthy explanation of feelings.

The view that perception, experience, and reason change according to the viewer's relative perspective and interpretation. It rejects the idea of "one unchanging and essential world accessible to neutral representation by a disembodied subject."

The view that perception, experience, and reason change according to the viewer's relative perspective and interpretation. It rejects the idea of "one unchanging and essential world accessible to neutral representation by a disembodied subject."

term: Unification Church of the United States
comment: A religious cult which began in the 1950s and 1960s when missionaries from Japan and South Korea were sent to the United States by the international Unification movement's founder and leader Sun Myung Moon. It expanded in the 1970s and then became involved in controversy due to its theology, its political activism, and the lifestyle of its members. Since then it has been involved in many areas of American society and has established businesses, news media, projects in education and the arts as well as taking part in political and social activism, and has itself gone through substantial changes.

A worldwide church whose members are sometimes colloquially called "Moonies". It was officially founded in 1954 under the name Holy Spirit Association for the Unification of World Christianity (HSA-UWC) in Seoul, South Korea by Sun Myung Moon (1920–2012), a Korean religious leader also known for his business ventures and engagement in social and political causes. The beliefs of the Unification movement are based on Moon's book Divine Principle, which differs from the teachings of Nicene Christianity on its view of Jesus and its introduction of the concept of "indemnity". The movement is well known for its unique "Blessing" or mass wedding ceremonies. It also has unique funeral ceremonies for its members. The Unification movement has attracted numerous controversies, and has been called a dangerous cult.
People as organized by occupation.

An advanced behavior whereby an individual observes and replicates another's behavior. Imitation is also a form of social learning that leads to the "development of traditions, and ultimately our culture. It allows for the transfer of information (behaviours, customs, etc.) between individuals and down generations without the need for genetic inheritance."
Mimicking or copying the movements of other individuals as a means of interaction and play as well as to learn by modeling the actions and behaviors of others.

Any of various religions deriving from those of Protestantism, but having more independent and autonomous styles of church governance. such churches tend to be isolated from other Protestant denominations and are often considered cults by other Protestants.
Makeup that is used to assist in creating the appearance of the characters that actors portray during a theater production.

A worldwide new religious movement whose members are sometimes colloquially called "Moonies". It was officially founded in 1954 under the name Holy Spirit Association for the Unification of World Christianity (HSA-UWC) in Seoul, South Korea by Sun Myung Moon (1920–2012), a Korean religious leader also known for his business ventures and engagement in social and political causes.
An interdisciplinary academic field that is primarily devoted to the study of the history, culture, and politics of Afro-European people.
Any of various new religious movements associated with Christianity.
An interdisciplinary academic field that is primarily devoted to the study of the history, culture, and politics of Afro-Caribbean peoples.
A type of imitation in which someone who imitates or copies the behavior or actions of another for any of various reasons.

An American extremist cult and hate group known for engaging in pickets with inflammatory homophobic, transphobic, anti-American, anti-atheist, anti-Christian, antisemitic, anti-Mormon, and Islamophobic hate speech. It is not affiliated with any Baptist denomination and has been denounced by Baptist conventions, including the Baptist World Alliance and the Southern Baptist Convention, and by other mainstream Christian denominations. The Westboro Baptist Church (WBC) has been involved in actions against LGBTQ+ people since at least 1991, when it sought a crackdown on homosexual activity at Gage Park near its headquarters. In addition to conducting anti-gay protests at military funerals, the organization pickets celebrity funerals and public events. Protests have also been held against Jews, against Mormons, and against Catholics. Many protests have included WBC members defacing the American flag, flying the flag upside down on a flagpole, and holding protest signs with inflammatory statements. the most notable of which being "God hates fags" and "Thank God for dead soldiers".

The study of Africa, especially the continent's cultures and societies (as opposed to its geology, geography, zoology, etc.). The field includes the study of Africa's history (pre-colonial, colonial, post-colonial), demography (ethnic groups), culture, politics, economy, languages, and religion (Islam, Christianity, traditional religions).

A branch of Protestant theology that denies the universal duty of human beings to believe in Christ for the salvation of their souls. It is at times regarded as a variation of Calvinism, but critics emphasize its differences from traditional Calvinistic beliefs.
An interdisciplinary field of research and scholarship pertaining to particular geographical, national/federal, or cultural regions.
Any of various Protestant churches in the Reformed tradition practising congregationalist church governance, in which each congregation independently and autonomously runs its own affairs.
An interdisciplinary academic field that is primarily devoted to the study of the history, culture, and politics of African Americans.

A mainline Protestant Christian denomination based in the United States, with historical confessional roots in the Congregational, Reformed, and Lutheran traditions, and with approximately 4,852 churches and 802,356 members. The United Church of Christ is a historical continuation of the General Council of Congregational Christian churches founded under the influence of New England Pilgrims and Puritans. Moreover, it also subsumed the third largest Reformed group in the country, the German Reformed. The Evangelical and Reformed Church and the General Council of the Congregational Christian Churches united in 1957 to form the UCC. These two denominations, which were themselves the result of earlier unions, had their roots in Congregational, Lutheran, Evangelical, and Reformed denominations. The national settings of the UCC have historically favored liberal views on social issues, such as civil rights, LGBTQ rights, women's rights, and abortion. However, United Church of Christ congregations are independent in matters of doctrine and ministry and may not necessarily support the national body's theological or moral stances. It self-describes as "an extremely pluralistic and diverse denomination".
An interdisciplinary academic field that is primarily devoted to the study of the history, culture, and politics of Black persons or Blackness as a concept.
Any of various mainline Protestant movements or religions which aims to bring about closer relationships among their churches and promote Christian unity.
Any of various religions originating in Asia.
Any of various sports which take place primarily in, or on, a body of snow and/or ice.
An event in which an organism is killed.
Extermination of national culture as a genocide component.

A West African creole language lexified by pidgin English and local African languages. It originated as a language of commerce between British and African slave traders during the period of the Atlantic slave trade. As of 2017, about 75 million people in Nigeria, Cameroon, Ghana and Equatorial Guinea use the language.
Intentional action to destroy a people (usually defined as an ethnic, national, racial, or religious group) in whole or in part.
Any of various English-based creole languages deriving primarily from the region of the African coast of West Africa which lies along the Gulf of Guinea.
A process in which a sounding rod (oftentimes simply referred to as a sound) is introduced into a body passage, typically for probing and/or dilation.
The act of putting something into or in between an area(s) of the body.
An instrument for probing and dilating passages within the body, the best-known examples of which are urethral sounds and uterine sounds.

The medical use of probes called sounds to increase the inner diameter of the urethra and to locate obstructions in it. Sounds are also used to stretch the urethra in order to receive genital piercing.
A language family includes the Japanese language, spoken in the main islands of Japan, and the Ryukyuan languages, spoken in the Ryukyu Islands.
Any of various dialects of English primarily spoken in the region of, and the regions directly surrounding, Australia.
Any of various medical procedures which introduce an object and/or substance into or onto the body.
Sexual intercourse in which some anatomical structure is inserted into the urethra.
Any pseudoscientific theory, idea, or belief which purports various claims about chemical entities and/or processes.

A pseudoscientific practice using the language of physics or discussing issues related to or pertinent to physics to promote ideas which are either incoherent or contradictory to known physics (experimental phenomenology).
A killing of multiple members of a group without the intention of eliminating the entire group. also, killing large numbers of people without precise group membership definitions.
Under the strictest definition, incidents of non-combat killing of 50,000 people or more.
Any pseudoscientific theory, idea, or belief which purports various claims about astronomical bodies and the universe.
Killing in which one person or persons kill more than one person.
A pseudoscience that claims to divine information about human affairs and terrestrial events by studying the movements and relative positions of celestial objects.
Killing in which one person or persons kills another person.

An ancient branch of natural philosophy, a philosophical and protoscientific tradition practiced throughout Europe, Africa, China and throughout Asia, observable in Chinese text from around 73–49 BCE and Greco-Roman Egypt in the first few centuries CE. Alchemists attempted to purify, mature, and perfect certain materials. Common aims were chrysopoeia, the transmutation of "base metals" (e.g., lead) into "noble metals" (particularly gold). the creation of an elixir of immortality. the creation of panaceas able to cure any disease. and the development of an alkahest, a universal solvent. The perfection of the human body and soul was thought to permit or result from the alchemical magnum opus and, in the Hellenistic and Western mystery tradition, the achievement of gnosis. In Europe, the creation of a philosopher's stone was variously connected with all of these projects.
Any of various events during which a person or person's other than one's self are killed.
A non-scientific field of study which becomes a field of science.
Any of various rates of fertility.
The number of deaths per given unit of population over a given period of time.
The ratio of live births in an area to the population of that area, expressed per 1000 people in the population per year.
Births in 1 year x 1,000/number of women aged 15-44 at midyear.
Any of various rates involving number of births in a population. usually used as shorthand for crude birth rate.
Conferences specific to women.
Marches including political rallies for the purposes of women's rights or other women's movements.
A presentation of a topic to an audience at a conference.
Almost always offensive impersonation of a Brown person in any of various forms. Nearly exclusively a form of cultural appropriation and discrimination.

A grammatically simplified means of communication that develops between two or more groups that do not have a language in common: typically, its vocabulary and grammar are limited and often drawn from several languages. It is most commonly employed in situations such as trade, or where both groups speak languages different from the language of the country in which they reside (but where there is no common language between the groups).
A language that arises among a bilingual group combining aspects of two or more languages but not clearly deriving primarily from any single language.
Spoken or written language as used in ordinary communications between individuals and groups.

Any language that has evolved naturally in humans through use and repetition without conscious planning or premeditation. Natural languages can take different forms, such as speech or signing. They are distinguished from constructed and formal languages such as those used to program computers or to study logic.

A stable natural language that develops from the simplifying and mixing of different languages into a new one within a fairly brief period of time: often, a pidgin evolved into a full-fledged language.
Almost always offensive impersonation of a Jewish person in any of various forms, mostly of a racial nature. Nearly exclusively a form of cultural appropriation and discrimination.

A variation of Blackface in which a person imitates a person of Latin American, Middle Eastern, North African, Maritime Southeast Asian, Polynesian, Native American, and/or South Asian ethnic origin. This can be done using makeup, hair-dye, and/or by wearing traditional ethnic clothing to make a person appear as though they belong one of these "Brown" ethnic groups. It is typically defined as a racist phenomenon, whether or not the offender intended to be racist.
Impersonation of another person in which their identity is assumed in order to either gain benefit or to cause harm to that person.

A vaudeville act that became popular among Eastern European Jews who immigrated to the United States in the 1880s. The name plays off of the term "Blackface," and the act featured performers enacting Jewish stereotypes, wearing large putty noses, long beards, and tattered clothing, and speaking with thick Yiddish accent. Early portrayals were done by non-Jews, but Jews soon began to produce their own "Jewface" acts. By the early 20th century, almost all the "Jewface" actors, managers, agents, and audience members were Jewish. "Jewface" featured Jewish dialect music, written by Tin Pan Alley songwriters. These vaudeville acts were controversial at the time. In 1909 a prominent Reform rabbi said that comedy like this was "the cause of greater prejudice against the Jews as a class than all other causes combined," and that same year the Central Conference of American Rabbis denounced this type of comedy.
A slogan related to HIV/AIDS.
Any of various Creole languages based on English.

A drink historically described as a distilled, highly alcoholic beverage (45–74% ABV / 90–148 U.S. proof). It is an anise-flavoured spirit derived from botanicals, including the flowers and leaves of Artemisia absinthium ("grand wormwood"), together with green anise, sweet fennel, and other medicinal and culinary herbs. Absinthe has often been portrayed as a dangerously addictive psychoactive drug and hallucinogen. The chemical compound thujone, which is present in the spirit in trace amounts, was blamed for its alleged harmful effects. By 1915, absinthe had been banned in the United States and in much of Europe, including France, the Netherlands, Belgium, Switzerland, and Austria–Hungary, yet it has not been demonstrated to be any more dangerous than ordinary spirits. Recent studies have shown that absinthe's psychoactive properties have been exaggerated, apart from that of the alcohol.
An alcoholic drink produced by distillation of grains, fruits, or vegetables that have already gone through alcoholic fermentation.

The Gender and Development (GAD) approach focuses on the socially constructed differences between men and women, the need to challenge existing gender roles and relations, and the creation and effects of class differences on development.

An umbrella term for religious beliefs that consider Satan to be an objectively existing deity, supernatural being, or force which is worthy of worship and supplication, whom individuals may contact, convene with and even praise, rather than just an archetype, a metaphor, a symbol, or an idea as in LaVeyan Satanism.

A broad concept denoting the idea that societies and countries have differing levels of "development" on an international scale. It is the basis for international classifications such as developed country, developing country and least developed country, and for a field of practice and research that in various ways engages with international development processes. There are, however, many schools of thought and conventions regarding which are the exact features constituting the "development" of a country.

A belief system that venerates the essential characteristics that are affixed to Lucifer. The tradition, influenced by Gnosticism, usually reveres Lucifer not as the devil, but as a destroyer, a guardian, liberator, light bringer or guiding spirit to darkness, or even the true god as opposed to Jehovah.
A public sector term, is the process by which the economic well-being and quality of life of a nation, region or local community are improved according to targeted goals and objectives.
Mobilization of human, financial, capital, physical and or natural resources to generate goods and services.. Increase in the level of production of goods and services.

A collection of religious ideas and systems which originated in the first century AD among early Christian and Jewish sects. These various groups emphasised personal spiritual knowledge (gnosis) over the orthodox teachings, traditions, and authority of the church. Viewing material existence as flawed or evil, Gnostic cosmogony generally presents a distinction between a supreme, hidden God and a malevolent lesser divinity (sometimes associated with the Yahweh of the Old Testament) who is responsible for creating the material universe. Gnostics considered the principal element of salvation to be direct knowledge of the supreme divinity in the form of mystical or esoteric insight. Many Gnostic texts deal not in concepts of sin and repentance, but with illusion and enlightenment.
An act of religious devotion, usually directed towards a deity.
Sexual arousal or gratification contingent on the death of a human being.
Any of various behaviors motivated by religious beliefs.
A homicide in which the offender searches for erotic satisfaction by killing someone.
Murders organized by some categorical typing that isn't by method.

An approach of development projects that emerged in the 1960s, calling for treatment of women's issues in development projects. It is the integration of women into the global economies by improving their status and assisting in total development. Later, the Gender and development (GAD) approach proposed more emphasis on gender relations rather than seeing women's issues in isolation.

An Indigenous people of the Southeastern Woodlands. Their traditional territory was in the Southeastern United States of Mississippi, Alabama and Tennessee. Their language is classified as a member of the Muskogean language family. In the present day, they are organized as the federally recognized Chickasaw Nation.
Any of various Indigenous American peoples who speak languages that are members of the Muskogean language family.
Coercion of a sexual nature.
An exercise to strengthen the pelvic floor muscles, in which the levator muscles are squeezed and held, then released, for a number of repetitions.
How one chooses (or is forced) to express their sexuality.
Mass killing, injury and/or damage to property deliberately committed with a vehicle.
A situation in which a person has previous engaged in sexual intercourse, but makes some type of commitment to not be sexually active again until marriage or some other point in the future.
Criminal behavior which involves vehicles, typically cars, directly.
Oral intercourse practiced simultaneously, with each other's mouths placed on or near one another's genitals.
A group sex act in which one participant is ejaculated on by two or more other participants. It is often portrayed in pornographic films.
A group sex act in which one participant is ejaculated on by two or more other participants. It is often portrayed in pornographic films.
A substance which is part of a device or is otherwise required for a device or its various subprocesses.
An anomaly of the uterus which involves a hypoplastic or T-shaped uterus.
Race riots primarily involving Black Americans.
A type of mullerian anomaly in the human uterus, where there is a deep indentation at the fundus (top) of the uterus.
Race riots primarily involving white Americans.
A form of a uterine anomaly or variation where the uterine cavity displays a concave contour towards the fundus.

term: race riot in the United States
comment: Race riots taking place primarily in the United States.
Gender analysis is a type of socio-economic analysis that uncovers how gender relations affect a development problem.
The average number of daughters that would be born to a female (or a group of females) if she passed through her lifetime conforming to the age-specific fertility and mortality rates of a given year.
Any of various rates of reproduction or reproductive ability.

The average number of daughters a woman would have if she survived all of her childbearing years, which is roughly to the age of 45, subject to the age-specific fertility rate and sex ratio at birth throughout that period.
Care in which any of a variety of non-medical services are offered by various institutions to improve quality of life, especially those in vulnerable situations.
Contiguous large-scale (1000-400,000 basepairs) differences in the genomic DNA between individuals, due to sequence deletion. sequence insertion. or sequence inversion.
Any of various Indigenous peoples in North America which primarily speak languages belonging to the Iroquoian language family.
The number of offspring that would be born per woman if they were to live through their childbearing years, bearing offspring in accordance with current age-specific fertility rates.
A genetic polymorphism that is part of a DNA molecule.
A tribe of Native Americans historically living on the plains of Colorado and Wyoming. They were close allies of the Cheyenne tribe and loosely aligned with the Lakota and Dakota.
The number of births per one thousand women of a given age group in a given region for a specified amount of time.
Increase or decrease of the number of copies of a chromosomal region. Sizes of copy number variations range from about 1 kilobase to several megabases.

One of the most populous and widespread North American Indigenous language groups. Today, thousands of individuals identify with various Algonquian peoples. Historically, the peoples were prominent along the Atlantic Coast and into the interior along the Saint Lawrence River and around the Great Lakes. This grouping consists of the peoples who speak Algonquian languages.
The number of intentional homicides per given unit of population over a given period of time.
An allele is one of a set of sequence variants of a gene.

A First Nation in the Canadian provinces of Ontario and Manitoba, residing in a narrow band extending from the Missinaibi River region in Northeastern Ontario at the east to Lake Winnipeg at the west. The Oji-Cree people are descended from historical intermarriage between the Ojibwa and Cree cultures, but are generally considered a nation distinct from either of their ancestral groups.
The number of homicides per given unit of population over a given period of time.
A variation in or modification of the molecular sequence of a gene or gene product.

One of the Indigenous peoples of the Great Plains that speak a language that is a member of the Algonquian language family. The Cheyenne comprise two Native American tribes, the Só'taeo'o or Só'taétaneo'o (more commonly spelled as Suhtai or Sutaio) and the Tsétsêhéstâhese (also spelled Tsitsistas). These tribes merged in the early 19th century.
Any kind of violence considered to have a "massive" scope.
A mutation in an organism's DNA.
A Cherokee person who is part of a certain non-binary cultural gender role in those communities and who may, in modern times, be assigned female at birth.

An attack at an educational institution, such as a primary school, secondary school, or university, involving the use of firearms. Many school shootings are also categorized as mass shootings due to multiple casualities.
A variation in chromosome structure or number.
A Cherokee person who is part of a certain non-binary cultural gender role in those communities and who may, in modern times, be assigned male at birth.
The systematic forced removal of ethnic, racial and/or religious groups from a given territory by a more powerful ethnic group, often with the intent of making it ethnically homogeneous.
Variation in chromosome structure including microscopic and submicroscopic types of variation such as deletions, duplications, copy-number variants, insertions, inversions and translocations.

One of the Indigenous peoples of the Southeastern Woodlands of the United States. Prior to the 18th century, they were concentrated in what is now southwestern North Carolina, southeastern Tennessee, edges of western South Carolina, northeastern Georgia and northeastern Alabama.
Mortality from all causes in a given time interval, for a given population.
A variation of a single nucleotide at a specific location of the genome due to base substitution, which is found at any frequency in the population.
Television episodes pertaining especially to LGBTQIA+ persons and/or culture.
An excessive reaction to stress caused by one's environment that may be characterized by feelings of emotional and physical exhaustion, coupled with a sense of frustration and failure.
A television episode about or otherwise related to a particular subculture or subcultures.

Education about the human immunodeficiency viruses and the diseases they cause, primarily AIDS. Comprehensive HIV/AIDS education focuses on both the sexual and non-sexual components of HIV-associated diseases.
A single installment of a television series.
A sex education program within a school, university, or community center that addresses prominent sexual health topics among LGBTQIA+ groups.

A form of sex education that teaches not having sex outside of marriage. It often excludes other types of sexual and reproductive health education, such as birth control and safe sex. Comprehensive sex education, by contrast, covers the use of birth control and sexual abstinence.
Romantic attraction to persons of a different gender/sex.
Romantic attraction to persons of a different gender/sex.
Television episodes pertaining especially to intersex persons and/or culture.
Decreased condom usage in response to weariness of and decreased effectiveness of safer sex messages.
Television episodes pertaining especially to bisexual persons and/or culture.
Emotional distress caused by repeated or prolonged expression of compassion or empathy. It may occur in individuals working in care giving professions.
Television episodes pertaining especially to asexual persons and/or culture.

Adverse psychological and behavioral reactions caused by the pressures and demands of employers or clients or other factors, such as the physical environment of the workplace, workplace violence. or workplace bullying.
Romantic attraction to persons of the same gender/sex.
Romantic attraction to persons of the same gender/sex.
Television episodes pertaining especially to lesbians and/or lesbian culture.

An excessive stress reaction to one's occupational or professional environment. It may be characterized by feelings of emotional and physical exhaustion, coupled with a sense of frustration and failure.
A place where people engage in sexual activity with sex workers.

A television episode in which a seemingly heterosexual character engages in a kiss with a possibly lesbian or bisexual character. In most instances, the potential of a relationship between the women does not survive past the episode and the lesbian (or suspected lesbian) never appears again.
A person's gender as represented or recognized in any of various legal systems.
A person's gender as represented or recognized in any of various legal systems.
Television episodes pertaining especially to transgender persons and/or transgender culture.
A malformation of the uterus in which the uterus is present as a paired organ as a result of the failure of fusion of the mullerian ducts during embryogenesis.
A minority group whose minority status is not immediately obvious. or a minority group which is not visible (for example. "passing" of gay men as heterosexual).
Television episodes pertaining especially to gay men and/or gay male culture.

A phenomenon wherein individuals or societies who had been concerned about the impact of HIV or AIDS become desensitized to having a strong emotional response to HIV issues after receiving continual messages about the danger over a long period of time.

A substance, usually organic, introduced to reduce friction between surfaces in mutual contact, which ultimately reduces the heat generated when the surfaces move. It may also have the function of transmitting forces, transporting foreign particles, or heating or cooling the surfaces.

Lubricants used to reduce vaginal dryness and pain during intercourse, and by couples trying to conceive. During fertility interventions, the use of a lubricant eases sperm specimen collection by masturbation. Commonly used lubricants include saliva, oil (such as baby oil, olive oil, canola oil, or mineral oil) or commercially available lubricants that are either water-based or hydroxyethylcellulose-based.
Any of various methods of removing facial and/or body hair.

Specialized lubricants used during human sexual acts such as intercourse and masturbation to reduce friction to or between the penis and vagina, anus or other body parts or applied to sex toys to reduce friction or to ease penetration.

A unicornuate uterus represents a uterine malformation where the uterus is formed from one only of the paired Müllerian ducts while the other Müllerian duct does not develop or only in a rudimentary fashion.
A malformation of the uterus in which the uterine cavity is partitioned by a longitudinal septum while the outside of the uterus has a normal typical shape.

A naturally produced fluid that lubricates a person's vagina. Vaginal lubrication is always present, but production increases significantly near ovulation and during sexual arousal in anticipation of sexual intercourse.
The process of hair removal by means of exposure to pulses of laser light that destroy the hair follicle.
A mixture of liquid, cells, and bacteria that lubricate and protect the vagina.

Normal or abnormal secretions from the vagina. Mucus produced by the cervical glands is discharged from the vagina naturally. Causes of abnormal vaginal discharge include infectious agents (e.g., Neisseria gonorrhea, Chlamydia trachomatis, Trichomonas, and Candida albicans), the presence of foreign bodies, and cervical or vaginal cancer.
The removal of hair, by using a razor or any other kind of bladed implement, to slice it down—to the level of the skin or otherwise.
An emission produced by the vagina.
Temporary hair removal to the level of skin, lasting anywhere from several hours to several days.

Lubricants that are safe for anal sex, especially products that are specifically marketed or designed to enhance enjoyment of anal sex. Often, they are simply a thicker gel rather than a liquid. This thicker consistency is preferable because it helps the lubricant stay in place. Some anal lubricants contain numbing agents to relieve discomfort during anal sex, although it is generally inadvisable as a lack of sensation makes accidental injury more likely.
Removal of hair from the root, which lasts from several days to permanent removal.

An emission or expulsion of air from the vagina. It may occur during or after sexual intercourse or during other sexual acts, stretching or exercise. The sound is somewhat comparable to flatulence from the anus but does not involve waste gases and thus often does not have a specific odor associated.
The secretion of the apocrine glands of the clitoris, in combination with desquamating epithelial cells.
A sex education instruction method based on-curriculum that aims to give students the knowledge, attitudes, skills and values to make appropriate and healthy choices in their sexual lives.

A fluid produced from minute microscopic protrusions of the mucosal surface of the foreskin and that living cells constantly grow towards the surface, undergo fatty degeneration, separate off, and form smegma.
Method for supporting institutional and organizational change which ultimately is meant to foster gender awareness and equality.
The process of using electricity for hair removal.
Consent given by all parties.
The intentional restriction of oxygen to one's own brain for the purposes of sexual arousal.
The act of touching a part of a body in a way that causes involuntary twitching movements or laughter.
Any malformation or condition related to a cerebral malformation which is present at birth, regardless of cause.
The empire of Napoleon Bonaparte of France and the dominant power in much of continental Europe at the beginning of the 19th century.
A kiss in which there is tongue contact.

term: congenital malformation of the nervous system
comment: Malformations of any part or the entirety of the nervous system which are present at birth.
An amorous kiss in which the participants' tongues extend to touch each other's lips or tongue.
Any malformation or condition related to a heart malformation which is present at birth, regardless of cause.
A defect in the structure of the heart or great vessels that is present at birth.
The intentional restriction of oxygen to the brain for the purposes of sexual arousal.
A kiss given out of reverence or respect to another person or thing.

term: congenital malformation of the circulatory system
comment: Any malformation or condition related to a circulatory malformation which is present at birth, regardless of cause.
Accidental or purposeful deaths that occur during sexual self-stimulation when an apparatus, device or prop that is being employed to enhance pleasure causes the death.
A congenital abnormality in which the cerebrum is underdeveloped, the fontanels close prematurely, and, as a result, the head is small.

Head circumference below 2 standard deviations below the mean for age and gender. Head circumference is measured from just above the glabella (the most prominent point on the frontal bone above the root of the nose) to the most posterior prominent point of the occipital bone using a tape measure. Some standard charts are organized by centiles, others by standard deviations. It is important to add an indication of how far below the normal standard the head circumference is if an accurate assessment of this can be made. Microcephaly is an absolute term. The term relative microcephaly can be used when the head size centile is less than the centile for height, for example, head size at the 3rd centile with height at the 75% for age and sex. On prenatal ultrasound, microcephaly is diagnosed if the head circumference or the biparietal diameter is more than three standard deviations below the mean.
Erotic asphyxiation. a sexual practice involving the intentional deprivation of oxygen to the brain by choking, hanging, or other means.

Gesturing is a form of nonverbal communication in which visible bodily actions communicate particular messages, either in place of speech or together and in parallel with spoken words. Gestures include movement of the hands, face, or other parts of the body.
An abnormal accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid within the ventricles of the brain that is present at birth.
Hydrocephalus that is present at birth.
Death is the permanent cessation of all biological functions that sustain a living, physical organism.
A kiss used as a salutation between friends or acquaintances.

term: congenital malformation of the neural tube
comment: Congenital malformations of the central nervous system and adjacent structures related to defective neural tube closure during the first trimester of pregnancy generally occurring between days 18-29 of gestation. Ectodermal and mesodermal malformations (mainly involving the skull and vertebrae) may occur as a result of defects of neural tube closure.
Death due to erotic and/or sexual means or mechanisms.

A malformation of the nervous system caused by failure of the anterior neuropore to close. Infants are born with intact spinal cords, cerebellums, and brainstems, but lack formation of neural structures above this level. The skull is only partially formed but the eyes are usually normal. This condition may be associated with folate deficiency. Affected infants are only capable of primitive (brain stem) reflexes and usually do not survive for more than two weeks.
A rare neural tube defect during pregnancy, resulting in the absence of a large portion of the brain and skull in the fetus.

A congenital nervous system abnormality characterized by failure of the anterior neuropore to close resulting in partial or complete absence of the cranial vault accompanied by absence of overlying tissues, including the brain and cerebral hemispheres, skull and scalp.
A young person who is nonbinary.
Erotic asphyxiation. a fetish involving asphyxia at the moment of orgasm.
A day dedicated to bringing awareness to a certain civil cause and/or condition.
Implants which form part of the genitourinary system.
A month dedicated to bringing awareness to a certain cause and/or condition.
A congenital neural tube defect in which vertebrae are not fully formed. It results in the protrusion of the spinal cord through the opening of the vertebrae.
Incomplete closure of the embryonic neural tube, whereby some vertebral arches remain unfused and open. The mildest form is spina bifida occulta, followed by meningocele and meningomyelocele.
A kiss in which a person's lips contact another person's nose.

A variant of "yes means yes" consent is enthusiastic consent. Project Respect states that "positive sexuality" needs to start with enthusiastic consent" in which a person is as "excited and into someone else’s enjoyment" a they are, an engaged partner. Planned Parenthood says that enthusiastic consent can be seen when a partner is "...happy, excited, or energized".
A kiss in which a person's lips contact another person's cheek.

A venue where strip dancers provide the primary source of entertainment, predominantly in the form of striptease or other erotic dances. Strip clubs typically adopt a nightclub or bar style, and can also adopt a theatre or cabaret-style.
Different types of kisses organized by the anatomical structure received by the lips (i.e. lip-to-lip kissing, lip-to-hand kissing, etc.
Sex work done by migrant workers.
A hug involving more than two persons.

An institutional policy of granting authority to health personnel to perform procedures on patients or to remove organs from cadavers for transplantation unless an objection is registered by family members or by the patient prior to death. This also includes emergency care of minors without prior parental consent.
An act, usually of endearment, in which two or more people put their arms around the neck, back, or waist of one another and hold each other closely.
A kiss in which a person's lips contact another person's hand or hands.

Consent which is not expressly granted by a person, but rather implicitly granted by a person's actions and the facts and circumstances of a particular situation (or in some cases, by a person's silence or inaction). The term is most commonly encountered in the context of United States drunk driving laws. There are no U.S. states that allow implied consent as an excuse for rape in a court of law.
A kiss in which a person's lips contact another person's lips.
Consent expressed specifically, either verbally or in the form of writing.
A kiss indicating peace or transmitting a feeling of peace as part of a ritual.
A kiss which is part of some ritual, religious or otherwise.
Consent which allows a decision maker to attempt to establish the decision an incompetent person would have made if they were competent.
A kiss in which a person's lips contact another person's forehead.
Sexual consent in which all parties agree to sexual conduct, either through clear, verbal communication or nonverbal cues or gestures.
A theoretical erogenous zone of the vagina located in the posterior fornix.
Any of various legal cases which reach the federal level or federal courts in government.
Sexual arousal from vomiting, or from watching others vomit.

A theoretical erogenous zone of the vagina that when stimulated can lead to rapid vaginal lubrication and arousal, sometimes without any other form of stimulation, with continued stimulation resulting in an intense orgasm.
A legal case in which a person is tried as a criminal or which otherwise involves some aspect or aspects of criminal law.
A lawsuit or legal case involving some aspect of civil law or civil law procedure.
Practice or practices of sexual masochism which is considered compulsive in nature.

A vibrating and rotating sex toy, usually made in the shape of a phallus with a clitoral stimulator attached to the shaft. However, the rabbit vibrator has evolved to reach a wider market, with many new introductions that do not take a phallic shape. The name of the device is derived from the fact that the clitoral stimulator looks like a pair of rabbit ears.
Court cases heard at the Tax Court of the United States.
Practice or practices of sexual masochism which is considered symptomatic of some other condition.
A theoretical phenomena defined as a longer and more intense version of a classical orgasm with its own unique characteristics.
Court cases heard at the Supreme Court of the United States.
Consensual psychological humiliation performed in order to produce erotic excitement or sexual arousal.
A physiological response to sexual stimulation.

term: federal case in the United States

When Spaniards entered the area beginning in the 16th century, they came across complex, multi-story villages built of adobe, stone and other local materials, which they called pueblos, or villages, a term that later came to refer also to the peoples who live in these villages.

An Anishinaabe people of Canada and the northern Midwestern United States. They are one of the most numerous Indigenous peoples north of the Rio Grande. In Canada, they are the second-largest First Nations population, surpassed only by the Cree. In the United States, they have the fifth-largest population among Native American peoples, surpassed in number only by the Navajo, Cherokee, Choctaw and Sioux.
A business serving mostly gay men whose primary function is the serving of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises.

An Indigenous American ethnic group who primarily inhabit land in the Eastern Woodlands region, commonly known as the northern United States and southern Canada. They have long had territory that crosses the current border between the two countries, and they are federally recognized as Native American tribes in the United States and have numerous recognized First Nations bands in Canada. They are one of the Anishinaabeg, related to but distinct from the Ojibwe and Potawatomi peoples.

Any of the various Indigenous peoples of the Aleutian Islands. Both the Aleut people and the islands are divided between the United States state of Alaska and the Russian administrative division of Kamchatka Krai.

A Native American pueblo approximately 60 miles (97 km) west of Albuquerque, New Mexico in the United States. Four communities make up the village of Acoma Pueblo: Sky City (Old Acoma), Acomita, Anzac, and McCartys. The Acoma Pueblo tribe is a federally recognized tribal entity.
A business serving mostly lesbians whose primary function is the serving of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises.

A class of people in the middle of a social hierarchy. However, it is oversimplification to consider this term as an easily identifiable category that falls between "x" and "y" on one specific, agreed-upon continuum with established criteria. The definition of the term "middle class" is highly political and vigorously contested by various schools of political and economic philosophy.

A subdivision of the greater middle class. Usually the term refers to the group of middle class households or individuals who have not attained the status of the upper middle class associated with the higher realms of the middle class.
