The social group constituted by higher status members of the middle class. This is in contrast to the term lower middle class, which is used for the group at the opposite end of the middle-class stratum, and to the broader term middle class. There is considerable debate as to how the upper middle class might be defined.

Infection of the brain or spinal cord by Treponema pallidum. It occurs many years following the original infection which remained untreated. Signs and symptoms include abnormal gait, blindness, depression, paralysis, seizures and dementia.

The behavior of performing an act persistently and repetitively without it leading to reward or pleasure. The act is usually a small, circumscribed behavior, almost ritualistic, yet not pathologically disturbing. Examples of compulsive behavior include twirling of hair, checking something constantly, not wanting pennies in change, straightening tilted pictures, etc.

Since 1817, the Principality was ruled by the Obrenović dynasty (replaced by the Karađorđević dynasty for a short time). The Principality, under the suzerainty of the Ottoman Empire, de facto achieved full independence when the last Ottoman troops left Belgrade in 1867. The Congress of Berlin in 1878 recognized the formal independence of the Principality of Serbia, and in its composition Nišava, Pirot, Toplica and Vranje districts entered the South part of Serbia.

A provisional state established during World War II on 29 November 1943 through the Second Session of the Anti-Fascist Council for the National Liberation of Yugoslavia (AVNOJ). The National Committee for the Liberation of Yugoslavia (NKOJ) was its original executive body. Throughout its existence it was governed by Marshal Josip Broz Tito as prime minister.

The republican government of France from 27 October 1946 to 4 October 1958, governed by the fourth republican constitution. It was in many ways a revival of the Third Republic that was in place from 1870 during the Franco-Prussian War to 1940 during World War II, and suffered many of the same problems. France adopted the constitution of the Fourth Republic on 13 October 1946.

A country in the Balkans that existed from 1992 to 2003, following the breakup of the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia. The Federal Republic of Yugoslavia comprised the Republic of Serbia and the Republic of Montenegro.
The northern region of Bosnia and Herzegovina, encompassing roughly 81% of the country. the other region, the southern part, is Herzegovina.

The southern and smaller of two main geographical regions of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the other being Bosnia. The original name of Soviet Ukraine in 1919 was Ukrainian Socialist Soviet Republic, but after the ratification of the 1936 Soviet Constitution, the names of all Soviet republics were changed, transposing the second (socialist) and third (soviet or radianska in Ukrainian) words.

The original name of Soviet Ukraine in 1919 was Ukrainian Socialist Soviet Republic, but after the ratification of the 1936 Soviet Constitution, the names of all Soviet republics were changed, transposing the second (socialist) and third (soviet or radianska in Ukrainian) words. In accordance, on 5 December 1936, the 8th Extraordinary Congress Soviets in Soviet Union changed the name of the republic to the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic, which was ratified by the 14th Extraordinary Congress of Soviets in Ukrainian SSR on 31 January 1937.

One of the constituent republics of the Soviet Union from the Union's inception in 1922 until its breakup in 1991. In the anthem of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic, the republic was referred to simply as Ukraine. The republic was governed by the Communist Party of the Soviet Union through its republican branch, the Communist Party of Ukraine, as a union republic of the Soviet Union, which existed as a highly centralized one-party state.

The effect or sway that a peer group exerts on the beliefs, value systems and behavior of each member of a group. The social expectations for individuals to conform to peer group influence is known as peer pressure.
An actor who is transgender.
An actor who is a gay man.
Entertainers who are LGBTQIA+.
Phrases that are euphemisms in certain contexts can be considered dysphemistic in others
An orgasm which is impeded or which has a low occurrence considered unhealthy or otherwise nonnormative.
Technique or procedure for manipulation of cells and analysis of cell properties and subcellular features.
A condition in which orgasm is painful.
A postmortem examination of the body that includes an examination of the internal organs and structures after dissection to determine the cause of death and the nature of pathological changes.
An actor who is a lesbian.
The use of a derogatory, offensive or vulgar word or phrase to replace a (more) neutral original.
A condition in which orgasm takes a prolonged period of time typically considered unnormal or unhealthy.
Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting.
Students who are LGBTQIA+.
Dysphemistic terms which hold different meanings in different cultures.
An orgasm which occurs during coitus.

One of the main characteristics of cultural globalization, referring to the reduction in cultural diversity through the popularization and diffusion of a wide array of cultural symbols—not only physical objects but customs, ideas and values.
A student who is a lesbian.
Use of any of various contraceptive methods.

A consensual BDSM sexual play whereby a person consents to be forced to orgasm despite their attempts to delay or not to orgasm. The person who is to be brought to involuntary orgasm would typically be put in physical restraints to increase the feeling of helplessness, and deprive them of the ability to control the onset and intensity of orgasm.

A form of defense known as an excuse so that defendants falling within the definition of an "infant" are excluded from criminal liability for their actions, if at the relevant time, they had not reached an age of criminal responsibility. After reaching the initial age, there may be levels of responsibility dictated by age and the type of offense committed.

A criminal law defense in which the defendant argues that a prior history of abuse justifies violent retaliation. While the term most often refers to instances of child abuse or sexual assault, it also refers more generally to any attempt by the defense to use a syndrome or societal condition to deflect responsibility away from the defendant.
Having a feminine gender (identity) which is different from the sex one was assigned at birth.
Having a feminine gender (identity) which is different from the sex one was assigned at birth.
Having a feminine gender (identity) which is different from the sex one was assigned at birth.
Orgasm originating from the stimulation of the uterus.

A biospecimen collection and staining procedure in which secretions and superficial cells of the cervix are collected and stained with the Papanicolaou stain followed by microscopic examination to identify the presence of abnormal cells.
Having a masculine gender (identity) which is different from the sex one was assigned at birth.
Having a masculine gender (identity) which is different from the sex one was assigned at birth.
Having a masculine gender (identity) which is different from the sex one was assigned at birth.
An orgasm which occurs as part of a genital reflex and is not under conscious control.
Procedures for the collection and/or preparation of biological specimens for light microscopy examination.
Historians who are LGBTQIA+.
Models who are LGBTQIA+.
The status of being clothed or unclothed.
Nurses who are LGBTQIA+.
The state of being clothed or in clothing.
When a person mimes or otherwise pretends to have had orgasm without having actually experienced one.
Significant phonetic features produced by many LGBTQIA+ persons.
A gay man who is a student at a secondary school.
A bisexual person who is a student at a secondary school.
A transgender person who is a student at a secondary school.
LGBTQIA+ persons who are authors.
Orgasm originating from the stimulation of the prostate.
Orgasm originating from the stimulation of the penis.
Significant phonetic features produced by many transgender people.
The phase of the human sexual response cycle which occurs after orgasm and allows the muscles to relax, blood pressure to drop and the body to slow down from its excited state.
Significant phonetic features produced by many lesbians.
LGBTQIA+ persons who are students at a secondary school.

The period of sexual excitement prior to orgasm. The phase is characterised by an increased circulation and heart rate in both sexes, increased sexual pleasure with increased stimulation and further increased muscle tension. Also, respiration continues at an elevated level.
Significant phonetic features produced by many gay men.
A lesbian who is a student at a secondary school.
A four-stage model of physiological responses to sexual stimulation, which, in order of their occurrence, are the excitement-, plateau-, orgasmic-, and resolution phases.
The direct influence on people by any social group.
Any of various models of physiological responses to sexual stimulation which take the form of a cycle.
The relative highness of lowness of speech as perceived by the listener.
Individual phases of the sexual response cycle.
Involuntary and repetitive utterances of obscene or socially inappropriate words or statements.
Orgasm originating from the stimulation of the clitoris.
Involuntary ("parrot-like"), meaningless repetition of a recently heard word, phrase, or song. This condition may be associated with transcortical aphasia. schizophrenia. or other disorders.
A symptom of neurologic or psychiatric dysfunction in which the individual involuntarily and meaninglessly repeats a recently heard word, series of words, or a song.
A lesbian who is an author.
Cartoonists who are LGBTQIA+.
An orgasm with an intensity or high occurrence considered unhealthy or otherwise nonnormative.
A lesbian who is a cartoonist.
Any sort of orgasm or orgasmic process considered unhealthy or otherwise nonnormative.

The direct influence on people by peers, or the effect on an individual who gets encouraged to follow their peers by changing their attitudes, values or behaviors to conform to those of the influencing group or individual.

Comprises a set of group dynamics whereby a group in which one feels comfortable may override personal habits, individual moral inhibitions or idiosyncratic desires to impose a group norm of attitudes and/or behaviors.
An athlete who is a lesbian.
A socially considered nude state in which some intimate parts, but not all, are exposed. For example, in American culture when a woman's breasts are exposed but not her genitalia.
The age at which one's voice drops, usually coinciding with the processes of puberty.

A version of the abuse defense in which an individual experiencing the daily life of racial segregation and violence common in many inner cities in the United States causes a subjective state equivalent to that caused by survival in a violent battleground of war. As such it leads to a condition similar to a syndrome already recognized in both psychological and psychiatric practices, that is, post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).
The state in which a woman's breasts, including her areola and nipples, are exposed, especially in a public place or in a visual medium.
The physical or psychological fear of sexual relations or sexual intercourse.
A defense which is not a defense in and of itself, but instead includes a combination of other defenses: self-defense, provocation, insanity, and diminished responsibility.
A clinical condition resulting from repeated physical and psychological injuries inflicted on a child by the parents or caregivers.
A clinical condition resulting from repeated physical and psychological injuries inflicted on person by their partner.
Occurrence of the first menstrual period before the usual or expected age.

term: in vitro fertilization with intracytoplasmic sperm injection and donor egg
comment: An assisted fertilization technique consisting of the microinjection of a single viable sperm into an extracted ovum. It is used principally to overcome low sperm count, low sperm motility, inability of sperm to penetrate the egg, or other conditions related to infertility in persons with sperm.
A quality that causes sexual feelings, as well as a philosophical contemplation concerning the aesthetics of sexual desire, sensuality, and romantic love.

The earliest gonadal changes of puberty, when (in response to pituitary gonadotropins), the ovaries and the testes begin to grow and increase the production of the sex steroids, especially estradiol and testosterone.
In vitro fertilization technique that uses mitochondrial DNA from a healthy donor in order to prevent the transmission of mitochondrial disease.

The replacement of mitochondria in one or more cells to prevent or ameliorate disease. MRT originated as a special form of in vitro fertilisation in which some or all of the future baby's mitochondrial DNA comes from a third party. This technique is used in cases when mothers carry genes for mitochondrial diseases. The therapy is approved for use in the United Kingdom. A second application is to use autologous mitochondria to replace mitochondria in damaged tissue to restore the tissue to a functional state. This has been used in clinical research in the United States to treat cardiac-compromised newborns.
The state of a man wearing no clothes above the waist, exposing the upper torso.
A human life stage that begins at birth and continues until twelve complete months of age.
An assisted reproductive technique that includes the direct handling and manipulation of oocytes and sperm to achieve fertilization in vitro.
A human life stage that begins at twelve years of age and continues until twenty-one complete years of age, generally marked by the beginning of puberty and lasting to the beginning of adulthood.
Artificial introduction of semen or spermatozoa into the vagina to facilitate fertilization.
Sexual intercourse as it takes place between two men.
Sexual intercourse as it takes place between two women.
The onset of growth of pubic hair at an earlier age than normal.

Sexual attraction between members of the same sex, either male–male or female–female. The concept differs from the concept of homosexuality: it refers specifically to the desire itself, which can be temporary, whereas "homosexuality" implies a more permanent state of identity or sexual orientation.
The first appearance of pubic hair in a child.
The medical donation of gametes.
Autoeroticism is the practice of becoming sexually stimulated through internal stimuli.
Occurrence of the first menstrual period before the lower limit of the normal age range for the reference population, without other signs of puberty.
A donation of some biological substance in order to satisfy some medical need.
A criminal defense occasionally used when a defendant is accused of a criminal attempt that failed only because the crime was factually or legally impossible to commit.
The state of being nude.
An orgasm that occurs during childbirth.
A defense by which a defendant may claim diminished responsibility on the basis of substance intoxication.

A rarely used criminal defense. It is one of the mental condition defenses that relate to the mental state of the defendant. Automatism can be seen variously as lack of voluntariness, lack of culpability (unconsciousness) or excuse (Schopp). Automatism means that the defendant was not aware of his or her actions when making the particular movements that constituted the illegal act.
Nudity in places or situations considered private in nature.
Self-aware sexism that is deemed acceptable given that its perpetrators are conscious of the inherent sexism and objectification of women in whatever action or statement is being carried out by them.
A defense which notes that a person charged was coerced to act against their will.
Nudity in places or situations considered public in nature.

Benevolent sexism represents evaluations of gender that may appear subjectively positive (subjective to the person who is evaluating), but are actually damaging to people and gender equality more broadly (e.g., the ideas that women need to be protected by men).
A concept related to an excuse defense (excuse) which reduces or extinguishes a person's culpability and therefore a person's liability to pay compensation to the victim of a tort in the civil law.
Nudity as it socially applies to the female body.
Hostile sexism reflects overtly negative evaluations and stereotypes about a gender (e.g., the ideas that women are incompetent and inferior to men).
A law passed by a legislative body in a common law system to set the maximum time after an event within which legal proceedings may be initiated.
Nudity as it socially applies to the male body.
A theoretical framework which posits that sexism has two sub-components: "hostile sexism" and "benevolent sexism".

A defense to a civil lawsuit or criminal charge is a fact or set of facts other than those alleged by the plaintiff or prosecutor which, if proven by the defendant, defeats or mitigates the legal consequences of the defendant's otherwise unlawful conduct.
Nudity in places or situations considered social in nature.
Female nudity in which one or more women are nude while one or more men are clothed.
A scale which assesses sexism in some capacity.
A physical and psychological condition of a person who has suffered (usually persistent) emotional, physical, or sexual abuse from another person.
Nudity practiced by an individual in personally private places or situations.
A scale which assesses prejudice against persons based on gender.

In law, provocation is when a person is considered to have committed a criminal act partly because of a preceding set of events that might cause a reasonable person to lose self control. This makes them less morally culpable than if the act was premeditated (pre-planned) and done out of pure malice (malice aforethought).
Nudity in sexual places or situations.
The assumption that gender differences perceived in character and behavior are caused by biological differences in brains.

A mistake of fact may sometimes mean that, while a person has committed the physical element of an offence, because they were labouring under a mistake of fact, they never formed the required mens rea, and so will escape liability for offences that require mens rea.
Male nudity in which one or more men are nude while one or more women are clothed.
A Native American people of the Great Plains, upper Mississippi River, and western Great Lakes region. They traditionally speak the Potawatomi language, a member of the Algonquian family.

One of the major divisions of the Saulteaux, found primarily in eastern and southern Manitoba, extending west into southern Saskatchewan. During the late 18th century and early 19th century, as partners with the Cree in the fur trade, the Saulteaux migrated northwest into the Swan River and Cumberland districts of west-central Manitoba, and into Saskatchewan along the Assiniboine River, as far its confluence with the Souris (Mouse) River. Once established in the area, the Saulteaux adapted some of the cultural traits of their allies, the Plains Cree and Assiniboine.

A First Nations band government in Ontario, Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Alberta and British Columbia, Canada. They are a branch of the Ojibwe when they pushed west forming into a mixed culture of woodlands and plains Indigenous customs and traditions.
A non-profit organization which exists for the promotion of social welfare.
Drag which derives from the Neo-Burlesque tradition or is otherwise related to it.
A trait or feature one uses in order to attempt to identify a person's gender or sex.
Sexual intercourse involving more than two participants.
A verbal or non-verbal hint or series of stimuli which guide social interactions.
A signal for an action, a pattern of stimuli indicating a particular response.
Organizations that use various forms of advocacy in order to influence public opinion and ultimately policy.
Transfer of preovulatory oocytes from donor to a suitable host. Oocytes are collected, fertilized in vitro, and transferred to a host that can be human or animal.
Erotic qualities organized by associated anatomical location.
The circumstance or condition that results in the death of a living being.
Factors which produce cessation of all vital bodily functions. They can be analyzed from an epidemiologic viewpoint.

The process of obtaining semen from male humans or other animals with the use of various methods, for the purposes of artificial insemination, or medical study (usually in fertility clinics). Semen can be collected via masturbation (e. g., from stallions and canids), prostate massage, artificial vagina, penile vibratory stimulation (vibroejaculation) and electroejaculation.
Eroticism primarily deriving from the anus.
The first sperm ejaculation.
Procedures for collecting specimens.
The age at which the first instance of sexual intercourse occurred.

The process by which a cell or cells are kept alive outside of the organism from which it was derived (i.e., kept from decay by means of a chemical agent, cooling, or a fluid substitute that mimics the natural state within the organism).
Sexual intercourse as it takes place between a man and a woman.
Occurrence of first sexual intercourse.
The donation of a person's sperm, typically for usage in assisted reproductive techniques.

A Native American tribe and First Nations band government in North America. They compose two of the three main subcultures of the Sioux people, and are typically divided into the Eastern Dakota and the Western Dakota.

A procedure in which spermatozoa are extracted from a person after they have been pronounced legally brain dead. There has been significant debate over the ethicality and legality of the procedure, and on the legal rights of the child and surviving parent if the gametes are used for impregnation.
A Native American tribe. Also known as the Teton Sioux. They are one of the three Sioux tribes of Plains. Their current lands are in North and South Dakota.

The surgical procedure of removing a small portion of tissue from the testicle and extracting any viable sperm cells from that tissue for use in further procedures, most commonly intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) as part of in vitro fertilisation (IVF).
Eroticism primarily deriving from the mouth.
The killing of one person by another.
Usage of any of various surgical techniques to collect semen.
The act of killing oneself.
A penile condom used for the purposes of sperm collection. Collection condoms are made from silicone or polyurethane, as latex is somewhat harmful to sperm.

The autonym for a group of culturally related Indigenous peoples in what are now Canada and the United States. These include the Odawa, Saulteaux, Ojibwe (including Mississaugas), Potawatomi, Oji-Cree, and Algonquin peoples. The Anishinaabe speak Anishinaabemowin, or Anishinaabe languages that belong to the Algonquian language family. They historically lived in the Northeast Woodlands and Subarctic.

A First Nations/Native American people originally from the Northern Great Plains of North America. Today, they are centered in present-day Saskatchewan. They have also populated parts of Alberta and southwestern Manitoba in Canada, and northern Montana and western North Dakota in the United States.
A means of inducing ejaculation through vibration.
The sexual partner who is penetrated by the penetrative partner.
A medical institution of secondary education, higher learning, research, or honorary membership.
The sexual partner who engages in penetrative sexual behavior.
Professional associations formed of and for pediatricians.
Hate groups who direct their hatred primarily against gay people, particularly gay men.

Any of various methods of care or attention given to a sexual partner or partners after a BDSM-related experience. Aftercare is usually negotiated before entering into the experience, often referred to as a scene.
Hate groups who direct their hatred primarily against LGBTQIA+ people.
A person who performs in drag.

A hate group is a social group that advocates and practices hatred, hostility, or violence towards members of a race, ethnicity, nation, religion, gender, gender identity, sexual orientation or any other designated sector of society.
A pediatric medical institution of secondary education, higher learning, research, or honorary membership.
Hate groups who direct their hatred primarily against transgender people.
Hate groups who direct their hatred primarily against bisexual people.
Hate groups who direct their hatred primarily against lesbians.
An organization which publishes or reviews some form of media, typically newsmedia.
A group which advocates for LGBTQIA+ persons.
Organizations which monitor media for particular attributes or overly suitability for a general audience or for specific audiences.
Organizations which analyze media in some capacity, such as for fact checking.
Sexual partners organized by their role and/or roles during sexual activities.
Partners organized primarily by sexual orientation and/or sexuality or by the sexuality of their partner(s). Note that this includes asexual persons.

term: man who has sex with men and women
comment: Male persons who engage in sexual activity with men and women, regardless of how they identify themselves.
Teleiophilic attraction to both men and women.
Any of various abnormal behaviors observed in animals.
A medical symptom primarily covered under the realm of psychiatry.
Behavior that is considered out of the ordinary, uncommon, or unexpected from a person or nonhuman animal given their previous patterns of behavior.
Note that abnormal behavior is usually a sign or symptom indicative of one of many psychiatric disorders, making it ostensibly different than behavior deemed unusual.
Persistent deficits in social interaction and communication and interaction as well as a markedly restricted repertoire of activity and interest as well as repetitive patterns of behavior.

The observable, measurable, and often pathological activity of an organism that portrays its inability to overcome a habit resulting in an insatiable craving for a substance or for performing certain acts. The addictive behavior includes the emotional and physical overdependence on the object of habit in increasing amount or frequency.
An intersex person who is a medical patient.

An individual’s true gender, as opposed to their gender assigned at birth. This term should replace terms like new gender or chosen gender, which imply that an individual’s gender was chosen. However, it is more preferable to simply use "gender".
A person who identifies and is affirmed as female.
The process through which individuals are affirmed in their gender identity through social interactions.
The process through which individuals are affirmed in their gender identity through social interactions.
A person who identifies and is affirmed as male.

The gender which one is assumed to be based on assigned gender at birth. Alternatively, the assumption of a person's gender based on any predefined characteristics and biases. Assumption of someone's gender can be considered transphobic, depending on the circumstance, so asking may be appropriate, or introducing oneself with their own pronouns/gender identification first.
A limitation on a person's physical functioning, mobility, dexterity or stamina.
A limitation on a person's mental functioning or intellectual capacity.
The love of women. a sexual attraction to women, in general. female-oriented teleiophilia.
Voice as utilizing by transmasculine persons, typically in order to pass or be socially accepted as their identified masculine gender.
Voice as utilizing by transfeminine persons, typically in order to pass or be socially accepted as their identified feminine gender.

Persons, usually in the United States, who identify as Latino. broadly, all Latin American men. In this context, persons from countries and dependencies in the Western Hemisphere where Romance languages such as Spanish, Portuguese, and French are predominantly spoken. it is broader than the terms Iberian or Hispanic.

Persons, usually in the United States, who identify as Latina. broadly, all Latin American women. In this context, persons from countries and dependencies in the Western Hemisphere where Romance languages such as Spanish, Portuguese, and French are predominantly spoken. it is broader than the terms Iberian or Hispanic.
A person who has any of various addictions.
A Black person who is female.
A person who has an addiction to alcohol.

A classification ised in educational settings that allows educational institutions to provide special education and related services to students who have displayed poor social and/or academic progress. any of various disorders considered as falling under this classification.
A transgender person who is allosexual.
A person who has an addiction to cocaine.
Any of various diseases affecting the genitourinary system.
A transgender person who is gay.
Any of various disorders with primary symptoms affecting emotional state or status.
A transgender person who is asexual.

Refers to a person's state of physical, mental and social well-being. usually it refers specifically to the state of being in good health, a state of complete physical, mental and social well-being, and does not consist only of the absence of disease or infirmity. In any organism health constitutes a form of homeostasis with inputs and outputs of energy and mass in approximate equilibrium allowing for growth and continued survival. In humans, a subjective feeling of well-being coming from somatic and cognitive perceptions is considered an essential component of health.

A chromosomal dysgenesis syndrome resulting from a triplication or translocation of chromosome 21. Down syndrome occurs in approximately 1:700 live births. Abnormalities are variable from individual to individual and may include slowed mental development, slowed growth, flat hypoplastic face with short nose, prominent epicanthic skin folds, small low-set ears with prominent antihelix, fissured and thickened tongue, laxness of joint ligaments, pelvic dysplasia, broad hands and feet, stubby fingers, transverse palmar crease, lenticular opacities and heart disease. Patients with Down syndrome have an estimated 10 to 30-fold increased risk for leukemia. most have symptoms of Alzheimer's disease by age 40. Also known as trisomy 21 syndrome.
The concept covering the physical and mental health conditions experienced by members of gender minorities, usually related to social disadvantages or discriminatory acts.
The concept covering the physical and mental health conditions experienced by members of gender and sexual minorities, usually related to social disadvantages or discriminatory acts.
The concept covering the physical and mental health conditions experienced by transgender people, usually related to social disadvantages or discriminatory acts.
The concept covering the physical and mental health conditions experienced by members of sexual minorities, usually related to social disadvantages or discriminatory acts.
Voice which is socially read as belonging to an individual of a constructed gender role.
Sound produced by vibration of the vocal cords during an expiration of air.

A state which existed from 1861—when King Victor Emmanuel II of Sardinia was proclaimed King of Italy—until 1946—when civil discontent led an institutional referendum to abandon the monarchy and form the modern Italian Republic. The state was founded as a result of the unification of Italy under the influence of the Kingdom of Sardinia, which can be considered its legal predecessor state.
The regime of Napoleon III from 1852 to 1870, between the Second Republic and the Third Republic, in France.

The unofficial name given to the Kingdom of the Netherlands as it existed between 1815 and 1839. The United Netherlands was created in the aftermath of the Napoleonic Wars through the fusion of territories that had belonged to the former Dutch Republic, Austrian Netherlands, and Prince-Bishopric of Liège. The polity was a constitutional monarchy, ruled by William I of the House of Orange-Nassau.
Persons who cross-dress in order to subvert gender stereotypes or societal norms.

The system of government adopted in France from 1870, when the Second French Empire collapsed during the Franco-Prussian War, until 10 July 1940 after France's defeat by Nazi Germany in World War II led to the formation of the Vichy government in France.
A medical sign primarily affecting the respiratory system.
A decrease in the amount of oxygen in the body. Symptoms range from mild (impaired judgment, memory loss, impaired motor coordination) to severe (seizures and coma).
Relatively complete absence of oxygen in one or more tissues.

A non-neoplastic or neoplastic disorder that affects the respiratory system. Representative examples include pneumonia, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, pulmonary failure, lung adenoma, lung carcinoma, and tracheal carcinoma.
A medical symptom primarily affecting the respiratory system.
A pathological condition caused by lack of oxygen, manifested in impending or actual cessation of life.
A state of general hypoxia and hypercapnea, resulting in acidosis, which affects all tissues in the body.
Voice which is socially read as belonging to an individual of a constructed female gender role.
Voice as utilizing by transgender persons, typically in order to pass or be socially accepted as their identified gender.
Voice which is socially read as belonging to an individual of a constructed male gender role.
Infection where the agent is a lentivirus.
Low libido considered unhealthy or otherwise nonnormative.
Infection where the agent is a retrovirus.
High libido considered unhealthy or otherwise nonnormative.
A syndrome with primarily psychiatric signs and/or symptoms.
Less frequent libido considered unhealthy or otherwise nonnormative.

Infection where HIV is the agent. includes the spectrum of human immunodeficiency virus infections that range from asymptomatic seropositivity, thru AIDS-related complex (ARC), to acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS).
More frequent libido considered unhealthy or otherwise nonnormative.
Syndromes primarily affecting the immunological system.
Any of various syndromes primarily affecting the immunological system of the body.
A syndrome in which the underlying genetic cause is known.

A form of gender nonconformity in which one has a name which is traditionally not associated with their gender. alternatively, a person who does not conform to traditional norms in relationship to their name or names (such as having a mononymous name in a society where most people have a first and last name).
A type of polygamous quadratic relationship which involves two triadic relationships: one in which persons A, B, and C are dating, and a second in which persons B, C, and D are dating.

A person who is gender nonconforming in the sense in which they have a name which is traditionally not associated with their gender. alternatively, a person who does not conform to traditional norms in relationship to their name or names (such as having a mononymous name in a society where most people have a first and last name).
A person who is gender nonconforming in the sense that one uses neopronouns or pronouns in a non-standard manner.
Syndromes in which there is a deficiency or defect in the mechanisms of immunity, either cellular or humoral.
Sexual behavior considered excessive.
Loss of libido considered nonnormative or unhealthy in a sudden period or over a longer period of time as the result of already decreasing libido.
Any sexual disorder characterized by abnormal presence or absence of sexual desire.

A syndrome resulting from the acquired deficiency of cellular immunity caused by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). It is characterized by the reduction of the Helper T-lymphocytes in the peripheral blood and the lymph nodes. Symptoms include generalized lymphadenopathy, fever, weight loss, and chronic diarrhea. Patients with AIDS are especially susceptible to opportunistic infections (usually pneumocystis carinii pneumonia, cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections, tuberculosis, candida infections, and cryptococcosis), and the development of malignant neoplasms (usually non-Hodgkin&apos.s lymphoma and Kaposi&apos.s sarcoma). The human immunodeficiency virus is transmitted through sexual contact, sharing of contaminated needles, or transfusion of contaminated blood.

An acquired defect of cellular immunity associated with infection by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), a CD4-positive T-lymphocyte count under 200 cells/microliter or less than 14% of total lymphocytes, and increased susceptibility to opportunistic infections and malignant neoplasms. Clinical manifestations also include emaciation (wasting) and dementia. These elements reflect criteria for AIDS as defined by the CDC in 1993.

A syndrome resulting from the acquired deficiency of cellular immunity caused by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). It is characterized by the reduction of the Helper T-lymphocytes in the peripheral blood and the lymph nodes. Symptoms include generalized lymphadenopathy, fever, weight loss, and chronic diarrhea. Patients with AIDS are especially susceptible to opportunistic infections (usually pneumocystis carinii pneumonia, cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections, tuberculosis, candida infections, and cryptococcosis), and the development of malignant neoplasms (usually non-Hodgkin&apos.s lymphoma and Kaposi&apos.s sarcoma). The human immunodeficiency virus is transmitted through sexual contact, sharing of contaminated needles, or transfusion of contaminated blood.

An acquired defect of cellular immunity associated with infection by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), a CD4-positive T-lymphocyte count under 200 cells/microliter or less than 14% of total lymphocytes, and increased susceptibility to opportunistic infections and malignant neoplasms. Clinical manifestations also include emaciation (wasting) and dementia. These elements reflect criteria for AIDS as defined by the CDC in 1993.
Sexual behavior considered below what is expected.
Infection where the agent is the HIV-2 virus.
Any sort of sexual drive considered unhealthy or otherwise nonnormative.
Infection where the agent is the HIV-1 virus.
The tendency or instinct of animals to engage in sexual activity.
Clinical entity defined by a set of morphological abnormalities resulting from a developmental anomaly involving more than one morphogenetic field. Includes sequences and associations.
A transgender person who is bisexual.
Any of various diseases affecting the genital system.
A transgender person who is heterosexual.
A term that refers to the classification of a disorder according to the anatomic site that is involved in the pathologic process.
Surgical procedures performed on the chest wall.
A syndrome characterized by the presence of congenital abnormalities that affect more than one organ or system.
A transgender person who is pansexual.
Decreased libido considered nonnormative or unhealthy.
A non-neoplastic or neoplastic disorder that affects the genital system.
Surgery in which the chest wall is repaired.

A stage of human development following early childhood and preceding adolescence. It commonly ends with the beginning of puberty, but may also be defined as ending with the start of the teenage years. For example, the age range is commonly designated as 10–13 years.
Any sort of libido change considered unhealthy or otherwise nonnormative.
A infectious disease caused by a virus of the family Retroviridae.
Libido considered within healthy boundaries or expected boundaries as defined within a particular context.
The period of development immediately prior to the onset of puberty when changes occur that lead to sexual maturity.
Increased libido considered nonnormative or unhealthy.

Human immunodeficiency virus. A non-taxonomic and historical term referring to any of two species, specifically HIV-1 and/or HIV-2. Prior to 1986, this was called human T-lymphotropic virus type III/lymphadenopathy-associated virus (HTLV-III/LAV). From 1986-1990, it was an official species called HIV. Since 1991, HIV was no longer considered an official species name. the two species were designated HIV-1 and HIV-2.
Any sort of libido considered unhealthy or otherwise nonnormative.
A infectious disease caused by a virus of the genus Lentivirus.
The state of not having sex drive or libido.
Polygyny in which females choose a territorial male based on the male's available resources, such as territorial boundaries.
Methodist clergy who are LGBTQIA+.
LGBTQ people who are Mennonites.
LGBTQ people who are Pentecostal.
A legal gender (or gender marker) that appears on a birth certificate.
Jewish clergy who are LGBTQIA+.
A legal gender (or gender marker) that appears on a passport.
Rabbis who are LGBTQIA+.
A racialized form of Anglo-Saxon neopaganism, particularly that practiced by the England-based group Woden's Folk, which believes that Adolf Hitler was the reincarnation of the god Woden.
LGBTQ people who are adherents of Orthodox Judaism.
Any of various forms of Anglo-Saxon neopaganism with racialist beliefs, especially those that are white nationalist.
Any of various pronoun sets including voi, void, voids, and voidself.

Variations of this color are known as sky blue, baby blue, or angel blue. Within the X11 color system, with a hue code of 194, this color is closer to cyan than to blue. The first recorded use of "light blue" as a color term in English is in the year 1915.
A shade of the standard (h = 240°) blue.

The hue of that portion of the visible spectrum lying between yellow and blue, evoked in the human observer by radiant energy with wavelengths of approximately 490 to 570 nanometers. any of a group of colors that may vary in lightness and saturation and whose hue is that of the emerald or somewhat less yellow than that of growing grass.
A shade of cyan (greenish-blue color), approximating the shade of the eggs laid by the American robin. The first recorded use of robin egg blue as a color name in English was in 1873.

Any of a variety of colors with hue between red and blue. Purple is closely associated with violet. In optics, purple and violet refer to colors that look similar, but purples are mixtures of red light and blue or violet light, whereas violets are spectral colors (of single wavelengths of light). In common usage, both refer to colors that are between red and blue in hue, with purples closer to red and violets closer to blue.[5][6] Similarly, in the traditional painters' color wheel, purple and violet are both placed between red and blue, with purple closer to red.
The visually perceived property of objects created by absorption or reflection of specific wavelengths of light.
The appearance of objects (or light sources) described in terms of a person's perception of their hue and lightness (or brightness) and saturation.

A composite color. In the CMYK color model used in printing or painting, brown is made by combining red, black, and yellow, or red, yellow, and blue. In the RGB color model used to project colors onto television screens and computer monitors, brown is made by combining red and green, in specific proportions. In painting, brown is generally made by adding black to orange.
Any of a group of colors between red and yellow in hue that are medium to low in lightness and low to moderate in saturation.

The hue of that portion of the visible spectrum lying between orange and green, evoked in the human observer by radiant energy with wavelengths of approximately 570 to 590 nanometers. any of a group of colors of a hue resembling that of ripe lemons and varying in lightness and saturation.

The hue of that portion of the visible spectrum lying between red and yellow, evoked in the human observer by radiant energy with wavelengths of approximately 590 to 630 nanometers. any of a group of colors between red and yellow in hue, of medium lightness and moderate saturation.

comment: A person who has been convicted of a crime or crimes.

A weapon, typically a firearm, which is concealed from view.
A site for the containment of enemy combatants captured by a belligerent power in time of war.

A penal institution in which a large number of individuals, typically those belonging to specific ethnic or racial categories (or other categories which a government has deemed dangerous or undiserable), are held without charges or intent to file charges. Oftentimes the term is applied to such confinement during warfare and often includes political prisoners.

The literature by people from formerly colonized countries. It exists on all continents except Antarctica. Postcolonial literature often addresses the problems and consequences of the decolonization of a country, especially questions relating to the political and cultural independence of formerly subjugated people, and themes such as racialism and colonialism. A range of literary theory has evolved around the subject. It addresses the role of literature in perpetuating and challenging what postcolonial critic Edward Said refers to as cultural imperialism.
The tendency to look at the world primarily from the perspective of a European (usually Western European, especially during the Cold War) lens.
A process by which a person comes to adopt behaviors and/or traits of a dominant culture while maintaining elements of their minority culture.

A postcolonial theory which reevaluates the assumption of colonial identity through the repetition of discriminatory identity effects. In this way, hybridity can unsettle the narcissist demands of colonial power, but reforms its identifications in strategies of subversion that turn the gaze of the discriminated back upon the colonist.
The analysis of texts which aims to uncover or surmise colonialist and anticolonialist ideologies present in those texts.

A postcolonial theory which designates and identifies colonial populations who are socially, politically, and geographically excluded from the hierarchy of power of an imperial colony and from the metropolitan homeland of an empire as subalterns. The lens of subaltern theory intends to explore political-actor role of the people who constitute the mass population, rather than re-explore the political-actor roles of the social and economic elites in the history of India.

A place where people are imprisoned by a third party that is contracted by a government agency. Private prison companies typically enter into contractual agreements with governments that commit prisoners and then pay a per diem or monthly rate, either for each prisoner in the facility, or for each place available, whether occupied or not. Such contracts may be for the operation only of a facility, or for design, construction and operation.
A short-term holding facility usually used for the newly arrested or those waiting trial or sentencing. Jails are usually local facilities.
A typically long-term holding facility usually used for those serving longer sentences. Prisons are usually federal or state facilities.
An institution where persons are confined for punishment under the guise of public protection.
An organization in which individuals are housed or live.
A group whose relationship status or relationship orientation (sociosexual orientation) differ from the majority of the surrounding society.
Any of various organizations created by law or public authority.
A piece of furniture made for an individual to sit upon.
Any of various types of chairs used primarily for assistive purposes.
A wheelchair that is propelled by means of an electric motor (usually using differential steering) rather than manual power.
Chairs mounted on wheels and designed to be propelled by the occupant.

A chair with wheels, used when walking is difficult or impossible due to illness, injury, old age related problems, or disability. These can include spinal cord injuries (paraplegia, hemiplegia, and quadriplegia), broken leg(s), cerebral palsy, brain injury, osteogenesis imperfecta, motor neurone disease (MND), multiple sclerosis (MS), muscular dystrophy (MD), spina bifida, among other conditions.

An over-generalized belief about a particular category of people. It is an expectation that people might have about every person of a particular group. The type of expectation can vary. it can be, for example, an expectation about the group's personality, preferences, or ability.

The bias or perceived bias of journalists and news producers within the mass media in the selection of many events and stories that are reported and how they are covered. The term "media bias" implies a pervasive or widespread bias contravening the standards of journalism, rather than the perspective of an individual journalist or article. The direction and degree of media bias in various countries is widely disputed.

The bias or perceived bias of scholars allowing their beliefs to shape their research and the scientific community. It can refer to several types of scholastic prejudice i.e. logocentrism, phonocentrism, ethnocentrism or the belief that some sciences and disciplines rank higher than other.

A concept coined by Cedric J. Robinson in his book Black Marxism: The Making of the Black Radical Tradition, published in 1983. It describes the process of extracting social and economic value from a person of a different racial identity, typically a person of color. however, a person of any race might engage in racial capitalism, as might an institution dominated by one particular race. Robinson, in contrast to both his predecessors and successors, theorized that all capitalism was inherently racial capitalism, and racialism is present in all layers of capitalism's socioeconomic stratification. In fact, he states that capital "can only accumulate by producing and moving through relations of severe inequality among human groups." Some men who insist on dry sex regard "wet" women as unchaste. Dry sex can be painful for women and men. Dry sex is common in Sub-Saharan Africa and it has also been reported in Suriname among Afro-Surinamese women. The practice has been linked to the high incidence of HIV/AIDS infection in South Africa.

A scoping review may often be a preliminary stage before a systematic review, which 'scopes' out an area of inquiry and maps the language and key concepts to determine if a systematic review is possible or appropriate, or to lay the groundwork for a full systematic review. A disorder associated with three or more of the following: eating until feeling uncomfortably full. eating large amounts of food when not physically hungry. eating much more rapidly than normal. eating alone due to embarrassment. feeling of disgust, depression, or guilt after overeating. Criteria includes occurrence on average, at least 2 days a week for 6 months. The binge eating is not associated with the regular use of inappropriate compensatory behavior (i.e. purging, excessive exercise, etc.) and does not co-occur exclusively with bulimia nervosa or anorexia nervosa.

Movements or behaviors associated with sleep, sleep stages, or partial arousals from sleep that may impair sleep maintenance. Parasomnias are generally divided into four groups: arousal disorders, sleep-wake transition disorders, parasomnias of REM sleep, and nonspecific parasomnias.

Disorder in which five (or more) of the following symptoms have been present during the same 2-week period and represent a change from previous functioning. at least one of the symptoms is either (1) depressed mood or (2) loss of interest or pleasure. Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day. psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day. fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day. feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt. diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day. or recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt.
A U.S. (United States) American person whose ancestry originates wholly or partially from Spain.

comment: LGBTQIA+ Americans who are Hispanic and/or Latine.

A parasomnia that occurs in non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep. This refers to a disorder of arousal that occurs during slow-wave sleep (ie, NREM stage 3 sleep).

An abnormal state of wakefulness in which a person is not self-aware and is either altogether unresponsive to external stimuli (but nevertheless capable of pursuing and realizing an aim) or is selectively responsive in following the directions of the person (if any) who has induced the trance. Trance states may occur involuntarily and unbidden.
A category of altered states of consciousness suggested by Vaitl (2012) as being induced by music, meditation, or hypnosis.

Warnings that a work contains writing, images, or concepts that may be distressing to some people.

A human condition involving focused attention, reduced peripheral awareness, and an enhanced capacity to respond to suggestion.
An HIV infection which is asymptomatic in nature.
Any technique or method which purports to lead to an altered state of mind or state of consciousness.

Diseases of viral origin, characterized by incubation periods of months to years, insidious onset of clinical manifestations, and protracted clinical course. Though the disease process is protracted, viral multiplication may not be unusually slow. Conventional viruses produce slow virus diseases such as subacute sclerosing panencephalitis, progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, and AIDS. Diseases produced by unconventional agents were originally considered part of this group. They are now called prion diseases.

There are competing theories explaining hypnosis and related phenomena. Altered state theories see hypnosis as an altered state of mind or trance, marked by a level of awareness different from the ordinary state of consciousness. In contrast, nonstate theories see hypnosis as, variously, a type of placebo effect, a redefinition of an interaction with a therapist or form of imaginative role enactment.

[A] means to critically negotiate the relentless urbanisms that often characterize any United States based 'gay imaginary'... in which the city represents a beacon of tolerance and gay community, the country a locus of persecution and gay absence. In this sense, queer anti-urbanism can be thought of as critical opposition to homonormative and metronormative ways of life.
A practice of dominance and submission, where a submissive will give gifts and money to a financial dominant.

A bias in favor of concentrated urban population centers over more diffuse rural or suburban population areas.

A bias in favor of rural population areas over more concentrated metropolitan population centers.

A psychological stimulus that prompts recall of a previous traumatic experience. The stimulus itself need not be frightening or traumatic and may be only indirectly or superficially reminiscent of an earlier traumatic incident, such as a scent or a piece of clothing.

Hostility toward the city as opposed to the country, a simple rejection of the city, or a wish to destroy the city. discrimination against persons seen as belonging to cities. Such hostility and/or discrimination may be individualized or collective. Anti-urbanism may also be interpreted as a philosophy which aims to tackle metronormative ways of life. The phenomenon of anti-urbanism is often linked to urban and/or metropolitan bias.
Any object or event that elicits a sensory or behavioral response in an organism.
The process whereby auditory stimuli are selected, organized, and interpreted by the organism.
Absence or restriction of the usual auditory stimuli to which the individual responds.

An art form and cultural activity whose medium is sound organized in time. General definitions of music include common elements such as pitch (which governs melody and harmony), rhythm (and its associated concepts tempo, meter, and articulation), dynamics (loudness and softness), and the sonic qualities of timbre and texture (which are sometimes termed the "color" of a musical sound). Different styles or types of music may emphasize, de-emphasize or omit some of these elements.
A dimension of auditory sensation varying with cycles per second of the sound stimulus.
A variant of Down syndrome in which the person also has three X chromosomes.
Theatre pertaining to, or including parts which relate to, a specific subculture.
Educational, campaigning, and community organizations related to BDSM practices and the BDSM community.

A syndrome characterized by chronic kidney failure and gonadal dysgenesis in phenotypic females with karyotype of 46,XY or female individual with a normal 46,XX karyotype. It is caused by donor splice-site mutations of Wilms tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 11.
Theatre pertaining to, or including parts which relate to, LGBTQIA+ culture, persons, or the LGBTQIA+ community.
A recreational organization whose primary activities involve sex or other sexual practices in some form.

A chromosomal deletion syndrome that is a nephroblastoma that results in a rare genetic syndrome in which affected children are predisposed to develop Wilms tumor, Aniridia (absence of the colored part of the eye, the iris), genitourinary anomalies, and intellectual disabilities. The condition results from a deletion on chromosome 11 resulting in the loss of several genes. As such, it is one of the best studied examples of a condition caused by loss of neighboring (contiguous) genes.

A collaborative form of performing art that uses live performers, typically actors or actresses, to present the experience of a real or imagined event before a live audience in a specific place, often a stage. The performers may communicate this experience to the audience through combinations of gesture, speech, song, music, and dance. A genetically heterogeneous disorder caused by hypothalamic GNRH deficiency and olfactory nerve defects. It is characterized by congenital hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and anosmia, possibly with additional midline defects. It can be transmitted as an X-linked, an autosomal dominant, or an autosomal recessive trait.
The absence or restriction of the usual external sensory stimuli to which the individual responds.

The occurrence in an individual of two or more cell populations of different chromosomal constitutions, derived from a single zygote, as opposed to chimerism in which the different cell populations are derived from more than one zygote.

A device which is considered attached to a residence, in any of various ways. otherwise, any object related to the functions of the household or persons within it.

An organization which is, in some form or another, part of the ex-gay movement. an organization which encourages persons to refrain from entering or pursuing same-sex relationships, to eliminate homosexual desires and to develop heterosexual desires, or to enter into a heterosexual relationship.

The occurrence in an individual of two or more cell populations of different chromosomal constitutions, derived from different individuals. This contrasts with mosaicism in which the different cell populations are derived from a single individual.

The main characteristics of this disorder are moderate to severe intellectual disability, speech delay, hypotonia and mild dysmorphic features, including facial asymmetry, hypertelorism, bilateral low set 'lop' ears, and micrognathia. Skeletal abnormalities (such as skull deformities, radioulnar synostosis, elbow flexion, clinodactyly, brachydactyly) have also been associated with this condition. The disorder is characterized by intrusive recurring thoughts or images of the traumatic event. avoidance of anything associated with the event. a state of hyperarousal and diminished emotional responsiveness. These symptoms are present for at least one month and the disorder is usually long-term.

A library designed to assist physicians, health professionals, students, patients, consumers, medical researchers, and information specialists in finding health and scientific information to improve, update, assess, or evaluate health care.
A device utilized for plethysmography.
Mental health disorders that are a result of an atypical response to both short and long-term anxiety due to physical, mental, or emotional stress.
A patient data recorder which produces graphical output.
The psychological trauma experienced by a rape victim that includes disruptions to normal physical, emotional, cognitive, and interpersonal behavior.
Recording of change in the size of a part as modified by the circulation in it.
A measurement of any physiological phenomenon.
Any of various disorders manifesting with symptoms similar to those of schizophrenia.
A device utilized for penile photoplethysmography.
An acute stress disorder that involves neurotic reactions to unusual, severe, or overwhelming military stress.
A device utilized for vaginal photoplethysmography.

A class of traumatic stress disorders that is characterized by the significant dissociative states seen immediately after overwhelming trauma. By definition it cannot last longer than 1 month, if it persists, a diagnosis of post-traumatic stress disorder is more appropriate.
A place or collection containing records, documents, or other materials that is primarily owned by a government or is itself a government entity.
Incestuous behavior between two adults.
The particular form of biological classification (taxonomy) set up by Carl Linnaeus, as set forth in his Systema Naturae (1735) and subsequent works.
Sexual activity or marriage between persons who were unaware of a family relationship between them which would be considered incestuous.

The system in which users apply public tags to online items, typically to make those items easier for themselves or others to find later. Over time, this can give rise to a classification system based on those tags and how often they are applied or searched for, in contrast to a taxonomic classification designed by the owners of the content and specified when it is published.
Incestuous behavior between two twins (either monozygotic or dizygotic).
A system of knowledge organization by which library resources are arranged and ordered systematically.
Incestuous behavior between two cousins.

The science of naming, defining (circumscribing) and classifying groups of biological organisms on the basis of shared characteristics. Organisms are grouped together into taxa (singular: taxon) and these groups are given a taxonomic rank. groups of a given rank can be aggregated to form a super-group of higher rank, thus creating a taxonomic hierarchy.
Incestuous behavior between an aunt or uncle (gender-neutral word: pibling) and their niece or nephew (gender-neutral word: niefling).
A loosely defined community of lesbians who practice BDSM activities.
Sexual intercourse occurring in public places.
A loosely defined community of gay men who practice BDSM activities.
A classification of the range of different levels at which humans vary in sexual characteristics.
A loosely defined community of LGBTQIA+ persons who practice BDSM activities.
Slang related to pornographic sex work or utilized by those engaged by such work.

A genre of pornography involving the depiction of incest (sexual activity between relatives). Incest pornography can feature actual relatives, but the main type of this pornography is fauxcest, which features non-related actors of similar looks to suggest family relationship.
Sexual intercourse occurring in private quarters or spaces.
Sexual intercourse which takes place outside the boundaries of a committed relationship, implying a lack of emotional attachment or necessary familiarity with sexaul partners.
A loosely defined community of transgender people who practice BDSM activities.
Awareness of the differences experienced by bisexual persons including life expectations and discriminatory attitudes.
A form of child sexual abuse in which a prepubescent child is sexually abused by one or more other children or adolescents, and in which no adult is directly involved.
Awareness of the differences experienced by Intersex persons including life expectations and discriminatory attitudes.
Incestuous behavior between two siblings.
Incestuous behavior which is abusive in nature, i.e. without the consent of involved persons or against their will (such as a parent with a young child).
Awareness of the differences experienced by asexual persons including life expectations and discriminatory attitudes.
The mating of plants or non-human animals which are closely related genetically.
The systematic arrangement of entities in any field into categories classes based on common characteristics such as properties, morphology, subject matter, etc.
Incestuous behavior between a stepparent and their stepchild.
A classification system categorizing some form of scientific knowledge.
Incestuous behavior between an adult and a child.
Sexuality of transgender persons.
Incestuous behavior toward a child which is abusive in nature, i.e. without the consent of involved persons or against their will.
Sexuality of cisgender persons.
Incestuous behavior between a parent and a child.
A hierarchical classification of things.
Any of various systems which attempt to classify biological entities, typically organisms.
Incestuous behavior which is considered heterosexual in nature (i.e. between a woman and a boy or between a man and a girl).
Any of various systems which attempt to classify elements or compounds according to certain chemical functional or structural properties.
Incestuous behavior which is considered homosexual in nature (i.e. between two men or between a man and a boy).
Media pertaining especially to lesbians and/or lesbian culture.

Literature pertaining especially to lesbians and/or lesbian culture.
Media related to a particular culture or culture. or to any of various subcultures.

A commercial experience that blurs the boundaries between a financial transaction and a romantic relationship. It ranges from a transactional sex relationship to a client paying a sex worker to pretend to be their partner during the session.

A hole in a wall, or other partition, often between public lavatory cubicles or adult video arcade booths and lounges, for people to engage in sexual activity or observe the person in the next cubicle while one or both parties masturbate.
Media pertaining especially to bisexual persons and/or culture.
Media pertaining especially to gay men and/or gay male culture.

Periodical pertaining especially to asexual persons and/or culture.
A periodical about or otherwise related to a particular subculture or subcultures.
Periodical pertaining especially to lesbians and/or lesbian culture.
Periodical pertaining especially to intersex people and/or culture.
Periodical pertaining especially to bisexual persons and/or culture.
Periodical pertaining especially to gay men and/or gay male culture.

A performing art form consisting of purposefully selected sequences of human movement. This movement has aesthetic and symbolic value, and is acknowledged as dance by performers and observers within a particular culture. Dance can be categorized and described by its choreography, by its repertoire of movements, or by its historical period or place of origin.
Periodical pertaining especially to transgender people and/or culture.

Forms of art in which artists use their voices, bodies or inanimate objects to convey artistic expression. It is different from visual arts, which is when artists use paint, canvas or various materials to create physical or static art objects. Performing arts include a range of disciplines which are performed in front of a live audience.
The sex or gender with which a person is most likely to have a romantic relationship or fall in love.
The sex or gender with which a person is most likely to have a romantic relationship or fall in love.
Sexual attraction after close emotional connections have been formed.
The interactions between individuals of different generations. These interactions include communication, caring, accountability, loyalty, and even conflict between related or non-related individuals.
The reciprocal interaction of two or more persons.
A relationship represents a directional (binary) association between two entities in which the observed entity is associated to the given entity.
A state of connectedness between people, objects, or events. to be associated or connected with something.
Connectedness between entities and/or interactions representing their relatedness or influence.
The reciprocal interaction of two or more professional individuals.
Any relationship which includes a temporal or time-based component.
The connectedness between entities as related by their position.
A relationship between entities within observations that has a spatial component (within, adjacent, etc.).
A sexual non-identity, in which an individual denies any specific label related to their sexual identity.
A person who identifies as pomosexual. i.e. an individual who does not wish to label their sexual orientation or sexuality generally.
Infrequent or irregular ovulation (usually defined as cycles of ≥36 days or <8 cycles a year).
A phenomenon whereby an observed phenotype, qualitative or quantative, is not explainable by the simple additive effects of the individual gene pertubations alone.
The effect that a pair of organisms living together in a community have on each other.
The state of being sexually and romantically attracted to members of more than one gender.
A sexuality that involves attraction to only one sex: generally, homosexuality or heterosexuality.
A sexual orientation characterized by the potential for aesthetic attraction, romantic love and/or sexual desire for people, regardless of their gender identity or biological sex.
A sexual orientation characterized by the potential for aesthetic attraction, romantic love and/or sexual desire for people, regardless of their gender identity or biological sex.

The state of being sexually attracted to members of female and male sexes (in non-human animals). In humans, bisexuality has historically been used to mean attraction to men and women, but is usually used today to refer to persons who are sexually and/or romantically attracted to persons with a gender or genders like theirs and those with a gender or genders unlike theirs.

The state of being sexually attracted to members of female and male sexes (in non-human animals). In humans, bisexuality has historically been used to mean attraction to men and women, but is usually used today to refer to persons who are sexually and/or romantically attracted to persons with a gender or genders like theirs and those with a gender or genders unlike theirs.

The state of being sexually attracted to members of female and male sexes (in non-human animals). In humans, bisexuality has historically been used to mean attraction to men and women, but is usually used today to refer to persons who are sexually and/or romantically attracted to persons with a gender or genders like theirs and those with a gender or genders unlike theirs.

The state of being sexually attracted to members of female and male sexes (in non-human animals). In humans, bisexuality has historically been used to mean attraction to men and women, but is usually used today to refer to persons who are sexually and/or romantically attracted to persons with a gender or genders like theirs and those with a gender or genders unlike theirs.
The state of being sexually and romantically attracted primarily or exclusively to persons of a gender identity different than one's own.
The state of being sexually and romantically attracted primarily or exclusively to persons of a gender identity different than one's own.
The state of being sexually and romantically attracted primarily or exclusively to persons of a gender identity different than one's own.

Homosexuality as observed in female organisms.
Homosexuality as observed in male organisms.
An interaction between two or more individuals or populations in a society. Social interaction is a building block of society.
The spectrum between asexuality and sexuality.
Polysexuality is sexual attraction to multiple, but not all, genders.
Bisexuality as observed in animals.

Absence of ovulation when it would be normally expected (in a post-menarchal, premenopausal person). Anovulation usually manifests itself as irregularity of menstrual periods, that is, unpredictable variability of intervals, duration, or bleeding. Anovulation can also cause cessation of periods (secondary amenorrhea) or excessive bleeding (dysfunctional uterine bleeding).
The absence of ovulation.
Suspension or cessation of ovulation in animals or humans with follicle-containing ovaries (ovarian follicle). Depending on the etiology, ovulation may be induced with appropriate therapy.
Bisexuality as observed in mammals.
Bisexuality as observed in vertebrates.
Bisexuality as observed in humans.
Bisexuality as observed in primates.
A business serving mostly drag artists or being heavily associated with drag performance, whose primary function is the serving of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises.

A type of business establishment where alcoholic drink is sold and dancers provide entertainment. The term go-go bar originally referred to a nightclub, bar, or similar establishment that featured go-go dancers. while some go-go bars in that original sense still exist, the link between its present uses and that original meaning is often more tenuous and regional. Speaking broadly, the term has been used by venues that cover a wide range of businesses, from nightclubs or discotheques, where dancers are essentially there to set the mood, to what are in essence burlesque theaters or strip clubs, where dancers are part of a show and the primary focus.
A specific type of go-go bar, located in Southeast Asia (usually in Thailand) wherein dancers are primarily kathoey.
The history of developments of computing hardware, ranging from early devices to aid calculation to modern-day computers.
Any of various histories pertaining to computer networks, i.e. sets of computers sharing resources located on or provided by network nodes.
Any of various theories pertaining to the global system of computer networks that provides the common TCP IP infrastructure for e-mail, the World Wide Web, and other online activities.
A business serving mostly gay people whose primary function is the serving of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises.
A business serving mostly transgender people whose primary function is the serving of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises.
A business serving mostly person belonging to any of various cross-dressing subcultures whose primary function is the serving of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises.
Heterosexuality as observed in animals.
Heterosexuality as observed in mammals.
Heterosexuality as observed in vertebrates.
Heterosexuality as observed in humans.
Heterosexuality as observed in primates.
A family relationship between persons linked through descent from a common ancestor.
Relationship between molecular entities, based on contacts, direct or indirect.
A biological family relationship between persons whoe are not linked through a direct line of descent.
A family relationship between persons linked through marraige or adoption.
A lineal family relationship from a person to their biological parent.
A biological family relationship between persons linked through a direct line of descent.
A lineal family relationship between two persons with at least one shared parent.
Organization of various histories by primary topic or topics.

The history of the invention of tools and techniques. Technology can refer to methods ranging from as simple as stone tools to the complex genetic engineering and information technology that has emerged since the 1980s.
The history of any of various methodologies of computation, including the study and experimentation of algorithmic processes and development of both hardware and software.
A sexuality defined by its lack of relationship to labels, defined by its avoidance of labels, or as its not fitting with any other specific labels.
Any of various histories of a given region or regions.
Any of various histories of Africa or any of various regions of Africa.
Any of various histories of Asia or any of various regions of Asia.
Any of various histories of Europe or any of various regions of Europe.
Any of various histories of Oceania or any of various regions of Oceania.
Any of various histories of North America or any of various regions of North America.
Any of various histories of South America or any of various regions of South America.
An interaction between two individuals.
An interpersonal relationship that involves physical or emotional intimacy.
Procedures by which a group of individuals approach and solve their common objectives.
An interaction between three individuals.
Sexual activity that usually does not include sexual penetration.
Sexual interaction between at least two organisms which involves contact and is expected to culminate in orgasm or orgasms for one or all of the parties involved.
Sexual intercourse in which some anatomical structure is inserted into the armpit.
Insertion of a body part or other object into a bodily orifice for the purposes of sexual pleasure.

term: person assigned female at birth who desires a penis
comment: A person who was assigned female at birth who desires to have a penis for any reason.
The conscientious, explicit and judicious use of current best evidence in making decisions about the care of individual patients.

term: person assigned male at birth who desires a vagina
comment: A person who was assigned male at birth who desires to have a vagina for any reason.
Mystical, religious, or spiritual practices performed for some presumed health benefit.
A person who was assigned X at birth.

The practice of prayer and gestures (such as laying on of hands) that are believed by some to elicit divine intervention in spiritual and physical healing, especially the Christian practice. Believers assert that the healing of disease and disability can be brought about by religious faith through prayer or other rituals that, according to adherents, can stimulate a divine presence and power. Religious belief in divine intervention does not depend on empirical evidence of an evidence-based outcome achieved via faith healing. Virtually all scientists and philosophers dismiss faith healing as pseudoscience.
A person who was assigned female at birth.

The study or comparison of the traditional medicine based on bioactive compounds in plants and animals and practiced by various ethnic groups, often members of various Indigenous peoples. Ethnomedical research is interdisciplinary. in its study of traditional medicines, it applies the methods of ethnobotany and medical anthropology.
