The act of seeing and the act of being seen.
Scientific journals which cover sexological topics.
Development of any of various interpersonal identities, or identities based on relationships with others (for example, sexual orientation identity).

Legal, social, or ethical principles of freedom or entitlement. that is, rights are the fundamental normative rules about what is allowed of people or owed to people, according to some legal system, social convention, or ethical theory.

The ability of an individual or group to seclude themselves, or information about themselves, and thereby express themselves selectively. The boundaries and content of what is considered private differ among cultures and individuals.
The condition or status of something being hidden.

Moral principles or norms that describe certain standards of human behaviour and are regularly protected as natural and legal rights in municipal and international law. They are commonly understood as inalienable,[3] fundamental rights "to which a person is inherently entitled simply because she or he is a human being" and which are "inherent in all human beings", regardless of their nation, location, language, religion, ethnic origin, or any other status.

A class of rights that protect individuals' freedom from infringement by governments, social organizations, and private individuals. They ensure one's entitlement to participate in the civil and political life of the society and state without discrimination or repression.
The condition of concealing one's sexual identity, as a gay person who actively conceals their identity.
The condition of concealing one's racial identity actively, rather than passing as a member of a different race.
The condition of concealing something about one's self.
The condition of concealing one's gender identity, as a transgender person before coming out or for any other reason.
The attainment of sexual pleasure from watching other people have sex.
The unique numerical identity of a person or being in the course of time.
The sum of a being's knowledge and understanding of their self.
The gaze of the cisgender viewer, specifically in regard to viewing transgender persons and blindness toward transgender issues.
The concept that being cisgender and heterosexual is the societal norm. the intersection of cisnormativity and heteronormativity.

The development of the distinct personality of an individual regarded as a persisting entity (known as personal continuity) in a particular stage of life in which individual characteristics are possessed and by which a person is recognized or known (such as the establishment of a reputation). This process defines individuals to others and themselves. Pieces of the person's actual identity include a sense of continuity, a sense of uniqueness from others, and a sense of affiliation.
The development of one's sexuality, including sexual orientation and interests, among other things.
One's identity in relationship to the groups within one interacts and participates and those they do not.

Sexual identity is how one thinks of oneself in terms of to whom one is sexually attracted. Note that sexual identity may also refer to sexual orientation identity, which is when people identify or dis-identify with a sexual orientation or choose not to identify with a sexual orientation.

Sexual identity is how one thinks of oneself in terms of to whom one is sexually attracted. Note that sexual identity may also refer to sexual orientation identity, which is when people identify or dis-identify with a sexual orientation or choose not to identify with a sexual orientation.
Development of one's self-concept of gender.
An Indigenous person who is gay.
A blending of the terms "queer" and "Indigenous", referring to the unique intersecting experiences of queer Indigenous identity.
Any of various sexual interactions which are physical in nature, rather than virtual.
Agents that improve the ability to carry out athletic activities.
Travel to another country for the purpose of obtaining a COVID-19 vaccine.
Travel to another country for the purpose of obtaining a vaccine.
A person who uses multiple sets of pronouns, such as a person who uses she/her and they/them pronouns.
An Indigenous woman who is a lesbian.
An Indigenous person who is a lesbian.
A pronoun set composed of they/them and he/him pronouns, in which they/them pronouns are typically (but not always) prioritized.
A non-neoplastic or neoplastic disorder that affects the wolffian reproductive system.
A reproductive organ cancer that is manifested in the müllerian genitals. This includes organs such as the ovaries, fallopian tubes, uterus, cervix, vagina and vulva.
A reproductive organ cancer that is manifested in the wolffian genital system. This includes organs such as the penis and scrotum.
A malignant neoplasm that affects the wolffian genital system.
A benign neoplasm that affects the wolffian genital system.
Any of the infectious diseases caused by the species Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
Any of various diseases due to organisms from the genus Mycobacteria.
A pronoun set composed of they, them, their, theirs, and either themself or themselves.
An infection that is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
A mistaken belief or a wrong idea pertaining to vaccines or vaccination.
A non-neoplastic or neoplastic disorder that affects the müllerian reproductive system.
Any of various pseudoscientific movements which purport the conspiracy that vaccination causes other health problems, autism, homosexuality, and gender dysphoria, among other things.

term: legal gender on original birth certificate
comment: A legal gender (or gender marker) that appears on a person's original (or first) birth certificate.

Assigned gender is one's gender which was assigned at birth, typically by a medical and/or legal organization, and then later registered with other organizations. Such a designation is typically based off of the superficial appearance of external genitalia present at birth.

Assigned gender is one's gender which was assigned at birth, typically by a medical and/or legal organization, and then later registered with other organizations. Such a designation is typically based off of the superficial appearance of external genitalia present at birth.
A benign or malignant neoplasm that affects the genital system.
Any of various changes to any legal gender marker on some documentation.
Any of various changes to any legal gender marker on some documentation.

Any of various shifts which result in a change of some form of gender. This can refer to changes in gender in fiction, a genderfluid person's shift from one gender identity to another, or a change of a legal gender marker from one to another.
A change of name which occurs as the result of a legal process.
An Indigenous person who is transgender.
An Indigenous person who is bisexual.
An Indigenous man who is gay.
A sequence which is found multiple times in a genome and also in other species, showing a common function between those organisms.
A benign or malignant neoplasm that affects the müllerian genital system.
A sequence of nucleotides in DNA or RNA which encode the synthesis of a gene product, either RNA or protein.
A benign or malignant neoplasm that affects the wolffian genital system.
A sequence of nucleotides in a gene which do not encode an RNA or protein product.
A sequence of single-stranded DNA which is complementary to messenger RNA or DNA that has been synthesized from messenger RNA by reverse transcriptase.

Politics further on the right of the left–right political spectrum than the standard political right, particularly in terms of extremist nationalism, nativist ideologies and authoritarian tendencies. Historically used to describe the experiences of fascism and Nazism, today far-right politics includes neo-fascism, neo-Nazism, the Third Position, the alt-right, white supremacism, white nationalism and other ideologies or organizations that feature aspects of ultranationalist, chauvinist, xenophobic, theocratic, racist, homophobic, transphobic, anti-communist, or reactionary views.

A kind of party politics which supports social equality and egalitarianism, often in opposition to social hierarchy. It typically involves a concern for those in society whom its adherents perceive as disadvantaged relative to others as well as a belief that there are unjustified inequalities that need to be reduced or abolished.
Politics which relate to political parties. often used in a derogatory manner to note the most of parties rather than on the good of the general public.

Politics further to the left of the left–right political spectrum than the standard political left. There are different definitions of the far-left. Some scholars define it as representing the left of social democracy while others limit it to the left of communist parties. In certain instances, especially in the news media, the term far-left has been associated with some forms of anarchism and communism, or it characterizes groups that advocate for revolutionary anti-capitalism and anti-globalization. Extremist far-left politics can involve violent acts and the formation of far-left militant organizations meant to abolish capitalist systems and the upper ruling class. Far-left terrorism consists of groups that attempt to realize their radical ideals and bring about change through violence rather than established political processes.

A kind of party politics which represents the view that certain social orders and hierarchies are inevitable, natural, normal, or desirable, typically supporting this position on the basis of natural law, economics, or tradition. Hierarchy and inequality may be seen as natural results of traditional social differences or the competition in market economies. The term right-wing can generally refer to "the conservative or reactionary section of a political party or system".
A conspiracy theory about the death of an individual.
Conspiracy theories related to religion.
A parasitic ectoparasitic infectious disease caused by members of the genus Sarcoptes.
A conspiracy theory which links multiple alleged conspiracies together hierarchically. At the summit is a distant but all-powerful evil force.
A parasitic ectoparasitic infectious disease caused by mites.

A conspiracy theory believed to have broad goals, usually conceived as securing control of a country, a region, or even the entire world. The goals are sweeping, whilst the conspiratorial machinery is generally simple: a single, evil organization implements a plan to infiltrate and subvert existing institutions.
Encephalomyelitis caused by opportunistic human T-lymphotropic virus type III (HTLV-III) infection.
A conspiracy theory related to a limited and well-defined event.

A disease given its first diagnostic criteria in 1986: (1) muscle fatiguability in which, even after minimal physical effort, three or more days elapse before full muscle power is restored. (2) extraordinary variability or fluctuation of symptoms, even in the course of one day. and (3) chronicity. Signs of encephalomyelitis were considered to be one of the symptoms noted in the 1950s.

term: sexuality and gender identity-related conspiracy theories
comment: Conspiracy theories related to sexuality and/or gender identity.
A central nervous system disease that features inflammation.
Sexual intercourse used with a dildo attached to a harness for vaginal penetration.
A lesbian who uses they/them pronouns. Typically such a person will identify as a woman, as woman-aligned, or as nonbinary, but not always.
An operation carried out for the purpose(s) of deception.
Immunological states where the immune system produces harmful responses upon reexposure to sensitising antigens.
Sexual intercourse used with a dildo attached to a harness for anal penetration.
A lesbian who uses he/him pronouns. Typically such a person will identify as a woman or as woman-aligned, but not always.
An immune or non-immune mediated pathological process that represents the underlying mechanism of hypersensitivity conditions.

A type of sex toy in the size and shape of a sexual partner for aid in masturbation. The sex doll may consist of an entire body with face, or just a head, pelvis or other partial body, with the accessories (vagina, anus, mouth, penis) for sexual stimulation. The parts are sometimes vibrating and may be removable or interchangeable.
A form of gender nonconformity in which one uses neopronouns or pronouns in a non-standard manner.
Altered reactivity to an antigen, which can result in pathologic reactions upon subsequent exposure to that particular antigen.

A word mentioned on Middle Kingdom Egyptian (2000 to 1800 BCE) pottery shards found near ancient Thebes alongside the words "tai" (male) and "hmt" (female). Modern scholars suggest that the term represented a third gender rather than eunuchs, as there is little evidence that such individuals were castrated.
A gay person who uses she/her pronouns. Typically such a person will identify as a man or as man-aligned, but not always.

Any of various conspiracy theories that attribute the planning and execution of the September 11 attacks against the United States to parties other than, or in addition to, al-Qaeda, including that there was advance knowledge of the attacks among high-level government officials. Government investigations and independent reviews have rejected these theories.
A parasitic ectoparasitic infectious disease caused by some species of arthropod.
A pronoun (or set of pronouns) derived from otherkin people or in use by an otherkin person.
Conspiracy theories related to science and/or technology.

The suppression of speech, public communication, or other information, on the basis that such material is considered objectionable, harmful, sensitive, or "inconvenient." Censorship can be conducted by governments, private institutions, and corporations.
A person who uses nounself pronouns.
A relationship involving some kind of sexual intimacy between two lesbians, one identifying as femme and the other identifying as butch.
A pronoun or set of pronouns that an individual likes less than their primary pronoun set or sets, but still allows to be used to refer to themself.
Sexual intercourse used with a dildo attached to a harness for either vaginal or anal penetration.
A kind of gender-neutral pronoun set derived from or using an emoji or series of emoji characters.

The period in the history of ancient Egypt following a period of political division known as the First Intermediate Period. The Middle Kingdom lasted from approximately 2050 to 1710 BCE, stretching from the reunification of Egypt under the reign of Mentuhotep II in the Eleventh Dynasty to the end of the Twelfth Dynasty. The kings of the Eleventh Dynasty ruled from Thebes and the kings of the Twelfth Dynasty ruled from el-Lisht.
A person who is a man or who is man-aligned who is attracted to other men or man-aligned people. This includes gay men, bisexual men, and pansexual men, among others.

A third gender category suggested by remains found in a Corded Ware burial ground found in a suburb of Prague, Czech Republic in April of 2011. The remains were believed to have been of a person who would've been assigned male at birth, but the grave did not carry any gender-specific grave goods and the orientation of the body was in a stereotypically feminine position for the culture.
A person who is a woman or who is woman-aligned who is attracted to other women or woman-aligned people. This includes lesbians, bisexual women, and pansexual women, among others.

A recurring assemblage of artifacts from a specific time and place that may constitute the material culture remains of a particular past human society. The connection between the artifacts is based on archaeologists' understanding and interpretation and does not necessarily relate to real groups of humans in the past.
The simultaneous use of pink, purple, and blue lighting to represent bisexual characters.
The illumination of scenes to be filmed.
A contagious infestation of parasitic arthropods.
The illumination of scenes to be photographed.
A contagious disease involving parasitic insects found on the head (Pediculus humanus capitis), body (Pediculus humanus corporis), or pubic area (Pthirus pubis) that typically cause itching and rash.

The deliberate use of light to achieve practical or aesthetic effects. Lighting includes the use of both artificial light sources like lamps and light fixtures, as well as natural illumination by capturing daylight.
A parasitic infectious disease that is caused by parasitic animals (or metazoans).
A lice infestation that involves parasitic infestation by crab lice Pthirus pubis, which are found in the pubic hair.

A lice infestation that involves parasitic infestation by pubic lice Pthirus pubis, which are found in the pubic hair, less commonly in eyebrows, eyelashes, beard, mustache, armpit, perianal area, groin, trunk and scalp. The symptoms include itching in the pubic and groin area. Intense itching leads to scratching which can cause sores and secondary bacterial infection of the skin.
Infections with organisms members of the kingdom Animalia (Metazoa).
Stong or extreme (and often vengeful) anger or indignation on the part of teh LGBTQIA+ community.
Conspiracy theories related to race.
Any fatigue syndrome which seems to occur after a COVID-19 infection.
Stong or extreme (and often vengeful) anger or indignation.
Conspiracy theories organized by the type of theory according to some typology.
Any fatigue syndrome which seems to occur after a viral infection.
Conspiracy theories organized by attribute or attributes of individuals or groups said to be involved as part of the theory.

A clinical diagnosis characterized by an unexplained persistent or relapsing chronic fatigue that is of at least six months' duration, is not the result of ongoing exertion, is not substantially alleviated by rest, and results in substantial reduction of previous levels of occupational, educational, social, or personal activities. Common concurrent symptoms of at least six months duration include impairment of memory or concentration, diffuse pain, sore throat, tender lymph nodes, headaches of a new type, pattern, or severity, and nonrestorative sleep.
Stong or extreme (and often vengeful) anger or indignation on the part of teh gay male community.
An informal grouping of syndromes in which the major symptom is fatigue.
The subfield of transgender studies dealing specifically with transgender youth.
A contagious infestation of parasitic insects of the suborder Anoplura.

May refer to (1) a branch of separatist feminism in the transgender community which advocates for separation from cisgender society in general. (2) a form of separatism within certain segments of the transgender community which aim to differentiate being "true" transgender people and "fake" transgender people (such as persons who follow the Harry Benjamin syndrome philosophy, self-identified autogynephiles, and transmedicalists). or (3) separation of transness from the LGBT (or LGBTQIA+) community.

Sex as defined in a specific medical and clinical context. It is almost always more preferable to be more specific as to how sex is being determined (chromosomally, genetically, hormonally, etc.) or to include quantitative values than to label something as "sex for clinical use".
Gender as recorded by any of various institutions, organizations, writings, etc.
A type of neopronoun derived from a pre-existing word in order for it to be used in a gender-neutral pronoun set.

A genre of popular music developed in the United States by inner-city African Americans and Latino Americans in the Bronx borough of New York City in the 1970s. DJ Kool Herc, a Jamaican DJ, is credited for officially originating hip hop music through his "Back to School Jam", hosted on August 11, 1973, at 1520 Sedgwick Avenue. It consists of a stylized rhythmic music that commonly accompanies rapping, a rhythmic and rhyming speech that is chanted.

A person who regards themselves as culturally, ethnically, or religiously adhering to aspects of Hinduism. Historically, the term has also been used as a geographical, cultural, and later religious identifier for people living in the Indian subcontinent.
An anthemic subgenre of house music that became most popular in gay clubs during the second half of the 1990s.

A loose grouping of primarily American litigants, commentators, tax protesters, and financial-scheme promoters, who claim to be answerable only to their particular interpretations of the common law and to not be subject to any government statutes or proceedings. In the United States, they do not recognize U.S. currency and maintain that they are "free of any legal constraints". They especially reject most forms of taxation as illegitimate. Participants in the movement argue this concept in opposition to the idea of "federal citizens", who, they say, have unknowingly forfeited their rights by accepting some aspect of federal law.
Any of various movements which derive their beliefs from libertarianism.

a political philosophy and type of libertarianism that supports capitalist property rights and defends market distribution of natural resources and private property. The term right-libertarianism is used to distinguish this class of views on the nature of property and capital from left-libertarianism, a type of libertarianism that combines self-ownership with an egalitarian approach to natural resources. In contrast to socialist libertarianism, right-libertarianism supports free-market capitalism.
LGBTQ people who are Tao.

term: legal gender on most recent birth certificate
comment: A legal gender (or gender marker) that appears on a person's most recent birth certificate.

A tradition in right-wing politics. the reactionary stance opposes policies for the social transformation of society, whereas conservatives seek to preserve the socio-economic structure and order that exists in the present. In popular usage, reactionary refers to a strongly traditionalist conservative political perspective of the person who is opposed to social, political, and economic change.
Acts of physical intimacy in the view of others. What is an acceptable display of affection varies with respect to culture and context.
Sex of a fetus that has not undergone the processes of sexual differentiation, which dies at or after 20 or 28 weeks of pregnancy, as the result of a stillbirth.
Any of various movements which derive their beliefs from paleoconservatism.
Sex workers who engage in phone sex with clients.
A sentimentality for the past, typically for a period or place with happy personal associations.
Any of various movements which derive their beliefs from conservatism.
An act or state of being sentimental, i.e. an act or state characterized by sentiment, sentimentality or excess emotion.

A tendency within the broader American Patriot movement that emphasizes Christian nationalism. Like the larger movement, it promotes a revisionist interpretation of American history in which the federal government has turned against the ideas of liberty and natural rights expressed in the American Revolution.
LGBTQ people who are Hindu.
Music which has been remixed using electronic elements. alternatively, any music which has been remixed which takes advantage of electronics for creation and/or playback.

A term which is used to describe a conglomeration of American non-unified right-wing populist, nationalist political movements, most notably far-right armed militias, sovereign citizens, and tax protesters. Ideologies held by patriot movement groups often focus on anti-government conspiracy theories, with the Anti-Defamation League (ADL) describing a common belief that "government has been infiltrated and subverted" and is no longer legitimate. The movement first emerged in 1994 in response to what members saw as "violent government repression" of dissenting groups, along with increased gun control and the Clinton government.
An adherent of Shinto.

An informal grouping of artists identifying as members of the LGBTQIA+ community into a subgenre of hip hop. These subgenre labels are not marked by any specific production style, as artists within it may simultaneously be associated with virtually any other subgenre of hip hop, or may also make music that falls outside the subgenre entirely. Rather, the terms are defined by a direct engagement with LGBTQ culture in elements such as the lyrical themes or the artist's visual identity and presentation.
Any of various movements which derive their beliefs from paleolibertarianism.
LGBTQ people who are Shinto.
A type of lyric music created in which the track is slowed down in order to make the singer's voice sound as that person's "trans" doppelgänger.
Any of various movements which derive their beliefs from right-wing libertarianism.
A follower of Taoism.

A genre of music in which a cover track is sped up from its source material by 10-30%. The name is derived from Nightcore, a Norwegian duo who released pitch-shifted versions of trance and eurodance songs, but now more broadly refers to any sped-up cover. Nightcore is also commonly associated with anime, with many YouTube thumbnails of nightcore remixes containing anime characters and art.

A libertarian political activism strategy. It was developed by American anarcho-capitalist theorists Murray Rothbard and Lew Rockwell in the American political context after the end of Cold War. From 1989 to 1995, they sought to communicate libertarian notions of opposition to government intervention using messages accessible to working and middle-class people of the time. This approach, usually identified as right-wing populism, was intended to radicalize citizens against the state. The name they chose for this style of activism evoked the roots of modern libertarianism, hence the prefix paleo. That founding movement was American classical liberalism, which shared the anti-war and anti–New Deal sentiments of the Old Right in the first half of the 20th century.
Medical and nursing care of patients in the terminal stage of an illness.
A nonbinary person who experiences sexual attraction outside of binary constructs. alternatively, a nonbinary person who is attracted to other nonbinary people.
An act committed with the intent of disguising the actual source of responsibility and pinning blame on lesbians.
Any of various communities associated with the cross-dressing subculture.
An act committed with the intent of disguising the actual source of responsibility and pinning blame on transgender people.
Any of various states of disharmony between actual and ideal selves, or any of various incongruences between experience, personality, and self-concept.
An act committed with the intent of disguising the actual source of responsibility and pinning blame on LGBTQIA+ people or persons.
An immune system disease that has material basis in abnormal immune responses, usually to allergens such as insect venom, dust mites, pollen, drugs or some foods.
An act committed with the intent of disguising the actual source of responsibility and pinning blame on a second party.

An immune response that occurs following re-exposure to an innocuous antigen, and that requires the presence of existing antibodies against that antigen. This response involves the binding of IgE to mast cells, and may worsen with repeated exposures.
An Austronesian and Southeast African ethnic group native to the island and country of Madagascar.

A broad range of percussive electronic music genres made largely for nightclubs, raves and festivals. It is generally produced for playback by DJs who create seamless selections of tracks, called a mix, by segueing from one recording to another. EDM producers also perform their music live in a concert or festival setting in what is sometimes called a live PA.

A political philosophy and type of libertarianism that stresses both individual freedom and social equality. Left-libertarianism represents several related yet distinct approaches to political and social theory.

An ethnic group of Madagascar. They are found on the western and northwest region of the island, in a band along the coast. The Sakalava are one of the smaller ethnic groups, constituting about 6.2 percent of the total population. Their name means "people of the long valleys." They occupy the western edge of the island from Toliara in the south to Sambirano in the north.
Music composed specifically to facilitate or accompany dancing.

A political philosophy that upholds liberty as a core principle. Libertarians seek to maximize autonomy and political freedom, emphasizing free association, freedom of choice, individualism and voluntary association. Libertarians share a skepticism of authority and state power, but some libertarians diverge on the scope of their opposition to existing economic and political systems.

Any of a broad group of electronic-based music styles such as techno, house, ambient, jungle and other styles intended not just for dancing. Sometimes the term is also used to refer electronic music generally.
A political movement which advocates for cultural, ethnic, tribal, religious, racial, governmental or gender separation from the larger group.

A gender role and/or identity that is part of Samoan culture. Typically, it refers to persons who are assigned female at birth and who embody both masculine and feminine traits to some degree. Such persons may characterize themselves as transgender men, cisgender lesbians, masculine women, tomboys, or a distinctly different category of experience.
Music that employs electronic musical instruments, digital instruments and circuitry-based music technology.
Any of various political movements related to anarchism, a political philosophy that is sceptical of authority and rejects all involuntary, coercive forms of hierarchy.
Any of various archaeological cultures of Europe.
An act committed with the intent of disguising the actual source of responsibility and pinning blame on gay men.

A political movement that is a hybrid of disparate political philosophies, such as the People's Mujahedin of Iran, who mix Marxism and Islam, the Third Way, which fuses social-democratic and neoliberal elements, and Christian democracy, which combines conservative ideas with some economically centre-left policies.
Any of various archaeological cultures of Central Europe.
An act committed with the intent of disguising the actual source of responsibility and pinning blame on bisexual people.

A collective attempt by a group of people to change government policy or social values. Political movements are usually in opposition to an element of the status quo and are often associated with a certain ideology.

An archaeological culture comprising a broad archaeological horizon of Europe between c. 2900 BCE – c. 2350 BCE, thus from the late Neolithic, through the Copper Age, and ending in the early Bronze Age. Corded Ware culture encompassed a vast area, from the Rhine on the west to the Volga in the east, occupying parts of Northern Europe, Central Europe and Eastern Europe.
An offshoot of queercore punk music which focuses more specifically on gender identity and gender issues, especially as they relate to transgender people.
Any of various communities associated with the drag subculture.

A culturally specific gender role in some Madagasy cultures for persons who may contemporarily be assigned male at birth but occupy a more stereotypically feminine societal role. Sekrata are often assigned spiritual importance.

A punk music genre which is distinguished by lyrics exploring themes of prejudice and dealing with issues such as sexual identity, gender identity and the rights of the individual. more generally, queercore bands offer a critique of society endemic to their position within it, sometimes in a light-hearted way, sometimes seriously.
Sexual development and behavior in children, as influenced by social and cultural aspects.

A genre of electronic dance music characterized by a repetitive four on the floor beat and a tempo of 120 to 130 beats per minute. It was created by DJs and music producers from Chicago's underground club culture in the 1980s, as DJs from the subculture began altering disco dance tracks to give them a more mechanical beat and deeper basslines.
Art music produced or rooted in the traditions of European culture or cultures, including both liturgical (religious) and secular music.
A lesbian who is an atheist.

A stylistic movement in Western orchestral music associated with the period of the nineteenth century commonly referred to as the Romantic era (or Romantic period). It is closely related to the broader concept of Romanticism—the intellectual, artistic and literary movement that became prominent in Europe from approximately 1800 until 1910.
A bisexual person who is Buddhist.
A genre of popular music that originated in its modern form during the mid-1950s in the United States and the United Kingdom.
A female-to-male cross-dresser who performs in a glamorous manner, especially one who performs at nightclubs and other entertainment venues.
A male-to-female cross-dresser who performs in a glamorous manner, especially one who performs at nightclubs and other entertainment venues.
Stories, books, magazines, etc. for lesbians meant for the time of life between childhood and maturity.
The number of intentional homicides of LGBTQIA+ persons per given unit of population over a given period of time.
Stories, books, magazines, etc. for transgender persons meant for the time of life between childhood and maturity.
Puerto Rican persons who are LGBTQIA+.
A gender which has a certain prerequisite which may be unrelated to gender, such as one belonging to a particular culture or Indigenous group.
Any of various cultures associated with working class LGBTQIA+ persons.
The condition of being non-intersex.
Any of various cultures associated with working class lesbians.
Any of various surveys related to LGBTQIA+ persons, culture, and/or movements.
Cissexism in which it genitalia or other body parts are equated with a particular gender, usually in the form of assumptive gender attribution.
A lesbian who is Buddhist.

Vocal and instrumental music written and performed in Europe during the Medieval era. This era begins in the fifth century with the fall of the Western Roman Empire and the resultant loss of much of the literary and artistic heritage of Ancient Greece and Ancient Rome. It ends sometime in the early fifteenth century, although establishing the end of the medieval era and the beginning of the Renaissance music era is difficult, since the trends started at different times in different regions.
A term used to describe a person who displays visible aspects of gender variance, evidenced by their appearance or actions, among other things.
A gay man who is Buddhist.
Generally, music from the Medieval era and the Renaissance era.
Stories, books, magazines, etc. for bisexual persons meant for the time of life between childhood and maturity.
A Puerto Rican person who is a lesbian.
A pronoun set composed of hu, hum, hus, and huself.
Stories, books, magazines, etc. for gay men meant for the time of life between childhood and maturity.

Vocal and instrumental music written and performed in Europe during the Renaissance era. Consensus among music historians has been to start the era around 1400, with the end of the medieval era, and to close it around 1600, with the beginning of the Baroque period, therefore commencing the musical Renaissance about a hundred years after the beginning of the Renaissance as it is understood in other disciplines.

A language that is marginalized, persecuted or banned. Language minoritization stems from the desire of large nations to establish a common language for commerce and government, or to establish homogeneity for ideological reasons.
A pronoun set composed of hu, hum, hus, and humself.
Music considered to be of high aesthetic value.
An actor in pornographic films who is a gay man.
Music with wide appeal that is typically distributed to large audiences through the music industry.
A type of cosplay (costume play) in which the person dresses up as a character of a different gender.

An activity and performance art in which participants called cosplayers wear costumes and fashion accessories to represent a specific character. Cosplayers often interact to create a subculture, and a broader use of the term "cosplay" applies to any costumed role-playing in venues apart from the stage.
A pronoun set composed of vi, vir, vis, virs, and virself.
A pronoun set composed of vi, vir, virs, and virself.
Any of various pronoun sets including vi, vir, and vis.
Police officers who are LGBTQIA+.

A music genre and musical form which was originated in the Deep South of the United States around the 1870s by African-Americans from roots in African musical traditions, African-American work songs, and spirituals. Blues incorporated spirituals, work songs, field hollers, shouts, chants, and rhymed simple narrative ballads.
A term used in Niue to describe an identity similar to the Samoan fa'afafine, i.e. persons who are assigned male at birth who take on a more traditionally feminine gender role.
A lesbian who is a police officer.

A music genre that originated in the African-American communities of New Orleans, United States in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, with its roots in blues and ragtime. Since the 1920s Jazz Age, it has been recognized as a major form of musical expression in traditional and popular music, linked by the common bonds of African-American and European-American musical parentage. Jazz is characterized by swing and blue notes, call and response vocals, polyrhythms and improvisation. Jazz has roots in West African cultural and musical expression, and in African-American music traditions.
A Tok Pisin term used recently to refer to the traditional gender identity/role observed in Papua New Guinea.
A bisexual person who is an atheist.

A period or style of Western art music composed from approximately 1600 to 1750. This era followed the Renaissance music era, and was followed in turn by the Classical era, with the galant style marking the transition between Baroque and Classical eras. The Baroque period is divided into three major phases: early, middle, and late. Overlapping in time, they are conventionally dated from 1580 to 1650, from 1630 to 1700, and from 1680 to 1750.
A term used in Fiji to describe an identity similar to the Samoan fa'afafine, i.e. persons who are assigned male at birth who take on a more traditionally feminine gender role.
A transgender person who is an atheist.
Music created during the Classical period of music history, spanning from 1750 to 1820.
Any of various pronoun sets including ve, ver, veirself.
An actor in pornographic films who is a lesbian.

A category of rock music that emerged from the independent music underground of the 1970s and became widely popular in the 1990s. "Alternative" refers to the genre's distinction from mainstream or commercial rock or pop music. The term's original meaning was broader, referring to a generation of musicians unified by their collective debt to either the musical style or simply the independent, DIY ethos of punk rock, which in the late 1970s laid the groundwork for alternative music.
A costumed gender performance which plays with or parodies traditional gender roles, perceptions and issues by intentionally presenting a confusing gender expression.
Any of various pronoun sets including ve, ver, and verself.
An actor in pornographic films who is transgender.

A broad genre of popular music that originated as "rock and roll" in the United States in the late 1940s and early 1950s, developing into a range of different styles in the mid-1960s and later, particularly in the United States and the United Kingdom. It has its roots in 1940s and 1950s rock and roll, a style which drew heavily from the genres of blues, rhythm and blues, and from country music. Rock music also drew strongly from a number of other genres such as electric blues and folk, and incorporated influences from jazz, classical, and other musical styles.
Crossplay in which a person who is male dresses as a character who is female.
A pronoun set composed of voi, void, voids, and voidself.
Poets who are LGBTQIA+.
A punk rock music genre and subculture that originated in the late 1970s. It is generally faster, harder, and more aggressive than other forms of punk rock.
Crossplay in which a person who is female dresses as a character who is male.
A pronoun set composed of voi, void, voids, and voidself.
A gay man who is an author.

A music genre that emerged in the mid-1970s. Rooted in 1960s garage rock, punk bands rejected the perceived excesses of mainstream 1970s rock. They typically produced short, fast-paced songs with hard-edged melodies and singing styles, stripped-down instrumentation, and often political, anti-establishment lyrics. Punk embraces a DIY ethic. many bands self-produce recordings and distribute them through independent record labels.
A pronoun set composed of vi, vir, vis, and vimself.
A gay man who is an atheist.
A film award related to LGBTQIA+ persons or culture.
A name applied to an ethnic group which has been created by another group of people.
A television award related to LGBTQIA+ persons or culture.
A name applied to a given ethnic group.
A literary award related to LGBTQIA+ persons or culture.

The name of one or more imaginary character(s) created by a writer to write in different styles. Heteronyms differ from pen names in that the latter are just false names, while the former are characters that have their own supposed physiques, biographies, and writing styles.
A pornographic film award related to LGBTQIA+ persons or culture.
A name applied to an ethnic group which has been created and is used by those belonging to that ethnic group.

A word that identifies a group of people (inhabitants, residents, natives) in relation to a particular place. Demonyms are usually derived from the name of the place (village, city, region, province, state, continent). Demonyms are used to designate all people (general population) of a particular place, regardless of ethnic, linguistic, religious or other cultural differences that may exist within the population of that place.
Feelings of discomfort or distress related to an individual’s gender identity in relationship to their hormonal and/or biochemical makeup.
A name used for professional purposes by a professional wrestler, martial artist or boxer.
Feelings of discomfort or distress related to an individual’s gender identity in relationship to their sexual characteristics.
A pronoun set composed of they/them and she/her pronouns, in which they/them pronouns are typically (but not always) prioritized.

The name given to a set of religious beliefs and practices originating in the ancient Greek and Hellenistic world, as well as from the Thracians, associated with literature ascribed to the mythical poet Orpheus, who descended into the Greek underworld and returned. Orphics revered Dionysus (who once descended into the Underworld and returned) and Persephone (who annually descended into the Underworld for a season and then returned). Orphism has been described as a reform of the earlier Dionysian religion, involving a re-interpretation or re-reading of the myth of Dionysus and a re-ordering of Hesiod's Theogony, based in part on pre-Socratic philosophy.
A pronoun set composed of he/him and they/them pronouns, in which he/him pronouns are typically (but not always) prioritized.
Social activism against transgender persons and communities including, most prominently, the opposition to legal rights for transgender persons and communities.
A pronoun set composed of she/her and they/them pronouns, in which she/her pronouns are typically (but not always) prioritized.
Literary festivals focused on LGBTQ culture and/or persons.
Any of various parts of a personal name derived from a person's father's name.
Social activism against LGBTQIA+ persons and communities including, most prominently, the opposition to legal rights for LGBTQIA+ persons and communities.
An anatomical entity composed of labia majus which have been fused or sealed together.
A large dance party attended primarily by gay men. similar to a rave, but with a music selection more closely tied to gay male culture.
Any of various parts of a personal name derived from a person's mother's name.

A type of trolling or harassment that consists of pursuing people with persistent requests for evidence or repeated questions, while maintaining a pretense of civility and sincerity. It may take the form of "incessant, bad-faith invitations to engage in debate".
A labia majus which is larger than what is considered "normal".
Dance parties originating in the 1940s and 1950s where LGBTQIA+ persons could socialize.
The name (or names) used by monarchs and popes during their reigns and, subsequently, historically.
Attraction toward elderly women.
A labia majus which is smaller than what is considered "normal".
Music festivals focused on LGBTQ culture and/or persons.
Any of various parts of a personal name derived from a person's child's name.
Attraction towards young women. alternatively, attraction toward young virgin women.
An extremely rare and relatively subjective condition in which the genital labia majora are said to be larger than what may be considered "normal".
An extremely rare and relatively subjective condition in which the genital labia minora are said to be larger than what may be considered "normal".
Fear or hatred of masculine women. fear or hatred of butch people.
An extremely rare and relatively subjective condition in which the genital labia are said to be larger than what may be considered "normal".

A movement which supports divesting funds from, or abolition of, police departments (and often police structures generally) and reallocating them to non-policing forms of public safety and community support, such as social services, youth services, housing, education, healthcare and other community resources.
Any of various personal names deriving from the name(s) of the land(s) or other properties an individual owns. For instance, Marquis de Lafayette owned the land of Lafayette.
Any of various cultures associated with working class gay men.
Any of various surveys related to transgender persons, culture, and/or movements.
A luchador (male wrestler) who fights and performs in drag.

The order of individual parts of a personal name when arranged as a full name. The order "given name, family name" is typically called the "Western name order" while the order "family name, given name" is usually called the "Eastern name order".
Pornographic magazines produced for an LGBTQIA+ audience.
A system describing the choice of personal name in a certain society. Personal names consists of one or more parts, such as given name, surname and patronymic.
An honor or reward striven for in a competitive contest. anything offered to be competed for, or as an inducement to, or reward of, effort.
The "real" name (typically meaning the legal name) of a person who uses a pseudonym.
Abnormal communication most commonly seen between two internal organs, or between an internal organ and the surface of the body.
Intersectional activism or engagement with feminism and feminist ideologies on the internet.
Something given to a recipient as a token of recognition of excellence in a certain field.
A personal name which is made up of multiple parts (such as a given name and a family name) as opposed to a mononym.
Activism or engagement with feminism and feminist ideologies on the internet, usually used in relationship to hashtag activism.
Awards related to the LGBTQIA+ community, LGBTQIA+ persons, and other LGBTQIA+ topic areas.
An individual's unique set of traceable digital activities, actions, contributions and communications manifested on the internet or digital devices.
A kind of questionnaire which elucidates aspects of a person's gender identity and/or one's relationship to their gender identity.
Digital entity which consists of a maximum number of some instances of discontinuous members of the same class.
Pornographic magazines produced for a gay male audience.
Any of various parts of a personal name derived from the name of a person's clan. alternatively, the name of the clan itself.
Pornographic magazines produced for a lesbian audience.
Any of various parts of a personal name derived from a person's grandfather's name.
A form of tourism marketed to LGBTQIA+ people.
A personal name is which is a singular name, not split into parts, as opposed to a polynym. Examples of mononymous persons include Molière, Napoleon, and Björk.
A parent or parents that are nonbinary.
A form of tourism marketed to transgender people.
Any of various names used for individual human beings (personal names) or groups of human beings.
A gay man who is Christian.
A block of text which has been copied and pasted from somewhere else.
A member of the clergy who is bisexual.
A member of the clergy who is transgender.
