Laws regarding human trafficking for the purpose of sexual exploitation, including sexual slavery.
Laws regarding the transmission of or exposure to sexually transmitted infections (STIs).
A glossary of terms related to asexuality and/or asexual culture.
Laws related to the legal rights afforded to victims of crime.
A party held in order to "repeal" a transgender person's sex assigned at birth and celebrate their gender identity.
Laws related to individual rights, the rights of an individual.
A party whose primary purpose is to give gifts to the guest of honor.
Laws related to the propagation of free and, in many cases, compulsory education.
A glossary of terms related to medicine.
Laws related to the economic, social and cultural right to adequate housing and shelter.
Parties specific to the transgender community and transgender people.
Laws permitting, prohibiting, restricting, or otherwise regulating the availability of and types of abortion services.
Affection without any limitations, or love without conditions. This term is sometimes associated with other terms such as true altruism or complete love.
Any and all criminal laws regarding sex, sexual acts, sexual practices, sexual paraphernalia, and the results of these things.
Love touted as unconditional, but potentially dependent on one's status or identity, for example, if one is gay or transgender.
Laws which refer to the rights of a group or collective of persons.

A celebration during which parents, friends and family find out the sex of a baby. This has become possible with the increasing accuracy of various technologies of determining the baby's sex before birth. It is a relatively new phenomenon and distinct from a baby shower, which is a gift-giving ceremony.
Laws which protect against or aim to combat discrimination.
A party of gift-giving or a ceremony that has different names in different cultures. It celebrates the delivery or expected birth of a child or the transformation of a woman into a mother.
Laws regarding particular types of sexual activity.

The use or threatened use of force or violence against persons based on their gender identity, role, and/or expression in violation of criminal laws for purposes of intimidation, coercion, or ransom, in support of political or social objectives.
A mode of sexual selection in which members of one biological sex compete with members of the same sex for access to members of the opposite sex.
A mode of sexual selection in which members of one biological sex choose mates of the other sex to mate with.
A feeling of affection shared between two or more organisms.

An individual's production of offspring per breeding event or lifetime. This is not limited by the number of offspring produced by one individual, but also the reproductive success of these offspring themselves.
A perception of mutual closeness that allows for sharing of personal feelings and demonstration of caring.
A feeling of close familiarity and mutual affection shared between two or more organisms.
Heightened urges of sexual desires in preparation for sexual behavior.
An expression of mutual affection which includes sensual proximity.
The alleged unconscious desire of a woman to possess a penis.
The sentiment of desiring feminine breasts.
Human penile-vaginal penetration in which no viable contraceptive methods are in place.
Human penile-vaginal penetration in which a viable contraceptive method or methods are in place.
Sexual intercourse without the use of precautions to prevent conception or the transmission of sexually transmitted diseases.
Sexual intercourse in which at least one participant utilizes a condom.
Any type of penetrative intercourse in which a condom is not used.
Human penile-vaginal penetration in which a condom is used.

A concept used to examine the attribution of fixed, intrinsic, innate qualities to women and men. In this theory, there are certain universal, innate, biologically- or psychologically-based features of gender (different from sex) that are at the root of observed differences in the behavior of men and women.
The theoretic counterpart to penis envy. the alleged unconscious desire of a man to possess a vagina.
Polygyny in which male animals gather in competitive displays and the "winner" or "winners" mate with multiple females.
The state of conjugating gametes that are different in size, structure and function. anisogamy.
Any of the various mechanisms by which the fusion of two gametes to form a zygote occurs.
A form of anisogamy (heterogamy) in which the female gamete (e.g. ovum) is significantly larger than the male gamete (sperm) and is non-motile.
A form of sexual reproduction involving gametes of similar morphology.
The process by which organism populations change over successive generations that is influenced by gene mutation and natural selection.
The process of cumulative change over successive generations through which organisms acquire their distinguishing morphological and physiological characteristics.
Biological processes involved in maintaining, expressing, and transmitting from one organism to another, genetically encoded traits.

The differential survival and reproduction of individuals due to differences in phenotype. It is a key mechanism of evolution, the change in the heritable traits characteristic of a population over generations.
Processes involved in the phenomenon of biological evolution.

A mode of natural selection where members of one biological sex choose mates of the other sex to mate with (intersexual selection), and compete with members of the same sex for access to members of the opposite sex (intrasexual selection).
Laws regarding exposure to, or transmission of, the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).
Laws regarding the classification of sexual harassment, its criminal treatment, and other aspects surrounding its occurrence.
Laws which discriminate against particular groups or collectives of individuals.
Laws which infringe upon the rights of, or discriminate against, LGBTQIA+ persons.
Laws related to LGBTQIA+ rights.
Laws related to transgender rights.

The common name for proposed legislation that defines access to public toilets by gender (restrooms)—or for transgender individuals. Bathroom bills affect access to sex-segregated public facilities for an individual based on a determination of their sex as defined in some specific way—such as their sex as assigned at birth, their sex as listed on their birth certificate, or the sex that corresponds to their gender identity.
Sexual intercourse with the use of precautions to prevent conception or the transmission of sexually transmitted diseases.
Laws which infringe upon the rights of, or discriminate against, transgender persons.
Laws which infringe upon the rights of, or discriminate against, gay persons.
The struggle for agency or power in society between persons of differing ethnicities or ethnic groups.
The struggle for agency or power in society between multiple cultures.
The struggle for agency or power in society between different roles.
The struggle for agency or power in society between different generations.
Riots in which race played a major factor.
Acts of violence committed by or against political constituencies.
Riots related to the LGBTQIA+ community and LGBTQIA+ people.
A refusal of obedience or order. It refers to the open resistance against the orders of an established authority.

A philosophy of education and social movement that developed and applied concepts from critical theory and related traditions to the field of education and the study of culture. It insists that issues of social justice and democracy are not distinct from acts of teaching and learning. The goal of critical pedagogy is emancipation from oppression through an awakening of the critical consciousness, based on the Portuguese term conscientização. When achieved, critical consciousness encourages individuals to effect change in their world through social critique and political action in order to self-actualize.
Any of various theories related to education.

Archaeology which employs a feminist perspective in interpreting past societies. It often focuses on gender, but also considers gender in tandem with other factors, such as sexuality, race, or class. Feminist archaeology has critiqued the uncritical application of modern, Eurocentric norms and values to past societies. It is additionally concerned with increasing the representation of women in the discipline of archaeology, and reducing androcentric bias within the field.

A category of dances that have a social function and context. Social dances are intended for participation rather than performance and can be led and followed with relative ease. They are often danced merely to socialise and for entertainment, though they may have ceremonial, competitive and erotic functions.

Any of various dances whose basic choreography involves coordinated dancing of two partners, as opposed to individuals dancing alone or individually in a non-coordinated manner, and as opposed to groups of people dancing simultaneously in a coordinated manner.
In the broadest sense, any of various recreatoinal dances with a partner. The International School and the American School designate specific dances as ballroom dances.

A partner dance and social dance that originated in the 1880s along the Río de la Plata, the natural border between Argentina and Uruguay. It was born in the impoverished port areas of these countries, in neighborhoods which had predominantly African descendants. The tango is the result of a combination of Rioplatense Candombe celebrations, Spanish-Cuban Habanera, and Argentinean Milonga. The tango was frequently practiced in the brothels and bars of ports, where business owners employed bands to entertain their patrons with music. The tango then spread to the rest of the world. Many variations of this dance currently exist around the world.

A social dance originating at the end of the 19th century in the suburbs of Buenos Aires and Montevideo. It has continued to grow in popularity and spread internationally, adding modern elements without replacing the older ones. Among its leading figures are the singer and songwriter Carlos Gardel and composers/performers Francisco Canaro, Juan D'Arienzo, Carlos Di Sarli, Osvaldo Pugliese, and Ástor Piazzolla.
A form of Argentine tango without regard to the traditional heteronormative roles of the dancers, and often to exchange the leader and follower roles.
Any of various headcanons which involve LGBTQIA+ elements or characters, confirmed or theorized.

Any of various philosophies which examine the goals, forms, methods, and meaning of education. The term is used to describe both fundamental philosophical analysis of these themes and the description or analysis of particular pedagogical approaches. Considerations of how the profession relates to broader philosophical or sociocultural contexts may be included.
What some organ, tissue, cell or biomolecule does or the reason why some process or system evolved in the context of selective pressures.
The alleged unconscious desire of a man to possess a womb.
Intellectual processes which allow for knowledge acquisition.
A psychological function.
Hostilities between different groups either inter-group or intra-group in nature.
Conflict between persons with some kind of interpersonal relationship.
Conflict between two or more members of the same group or team.

The struggle for agency or power in society. Social conflict occurs when two or more actors oppose each other in social interaction, each exerts social power with reciprocity in an effort to achieve incompatible goals whilst preventing the other from attaining their own.
Deliberate and planned acts of unlawful behavior engaged in by aggrieved segments of the population in seeking social change.
An approach to archaeology that uses queer theory to challenge normative, and especially heteronormative, views of the past.
Victims of murder who are LGBTQIA+.

A field of critical theory, inspired by queer theory and bisexual politics, that foregrounds bisexuality as both a theoretical focus and as an epistemology. Bisexual theory emerged most prominently in the 1990s, in response to the burgeoning queer studies movement, employing a similar post-structuralist approach but redressing queer theory’s tendency towards bisexual erasure.

An academic discipline that examines the meaning, nature, and consequences of disability. Initially, the field focused on the division between "impairment" and "disability", where impairment was an impairment of an individual's mind or body, while disability was considered a social construct.
Any of various theories considered by philosophical aesthetics.

An intellectual stance, mode of discourse, and philosophy defined by an attitude of skepticism toward what it considers as the grand narratives and ideologies of modernism, as well as opposition to epistemic certainty and the stability of meaning. Claims to objective fact are dismissed as naive realism. Postmodernism is characterized by self-referentiality, epistemological, moral relativism, pluralism, irony, irreverence, and eclecticism. it rejects the "universal validity" of binary oppositions, stable identity, hierarchy, and categorization.

A term for philosophical and literary forms of theory that both build upon and reject ideas established by structuralism, the intellectual project that preceded it. Though post-structuralists all present different critiques of structuralism, common themes among them include the rejection of the self-sufficiency of structuralism, as well as an interrogation of the binary oppositions that constitute its structures. Accordingly, post-structuralism discards the idea of interpreting media (or the world) within pre-established, socially constructed structures.

The use of social and political power to dictate how some people may live and how some must die. The deployment of necropolitics creates what Mbembe calls deathworlds, or "new and unique forms of social existence in which vast populations are subjected to living conditions that confer upon them the status of the living dead." Achille Mbembe, author of On the Postcolony, was the first scholar to explore the term in depth in his 2003 article, and later, his 2019 book of the same name. Mbembe identifies racism as a prime driver of necropolitics, stating that racialized people's lives are systemically cheapened and habituated to loss.

The study of veganism, within the humanities and social sciences, as an identity and ideology, and the exploration of its depiction in literature, the arts, popular culture, and the media. In a narrower use of the term, vegan studies seeks to establish veganism as a "mode of thinking and writing" and a "means of critique".
Any of various behaviors which contradict gender norms or as seen as "wrong" ways to do gender, in a given context.
Conflict within a marriage. conflict between married partners.
A form of violent crowd behavior which expresses the emotional release of resentments and prejudices, usually relevant to grievances toward the social system.
Events specific to the gay male community and gay men.
Events specific to the lesbian community and lesbians.
Events specific to the intersex community and intersex people.
Events specific to the transgender community and transgender people.
Meetings, protests, parties, etc., organized by a group of people for a particular purpose.
Events specific to the asexual community and asexual people.
A pronoun set composed of ze, zem, zer, zers, and zemself.
Any of various pronoun sets including ze, zem, and zirself.
Any of various pronoun sets including ze, zem, and zemself.
A pronoun set composed of xey, xem, xer, xers, and xemself.
Any of various pronoun sets including vi, vim, and vimself.
A pronoun set composed of vi, vim, vir, virs, and virself.
A pronoun set composed of vi, vim, vims, and vimself.
A pronoun set composed of vi, vim, vir, virs, and vimself.
A pronoun set composed of ze, zem, zir, zirs, and zemself.
Organizations primarily for gay people or which otherwise support gay people.
A pronoun set composed of ze, zem, zyr, zyrs, and zemself.
Any of various historical organizations founded for and by self-proclaimed homophiles, itself an historical term to refer to gay people.
A pronoun set composed of ze, zem, zems, and zemself.
Footwear which covers the foot, ankle, and at least some part of the lower calf.
When two or more people come together to discuss one or more topics, often in a formal or business setting, but meetings also occur in a variety of other environments.
An event of ritual significance, performed on a special occasion.
An event for researchers (not necessarily academics) to present and discuss their work.
Conferences pertaining primarily to medical topics.
The ceremony during which graduation occurs.

Collective behavior is a type of social behavior that occurs in crowds or masses. Riots, mobs, mass hysteria, fads, fashions, rumor, and public opinion are all examples of collective behavior. It is argued that people tend to surrender their individuality and moral judgment in crowds and give in to the hypnotic powers of leaders who shape crowd behavior as they like.
A social behavior that involves the coordinated behavior of large groups of similar animals as well as emergent properties of these groups.
Large public gatherings, marches, etc., organized for non-violent protest or affirmation in support of civil rights issues.
Large public gatherings, marches, etc., organized for non-violent protest or affirmation, even though incidental disturbances or incipient rioting may occur.
Large public gatherings, marches, etc., organized for non-violent protest or affirmation in support of LGBTQ civil rights issues.
A pronoun set composed of vi, ver, vers, and verself.

The theory and practice of learning, and how this process influences, and is influenced by, the social, political and psychological development of learners. Pedagogy, taken as an academic discipline, is the study of how knowledge and skills are imparted in an educational context, and it considers the interactions that take place during learning. Both the theory and practice of pedagogy vary greatly, as they reflect different social, political, and cultural contexts.
A pronoun set composed of vi, ver, vers, and virself.

An academic discipline devoted to exploring the intersection between queer theory and critical pedagogy, which are both grounded in critical theory. It is also noted for challenging the so-called "compulsory cisheterosexual and normative structures, practices, and curricula" that marginalize or oppress non-heterosexual and non-cisgender students and teachers.
The branch of biology concerned with the relations between organisms and their environment.

An ecological perspective which views nature, biology, and sexuality through the lens of queer theory. It objects to what it considers heterosexist notions of nature, drawing from science studies, ecofeminism, environmental justice, and queer geography. This perspective breaks apart various "dualisms" that exist within human understanding of nature and culture.

An identification string that defines a realm of administrative autonomy, authority or control within the internet. Domain names are used in various networking contexts and for application-specific naming and addressing purposes. In general, a domain name identifies a network domain, or it represents an internet Protocol (IP) resource, such as a personal computer used to access the internet, a server computer hosting a website, or the web site itself or any other service communicated via the internet.

One of the domains at the highest level in the hierarchical Domain Name System of the internet after the root domain. The top-level domain names are installed in the root zone of the name space. For all domains in lower levels, it is the last part of the domain name, that is, the last non empty label of a fully qualified domain name. For example, in the domain name www.example.com., the top-level domain is com. Responsibility for management of most top-level domains is delegated to specific organizations by the ICANN an Internet multi-stakeholder community, which operates the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA), and is in charge of maintaining the DNS root zone.
Events specific to the bisexual community and bisexual people.
Events pertaining to or about the LGBTQ community.
Events pertaining to or focused on men.
Events pertaining to or focused on gender identity.
Festivals focused on LGBTQ culture.
Events pertaining to or focused on women.
Any of various pronoun sets including vi and vir.
A pronoun set composed of s/he, hir, hirs, hirself.
A pronoun set composed of cy, cyr, cyrs, and cyrself.
A neopronoun derived from the word "person".
A pronoun set composed of ne, nir, nirs, and nirself.
A pronoun set composed of ne, nir, nirs, and nemself.
A sex classification based on absence and/or presence of internal organs.
Traditionally, a criminal behavior of high seriousness, whereas a misdemeanor is regarded as less serious.

A sex classification based on absence and/or presence of various organs. note that such a classification may be limiting as a precise "hierarchy" of organs is not typically possible (for instance, does presence of a prostate "outrank" presence of a vagina or presence of breasts?). It is recommended to simply add presence/absence data to a more appropriate area unless directly relevant.

term: person previously convicted of a crime
comment: A person who had previously been convicted of a crime. i.e. an individual who has been convicted of a crime, but has been released from or has otherwise been deemed to have served an appropriate sentence related to that crime.
A person's gender as represented or recognized in any of various administrative systems.
A person who has been convicted of a crime which they did not commit.
A sex classification based on absence and/or presence of externally visible organs.
A person who was convicted of a crime and then was later officially declared innocent of that same crime.
A pronoun set composed of zhe, zher, zhers, and zherself.

Any of various rules and aphorisms loosely connected by virtue of being codes of conduct or conventions related to the Internet. The original collection of rules, in the formalized sense, began on the 4chan image board.
A pronoun set composed of vi, vim, vis, vims, and vimself.
A type of linguistic prescription which intends to emphasize personhood above a particular characteristic or diagnosis, describing what a person "has" rather than asserting what a person "is".
One of the "rules of the internet" which speculates that "[i]f it exists, there is porn of it. No exceptions."
Conferences specific to the LGBTQ community and LGBTQ people.
Parties specific to the LGBTQ community and LGBTQ people.
Parades specific to the LGBTQ community and LGBTQ people.
An organized, extended presentation of films in one or more cinemas or screening venues, usually in a single city or region.

Sex as observed from any of various types of clinical imaging, such as x-rays or ultrasounds. Note that this can be unclear depending on the vagueness of the criteria outlined and/or the type of imaging utilized.
Events which occur in a fiction.

term: Black and Indigenous people of color
comment: A grouping of Black persons, Indigenous persons, and people of color which emphasizes common experiences of marginalization and discrimination, while also calling to mind shared histories of imperialization and colonization.
Planned events usually involving large groups of persons, oftentimes arranged by organizations.
A gathering of individuals who meet at an arranged place and time in order to discuss or engage in some common interest.
A gathering of people who have been invited by a host for the purposes of socializing, conversation, recreation, or as part of a festival or other commemoration of a special occasion.
A debate is an event wherein opposing arguments are put forward to argue for opposing viewpoints as a formalized type of discussion.

A procession of people, usually organized along a street, often in costume, and often accompanied by marching bands, floats, or sometimes large balloons. Parades are held for a wide range of reasons, but are usually celebrations of some kind.
A pronoun set composed of se, sim, sis, and sisself.
A pronoun set composed of se, sim, sis, and simself.
A pronoun set composed of xe, xem, xyr, xyrs, and xyrself.
A pronoun set composed of ze, zem, zir, zirs, and zirself.
A pronoun set composed of ze, zem, zeir, zeirs, and zemself.
A pronoun set composed of ze, zem, zes, and zirself.
A part of the Black Lives Matter movement which specifically advocates for Black trans people (especially Black trans women) and fights for racial equity and Black liberation.
A neopronoun derived from the word "fae", or related terms such as "fay" and "fey".

A decentralized political and social movement advocating for non-violent civil disobedience in protest against incidents of police brutality and all racially motivated violence against Black people. The broader movement and its related organizations typically advocate against police violence towards Black people, as well as for various other policy changes considered to be related to Black liberation.
A neopronoun derived from the word "void".
A neopronoun derived from the word "human".
A pronoun set composed of zie, zem, zes, and zirself.
A sexual attraction toward aliens.

The hue of the long-wave end of the visible spectrum, evoked in the human observer by radiant energy with wavelengths of approximately 630 to 750 nanometers. any of a group of colors that may vary in lightness and saturation and whose hue resembles that of blood.
Conferences primarily focused on cultural topics.

Any of various events related to aspects of culture (museum exhibitions, fashion shows, etc.), particular cultures (Greek festivals, Christian feast celebrations, etc.), or particular subcultures (LGBTQ parades, African-American festivals, etc.).
Events pertaining to given aspects of the arts.
An event ordinarily celebrated by a community and centering on some characteristic aspect of that community and its religion or cultures.
Events pertaining to given aspects of sexuality, sexuality in general, gender identity, and/or gender expression.
Events pertaining to given aspects of music.
A certificate provided for persons who "live in another gender" by the Gender Recognition Panel tribunal in the United Kingdom, and some similar systems in other countries.
The leather culture as it exists in the gay male community.
The leather culture as it exists in the LGBTQIA+ community.
A pronoun set composed of ze, mer, zer, zers, and zerself.
A pronoun set composed of ze, mer, zer, zers, and zemself.
A pronoun set composed of co, cos, and coself.
A pronoun set composed of co, cos, co's, and coself.
Actors in pornographic films who are LGBTQIA+.
A musician who plays a musical instrument.
A pronoun set composed of vi, vim, vims, and vimself.
Clergy who are LGBTQIA+.
A type of religious violence where terrorism is used as a tactic to achieve religious goals or which are influenced by religious identity.
A pronoun set composed of ve, ver, vis, and verself.
Fashion designers who are LGBTQIA+.
A percussionist who creates music using drums.

A social movement which opposes what is referred to as "gender ideology", a term which does not have a coherent definition. Individuals belonging to the movement typically oppose the distinction between sex and gender, oppose the ability for transgender persons (especially children) to access appropriate medical care, oppose discussion of gender theory and studies in schools, and oftentimes hold other relatively conservative views, such as opposing same-sex marriage. The movement derives from Catholic theology beginning in the 1990s, but the protests which brought the movement to attention did not start until around 2012–2013.
A pronoun set composed of ve, ver, vis, vers, and verself.
Journalists who are LGBTQIA+.
A musician who plays any of various percussion instruments.
Conspiracy theories related to LGBTQIA+ persons.
Physicians who are LGBTQIA+.
Film festivals focused on lesbian culture and/or lesbians.
The leather culture as it exists in the deaf community.
Scientists who are LGBTQIA+.
Any of various relationship types considered abusive.
The leather culture as it exists in the lesbian community.
Writers who are LGBTQIA+.
The use of intentional violence for political or religious purposes.
Novelists who are LGBTQIA+.
Noble persons who are LGBTQIA+.
An actor in pornographic films who is bisexual
A female percussionist who creates music using drums.
Events pertaining to or focused on cross-dressing.
Events pertaining to or focused on gender expression.
Events pertaining to or focused on sexuality or some aspect of sexuality.
A behavior which is intended to communicate a falsehood, typically used with the purpose of deceiving someone.
A statement or declaration which is an authentication of a fact or an attestation as to the truth of a matter.
Any of various objects or things inserted into the body.

The Internet-based practice of researching and publicly broadcasting private or identifying information (especially personally identifying information) about an individual or organization. The methods employed to acquire this information include searching publicly available databases and social media websites (like Facebook), hacking, and social engineering. It is closely related to Internet vigilantism and hacktivism.
A pronoun set composed of co, co's, and coself.
A device which is inserted into something. more generally, anything that is inserted into anything else.
Misconduct which takes place online, usually (but not always) on the internet.
Any of various pronoun sets including co, cos, and coself.
Any of various things inserted into the anal cavity or designed to be inserted into the anal cavity.
A neopronoun derived from the word "cyber".
Any of various things inserted into the genitalia or designed to be inserted into the genitalia.

A form of psychological manipulation in which the abuser denies the abuse ever took place, attacks the victim for attempting to hold the abuser accountable, and claims that they, the abuser, are actually the victim in the situation, thus reversing the reality of the victim and offender. This usually involves not just "playing the victim" but also victim blaming.
Any of various LGBTQIA+ organizations composed of and/or primarily for motorcyclists.
Events pertaining to or focused on some sexual fetish or fetishes.
Events pertaining to or focused on sexual orientation or on the sexual orientations of its participants.
Events specific to the transfeminine community and transfeminine people.
Events specific to the nonbinary community and nonbinary people.
A protest demonstration which takes the form of a parade.
Events specific to the transmasculine community and transmasculine people.
Any of various things inserted into the vagina or designed to be inserted into the vagina.
A march which addresses transgender rights, builds community, and creates transgender visibility.
A march which addresses lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and queer (LGBTQ) rights, builds community, and creates LGBTQ visibility.

A low number of circulating cells transferred from one individual to another. This often refers to fetal cells persisting in the material circulation and may play a role in the pathogenesis of autoimmune diseases.
The study of structure, function, ecology and evolution at the level of the organism.
Mosaicism occurring with brain cells.
The study of the diversification of living forms, both past and present, and the relationships among living things through time.
Gain of an entire chromosome or chromosome arm.
The study of the origin, structure, development, growth, function, genetics, and reproduction of plants.
Loss of an entire chromosome or chromosome arm.
The branch of biology dealing with the study of animals.
The branch of surgery broadly concerned with the skeletal system (bones and joints).
The condition of having additional copies of a chromosome present in a cell.
The branch of anatomy that concerns the structure and function of bones.
No copies of a chromosome in a cell or organism.
Duplication of an entire chromosome or chromosome arm.
A subdiscipline of biology that aims to understand life at a cellular and molecular level.
Variation affecting the number of chromosomes.
A branch of biology dealing with the study of the form and structure of organisms and their specific structural features.
The condition in which one chromosome of a pair is missing. In a normally diploid cell it is represented symbolically as 2N-1.
The branch of biology concerned with the study of the structure of organisms and their parts. Anatomy is a branch of natural science which deals with the structural organization of living things.
anatomic
Two copies of a chromosome in a cell or organism.
The study of the external appearance of an organism.
An academic discipline that deals with critical approaches to television.

A chromosomal condition in which a fetus has three copies of every chromosome instead of two. If this occurs in only some cells, it is called mosaic triploidy and is less severe. Most embryos with triploidy miscarry early in development.
The science that deals with the study of microorganisms, including algae, archaea, bacteria, fungi, protozoa, and viruses.
Human triploidy in which there are 69 sets of chromosomes per cell, including two X chromosomes and one Y chromosome.

The study of viral – submicroscopic, parasitic particles of genetic material contained in a protein coat – and virus-like agents. It focuses on the following aspects of viruses: their structure, classification and evolution, their ways to infect and exploit host cells for reproduction, their interaction with host organism physiology and immunity, the diseases they cause, the techniques to isolate and culture them, and their use in research and therapy.
Human triploidy in which there are 69 sets of chromosomes per cell, including one X chromosome and two Y chromosomes.
The branch and specialty of biology that studies the morphology, ecology, genetics and biochemistry of bacteria as well as many other aspects related to them.
Laser pitch tuning utilizing a CO2 (carbon dioxide) laser.
Polyploidy in which there are seven sets of chromosomes in the cell nucleus.
The branch of medical science that deals with the classification of diseases.
Any surgical procedure that results in the reconstruction of the earlobe.
The chromosomal constitution of cells, in which each type of chromosome is represented once. Symbol: N.
A branch of medicine that deals with the prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of cancer. A medical professional who practices oncology is an oncologist.
Any surgical procedure that results in the reconstruction of the auricle of the ear.
Ploidy in which there are no sets of chromosomes in the cell nucleus.
Any surgical procedure that results in the reconstruction of the external ear.
The degree of replication of the chromosome set in the karyotype.

The branch of biology concerned with the study of fungi, including their genetic and biochemical properties, their taxonomy and their use to humans as a source for tinder, traditional medicine, food, and entheogens, as well as their dangers, such as toxicity or infection.
Surgical procedures performed on parts of the auricle of the ear..
A chromosomal condition in which a fetus has four copies of every chromosome instead of two.

The study of parasites, their hosts, and the relationship between them. As a biological discipline, the scope of parasitology is not determined by the organism or environment in question but by their way of life. This means it forms a synthesis of other disciplines, and draws on techniques from fields such as cell biology, bioinformatics, biochemistry, molecular biology, immunology, genetics, evolution and ecology.
Surgical procedures performed on parts of the external ear.
Ploidy in which there is one set of chromosomes in the cell nucleus.

The scientific study of the nervous system. It is a multidisciplinary branch of biology that combines physiology, anatomy, molecular biology, developmental biology, cytology, mathematical modeling, and psychology to understand the fundamental and emergent properties of neurons and neural circuits.
Surgical procedures performed on parts of the ear.
The chromosomal constitution of cells, in which each type of chromosome is represented twice. Symbol: 2N or 2X.

The medical science, and specialty practice, concerned with all aspects of disease, but with special reference to the essential nature, causes, and development of abnormal conditions, as well as the structural and functional changes that result from the disease processes. Informally used to mean the result of such an examination.
Surgical procedures performed on any of the various laryngeal cartilages.
Any of various surgical procedures performed on the larynx.
Laser pitch tuning utilizing a KTP (potassium titanyl phosphate) laser.

An acquired uterine condition that occurs when scar tissue (adhesions) form inside the uterus and/or the cervix. It is characterized by variable scarring inside the uterine cavity, where in many cases the front and back walls of the uterus stick to one another. AS can be the cause of menstrual disturbances, infertility, and placental abnormalities. Although the first case of intrauterine adhesion was published in 1894 by Heinrich Fritsch, it was only after 54 years that a full description of Asherman syndrome was carried out by Joseph Asherman.

Apps were originally intended for productivity assistance such as email, calendar, and contact databases, but the public demand for apps caused rapid expansion into other areas such as mobile games, factory automation, GPS and location-based services, order-tracking, and ticket purchases, so that there are now millions of apps available.

Socialist feminists argue that liberation can only be achieved by working to end both the economic and cultural sources of women's oppression.

A philosophical variant of feminism. Marxist Feminism is focused on the ways in which women could be oppressed through systems of capitalism and the individual ownership of private property. According to Marxist feminists, women's liberation can only be achieved through a radical restructuring of capitalist economies, in which, they contend, much of women's labor is uncompensated.

Lesbian feminism, much like feminism, lesbian and gay studies, and queer theory, is characterized by the ideas of contestation and revision. At the same time, one of the key themes of lesbian feminism is the analysis of heterosexuality as an institution. Lesbian feminist texts work to denaturalise heterosexuality and, based on this denaturalization, to explore heterosexuality's "roots" in institutions such as patriarchy, capitalism, and colonialism. Additionally, lesbian feminism advocates lesbianism as a rational result of alienation and dissatisfaction with these institutions.

An online dating service presented through a mobile phone application, often taking advantage of a smartphone's GPS location capabilities, always on-hand presence, and easy access to digital photo galleries and mobile wallets to enhance the traditional nature of online dating.
