A service provided online or by the internet.
A service for matchmaking between potential couples, with a view toward romance and/or marriage between them.

A perspective within feminism that calls for a radical reordering of society in which male supremacy is eliminated in all social and economic contexts. Radical feminists view society as fundamentally a patriarchy in which men dominate and oppress women.
Any of many feminisms which study men and masculinity with a critical lens. alternatively, men involved in feminism or who are feminists.
Online dating services primarily used for the purposes of heterosexual dating.

A theory that feminist social science should be practiced from the standpoint of women or particular groups of women, as some scholars (such as Patricia Hill Collins and Dorothy Smith) say that they are better equipped to understand some aspects of the world.
Online dating services primarily used for the purposes of dating for gay persons.

A mix of post structuralism, postmodernism, and French feminism. The goal of postmodern feminism is to destabilize the patriarchal norms entrenched in society that have led to gender inequality. Postmodern feminists seek to accomplish this goal through rejecting essentialism, philosophy, and universal truths in favor of embracing the differences that exist amongst women to demonstrate that not all women are the same.

A company that provides specific mechanisms (generally websites or applications) for online dating through the use of Internet-connected personal computers or mobile devices. Such companies offer a wide variety of unmoderated matchmaking services, most of which are profile-based.
Feminist ideologies which incorporate ideas based on structurally intertwined relationships of gender and ethnicity.
Feminism which analyzes the structure of a gender system as a whole in relationship to the organization of society.

An underground feminist punk movement that began in the early 1990s in Washington state (particularly Olympia) and the greater Pacific Northwest. It also had origins in Washington, D.C., and spread to at least 26 countries. It is a subcultural movement that combines feminist consciousness and punk style and politics. It is often associated with third-wave feminism, which is sometimes seen as having grown out of the Riot Grrrl movement.

A framework which approaches aspects of culture from the viewpoint of socially constructured queerness, i.e. unconventional, nonnormative, or dejected aspects of gender and sexuality in a given societal context.

A framework which approaches aspects of culture from the viewpoint of socially constructured queerness, i.e. unconventional, nonnormative, or dejected aspects of gender and sexuality in a given societal context.

A framework which approaches aspects of culture from the viewpoint of socially constructured queerness, i.e. unconventional, nonnormative, or dejected aspects of gender and sexuality in a given societal context.
A crime in which an offender or perpetrator uses or threatens to use force upon a victim.
A type of movement or political ideology which seeks to increase the acceptability of characteristics of one's gender identity.
A social movement consisting of groups and organizations of men and their allies who focus on gender issues and whose activities range from self-help and support to lobbying and activism.
A loose grouping of ideologies associated with Indigenous peoples.

A Native American people originally occupying what is now the Southeastern United States (modern-day Alabama, Florida, Mississippi and Louisiana). Their Choctaw language belongs to the Muskogean language family group. Hopewell and Mississippian cultures, who lived throughout the east of the Mississippi River valley and its tributaries.
Erotic dancing in close quarters which may or may not involve sexual contact, but usually at least implies some form of sexuality.
Sex work engaged in where the client and the sex worker are separated by some physical boundary, i.e. the sex worker is exhibited to the client.
Groups of Native American tribes and First Nations peoples in North America. The modern Oceti Sakowin consist of two major divisions based on language divisions: the Dakota and Lakota.
Sex work in which someone may sporadically engage in, when and if, a particular client could potentially become available.

A related group of Indigenous peoples of the Southeastern Woodlands. Their original homelands are in what now comprises southern Tennessee, all of Alabama, western Georgia and part of northern Florida.
Sex work engaged in for the purposes of pornographic filming.

A gender or social role observed among the Lugbara. the word translates literally as "like men" and is used to refer to infertile, prepubertal and postmenopausal women as well as those who do not engage in sexual intercourse with their husbands or other men. Such non-sexuality is associated with the ability to act as a medium for spirits.
Erotic dancing in which the performer or performers gradually undress, either partially or completely, in a sexually suggestive manner.

A term used in the eastern Polynesian language Cook Islands Māori. sometimes translated as "behave(s) like a woman". Contemporarily, it may also refer to gender-variant or transgender persons, usually transgender women.

Trips organized from within the tourism sector, or from outside this sector but using its structures and networks, with the primary purpose of effecting a commercial sexual relationship by the tourist with residents at the destination
A gender category observed among the Maale people of Ethiopia. The exact meaning of the word is not known, with scholars having differing interpretations of the role's various associations.
Dancing that provides erotic entertainment and whose objective is the stimulation of erotic or sexual thoughts or actions in viewers.
A sexual activity involving application of pain or constriction to the penis and/or testicles.
A form of dancing engaged in for the purpose of crowd entertainment at nightclubs or other venues where music is played.
Primary or exclusive sexual attraction toward members of a specific age group, as with pedophilia or gerontophilia.

A cultural practice in parts of Afghanistan and Pakistan, in which some families without sons will pick a daughter to live and behave as a boy. This enables the child to behave more freely: attending school, escorting her sisters in public, and working. Bacha posh also allows the family to avoid the social stigma associated of not having any male children.
Sex tourism by men who travel intending to engage in sexual activities with one or more locals, usually female sex workers.
Sexual attraction based on attraction to partners or potential partners of a different age group.

Sex tourism by women who travel intending to engage in sexual activities with one or more locals, usually male sex workers. Female sex tourists may seek aspects of the sexual relationship not shared by male sex tourists, such as perceived romance and intimacy.
Prostitution in which the sex worker or workers are female and the client or clients are female.
Direct prostitution in which clients are passively sought in outdoor public places, such as particular street corners.
A two-spirit. a male-bodied person who has a feminine or third-gender/bigender gender role.
A two-spirit. a male-bodied person who has a feminine or third-gender/bigender gender role.
An Akimel O'odham or Tohono O'odham person who is part of a certain non-binary cultural gender role in those communities and who may, in modern times, be assigned male at birth.
Prostitution in which the sex worker or workers are female and the client or clients are male.
A two-spirit. a male-bodied person who has a feminine or third-gender/bigender gender role and is regarded as having special spiritual talents.
A two-spirit. a male-bodied person who has a feminine or third-gender/bigender gender role and is regarded as having special spiritual talents.
Prostitution in which sex workers are contacted (usually by phone) by clients and travel to mutually agreed upon premises.
A two-spirit. a male-bodied person who has a feminine gender role.
Performance of sex work streamed or otherwise sent virtually via the internet in engage for money or other material items.
A Tlingit person who is part of a certain non-binary cultural gender role in those communities and who may, in modern times, be assigned male at birth.

Direct prostitution in which clients are actively sought in venues such as clubs and hotels. alternatively prostitution in which clients actively seek out indoor areas where sex workers are present (such as brothels).
A Wappo person who is part of a certain non-binary cultural gender role in those communities and who may, in modern times, be referred to as intersex today.
Prostitution which takes place in a specified building for such practices, i.e. a brothel.
A two-spirit. a person assigned male at birth who perform tasks usually associated with women in Atsugewi culture.
Sex work taking place in places toted primarily as massage parlors.
A person assigned male at birth who occupies a feminine gender role in Takelma society.

A group of culturally related Native American tribes in the Southwestern United States, which include the Chiricahua, Jicarilla, Lipan, Mescalero, Salinero, Plains and Western Apache. Distant cousins of the Apache are the Navajo, with which they share the Southern Athabaskan languages. There are Apache communities in Oklahoma, Texas, and reservations in Arizona and New Mexico. Apache people have moved throughout the United States and elsewhere, including urban centers. The Apache Nations are politically autonomous, speak several different languages and have distinct cultures.
Types of prostitution organized by age of those prostituted.
A two-spirit or cultural gender identity. such persons are typically considered assigned female at birth but occupy mostly masculine roles.
Sex work engaged in via telephone, usually related to, but not limited to, simply describing sexual acts in great detail.
Homosexual relations in which partners are of different ages, usually in which one partner is an adolescent and the other is an adult, although this is not always the case.
Homosexual relations in which age bears no relevance and both partners play the same socially-accepted sex role as heterosexual persons of their own sex.
Homosexual relations in which each partner plays a different gender role (exemplified, for instance, in stereotypical North American lesbian butch/femme relationships).
Pederasty in ancient Greece was a socially acknowledged romantic relationship between an adult male (the erastes) and a younger male (the eromenos) usually in his teens.
Erotic love, sexually expressed or chaste, between a man and an adolescent boy.
Erotic love, sexually expressed or chaste, between a man and an adolescent boy.
Erotic love, sexually expressed or chaste, between a man and an adolescent boy.
Cretan pederasty was an archaic form of pederasty that involved the ritual kidnapping (harpagmos) of a noble boy by an adult male of the aristocratic class, with the consent of the boy's father.

Athenian pederasty entailed a formal bond between an adult man and an adolescent boy outside his immediate family, consisting of loving and often sexual relations. As an erotic and educational custom it was initially employed by the upper class as a means of teaching the young and conveying to them important cultural values, such as bravery and restraint.

A slang term in Afghanistan for a wide variety of activities involving sexual relations between older men and younger adolescent men, or boys. The practitioner is commonly called bacha baz (meaning "boy play" in Dari) or simply bach. It may include to some extent sexual slavery and child prostitution. Bacha bāzī is currently reported in various parts of Afghanistan. Force and coercion are common, and security officials state they are unable to end such practices because many of the men involved in bacha bazi-related activities are powerful and well-armed warlords.
A BDSM sexual activity involving the application of pain or pressure to a vulva or vagina, typically in the context of sadomasochism.

A Filipino identity which is considered nonnormative in terms of gender and/or sexuality. Depending on the context, such a person may also consider themselves to be gay, transgender, bisexual, or otherwise part of a cultural gender identity exclusive to the Philippines. However, the term is almost always applied to persons assigned male at birth.

A Filipino identity which is considered nonnormative in terms of gender and/or sexuality. Depending on the context, such a person may also consider themselves to be gay, transgender, bisexual, or otherwise part of a cultural gender identity exclusive to the Philippines. However, the term is almost always applied to persons assigned male at birth.
Sexual attraction toward the elderly.
A fetish involving or derived from sexual attraction to those of a certain age group or behaviors characteristic of said group, usually in the context of sexual role play.
Primary or exclusive sexual attraction to prepubescent and pubescent children by an adult.
Sexual attraction to adults.
The primary sexual attraction of adults to very young children (defined by various studies as 0–4).
Any of various disorders primarily characterized by pedohebephilia.
Primary adult sexual attraction towards late pubescent or postpubescent adolescents.
Adult sexual attraction primarily towards pubescent children.
Sexual behavior involving young adolescents or children in a sense that may be normative in the given society, such as pederasty was in ancient Greece.
A sexual preference for middle-aged adults.

term: national LGBTQ march in Washington, D.C.
comment: Any of various American national LGBTQIA+ marches taking place in the Washington, D.C.

term: national LGBTQ march in the United States
comment: Any of various national LGBTQIA+ marches taking place in the United States.
Any of various LGBTQIA+-related marches notably taking place on a national scale or stage.
A demonstration against LGBTQIA+ civil rights.
An event posed against the existence of LGBTQIA+ people.
Women who take a vow of chastity and wear male clothing in order to live as men in patriarchal Balkan society.
A woman who is accorded the status of a man without disrupting the patriarchal status quo.
Women who take a vow of chastity and wear male clothing in order to live as men in patriarchal Montenegrin society.
Women who take a vow of chastity and wear male clothing in order to live as men in patriarchal northern Albanian society.
Women who take a vow of chastity and wear male clothing in order to live as men in patriarchal northern Albanian society.
Persons who cross-dress for cultural reasons or purposes.
Persons who cross-dress for the purposes of performance.
Persons who cross-dress during wartime under various circumstances and for various motives.
Persons who cross-dress for the purposes of disguise.

Race is a characteristic of an individual defined by some culturally-defined combination of heritable phenotypic characteristics, geographic ancestry, physical appearance, ethnicity, and social status.

A grouping of humans based on shared physical or social qualities into categories generally viewed as distinct by society. The term was first used to refer to speakers of a common language and then to denote national affiliations. By the 17th century the term began to refer to physical (phenotypical) traits. Modern scholarship regards race as a social construct, an identity which is assigned based on rules made by society. While partially based on physical similarities within groups, race does not have an inherent physical or biological meaning.
A movement toward gender neutrality in language, services, and other areas of life.
The “societal-level conditions, cultural norms, and institutional practices that constrain the opportunities, resources, and wellbeing for stigmatized populations”.
The “societal-level conditions, cultural norms, and institutional practices that constrain the opportunities, resources, and wellbeing for stigmatized populations”.
Care practices which involves treatment based upon recognizing, understanding, and responded to the impact of different kinds of trauma.
Care practices which involves treatment based upon recognizing, understanding, and responded to the impact of different kinds of trauma.
Slang that is specific to, or primarily used within, the Two-Spirit community.
Any of various conditions related to personality.
The process by which a Black woman or women is made the subject of sexual obsession.
A person who is not autistic or otherwise on the autism spectrum.

The psychological phenomenon in which a body can display multiple distinct personas. This phenomenon can feature in identity disturbance, dissociative identity disorder, and other specified dissociative disorders, among other things. Some individuals describe their experience of multiplicity as a form of neurodiversity, rather than something that demands a diagnosis. In a body that contains multiple personas, a "system" may associate behavior with each persona and switch among them. Somebody who experiences multiplicity is described as a "multiple," while a person who does not experience is described as a "singlet".

One or more motions or positions of the muscles beneath the skin of the face. Facial expressions are a form of nonverbal communication. They are a primary means of conveying social information between humans, but they also occur in most other mammals and some other animal species. Humans can adopt a facial expression voluntarily or involuntarily, and the neural mechanisms responsible for controlling the expression differ in each case. Voluntary facial expressions are often socially conditioned and follow a cortical route in the brain. Conversely, involuntary facial expressions are believed to be innate and follow a subcortical route in the brain.
Any of various gestures not made primarily by the hands and arms.
A person whose plurality is related to a traumatic, or series of traumatic, experiences.
Any of various gestures made primarily by the hands and arms.
A person who is not plural.

Any media that are encoded in machine-readable formats. Digital media can be created, viewed, distributed, modified and preserved on digital electronics devices. Digital can be defined as any data represented with a series of digits, and Media refers to a method of broadcasting or communicating information together digital media refers to any information that is broadcast to us through a screen. This includes text, audio, video, and graphics that is transmitted over the internet, for viewing on the internet.
A video program produced on a regular basis, delivered over the Internet in a compressed digital format and designed for playback on computers or portable digital video players.
An audio program produced on a regular basis, delivered over the Internet in a compressed digital format and designed for playback on computers or portable digital audio players.

A person who shares the same physical body with other individuals. This is sometimes considered to be connected to the psychological phenomenon of multiplicity (also known as plurality), in which a body can display multiple distinct personas.

An interactive fiction video game genre, which originated in Japan, featuring text-based story with narrative style of literature and interactivity aided by static or sprite-based visuals, most often using anime-style art or occasionally live-action stills (and sometimes video footage). As the name might suggest, they resemble mixed-media novels. In Japanese terminology, a distinction is often made between visual novels (abbreviated NVL, derived from "novel"), which consist predominantly of narration and have very few interactive elements, and adventure games (abbreviated AVG, or ADV derived from "adventure"), which may incorporate problem-solving and other types of gameplay. This distinction is normally lost outside Japan, where both NVLs and ADVs are commonly referred to as "visual novels" by international fans.
A person who is considered to have a typical mental status or condition, or series of statuses or conditions, within the context of mental health, psychology, and socio-cultural context.

Software simulating environments in which players use text commands to control characters and influence the environment. Works in this form can be understood as literary narratives, either in the form of interactive narratives or interactive narrations. These works can also be understood as a form of video game, either in the form of an adventure game or role-playing game.
An audio or video program produced on a regular basis, delivered over the Internet in a compressed digital format and designed for playback on computers or portable digital audio players.

A style of Japanese young adult novel primarily targeting high school and middle school students. The term "light novel" is a wasei-eigo, or a Japanese term formed from words in the English language. Light novels are often called ranobe (ラノベ) or, in English, LN. The average length of a light novel is about 50,000 words, close to the minimum expected for a Western novel, and light novels are usually published in bunkobon size (A6, 10.5 cm × 14.8 cm), often with dense publishing schedules. A distinguishing characteristic of light novels is that they are illustrated with a manga art style and are often adapted into manga and anime. They are mainly published in separate book volumes, while some of them have their chapters serialized in anthology magazines before being collected in book form, similar to how manga is published.
A video game in which the player assumes the role of a protagonist in an interactive story driven by exploration and puzzle-solving.
The belief that gender is exclusively derived from genetic or other biological entities.
The belief that gender is entirely a social artifact and exclusively socially constructed.

Any of various conspiracy theories which involve misinformation about the COVID-19 virus and pandemic, including those concerning the origin, prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of COVID-19-related illnesses.
The philosophical idea that certain entities are entirely social artifacts and exclusively socially constructed.
False or misleading information that is spread deliberately to deceive.
False, inaccurate, or misleading information that is communicated regardless of an intention to deceive.

A digital asset designed to work as a medium of exchange wherein individual coin ownership records are stored in a ledger existing in a form of a computerized database using strong cryptography to secure transaction records, to control the creation of additional coins, and to verify the transfer of coin ownership.
A family with children that is headed by a single parent in which at least one of the family members is LGBTQIA+.
The categorization of a person's body frame into small, medium and large based on the measurement of wrist circumference or the breadth of the elbow.

The false belief that COVID-19 does not exist, or that some aspect of the diseases it causes or the widespread nature of the COVID-19 pandemic has been exaggerated or fabricated by the medical community or world governments.
The adoption of LGBTQ children, adolescents, or adults.
A family in which at least one parent is bisexual.
Any of various measurements of a body.
Denial of the medical consensus.
The adoption of children by LGBTQ people.
A family in which the parents are a gay male couple.
The weight of a human or any of various parts of a human.
An adolescent person who is intersex.
A family in which the parents are a lesbian couple.
The height of a human or any of various parts of a human.
The process through which individuals are disaffirmed in their gender identity, under the assumption that that identity is pathological in nature.
The physical measurements of a body shortly after birth.
A family with children that is headed by a single parent.
A birth weight that is less than 1,000 g (2 lb 3 oz).
Slang often used in the drag community.
A family in which at least one parent is transgender.
The weight of a human body.
A family comprised of drag performers led by a drag parent (commonly labeled as a drag mother or drag father).
The height of a human body.
A less experienced drag performer who is adopted by and is mentored and guided by a more experience drag performer, their drag parent (more often referred to as their drag mother or drag father).
The birth of a human being.
A more experienced drag performer who adopts and acts as the mentor and guide to other drag performers, known as their drag children.
The weight of an infant.
Any item or verifiable record that is generally accepted as payment for goods and services and repayment of debts, such as taxes, in a particular country or socio-economic context.
A term in economics referring to any item that is widely acceptable in exchange for goods and services.
The ratio of the lengths of different digits or fingers.

Any of a set of negative attitudes, often performative in nature, that individuals have toward heterosexuality, usually surrounding regret, embarassment, or hopelessness in relationship to the heterosexual experience. These attitudes typically center around oftentimes ridiculous clarifications around heterosexual performativity, and are usually commented on by LGBTQIA+ persons noting "Are straight people OK?".
Any of various ratios between anatomical entities.
Mental attitude that interprets life events as generally being positive.
One who practices, or is licensed to practice, electrolysis.
Mental attitude that interprets life events as generally being negative.
A person whose occupation is to cut or style hair in order to change or maintain a person's image.

The magnitude or dimensions of a thing. More specifically, geometrical size (or spatial size) can refer to linear dimensions (length, width, height, diameter, perimeter), area, or volume. Size can also be measured in terms of mass, especially when assuming a density range.
Any currency that is primarily managed, stored or exchanged on digital computer systems, especially over the internet.
Deficiency in the type 2 isozyme of 5α-reductase.
Any of various measurements which involve geometric components.
The most specific sense is money in any form when in use or circulation as a medium of exchange, especially circulating banknotes and coins.
Deficiency in the type 1 isozyme of 5α-reductase.
A measure of size for any of various animals.
A digit ratio calculated by dividing the length of the index finger of a given hand by the length of the ring finger of the same hand.
A measure of size for any of various organisms.
A birth weight that is less than 1,500 g (3 lb 5 oz).

The size of a human penis, based on any of various measures, including length and circumference when flaccid and erect. Besides the natural variability of human penises in general, there are factors that lead to minor variations in a particular male, such as the level of arousal, time of day, room temperature, and frequency of sexual activity. Compared to other primates, including large examples such as the gorilla, the human penis is thickest, both in absolute terms and relative to the rest of the body.
A measure of size for humans.
A birth weight of a infant of 2,499 g (5 lb 8.1 oz) or less, regardless of gestational age, as defined by the World Health Organization (WHO).
The physical measurements of a body.
An intersex person who is pregnant.
A nonbinary person who is pregnant.
Social conflicts which involve differences in ideologies, typically political in nature.
A man who is pregnant.

Derived from the eponymous male-male romance manga magazine first published in 1978, the term was originally used to describe works that resembled the art style of manga published in that magazine. It has also been used to describe amateur works depicting male homosexuality that are original creations and not derivative works. By the 1990s, the term had largely fallen out of use in favor of "boys' love". it has been suggested that publishers wishing to get a foothold in the June market coined "boys' love" to disassociate the genre from the publisher of June.

Derived from the eponymous male-male romance manga magazine first published in 1978, the term was originally used to describe works that resembled the art style of manga published in that magazine. It has also been used to describe amateur works depicting male homosexuality that are original creations and not derivative works. By the 1990s, the term had largely fallen out of use in favor of "boys' love". it has been suggested that publishers wishing to get a foothold in the June market coined "boys' love" to disassociate the genre from the publisher of June.
A woman who is pregnant.

A subgenre that focuses on the worship of beauty, and on romance between older men and beautiful youths. Tanbi as a term and concept predates male-male romance manga that emerged in the 1970s, having originated to describe prose fiction depicting homosexuality by authors such as Yukio Mishima, Yasunari Kawabata, and Jun'ichirō Tanizaki. Tanbi works are typically defined by their poetic prose and unusual kanji, such as Chinese characters appropriated into Japanese script.

A subgenre that focuses on the worship of beauty, and on romance between older men and beautiful youths. Tanbi as a term and concept predates male-male romance manga that emerged in the 1970s, having originated to describe prose fiction depicting homosexuality by authors such as Yukio Mishima, Yasunari Kawabata, and Jun'ichirō Tanizaki. Tanbi works are typically defined by their poetic prose and unusual kanji, such as Chinese characters appropriated into Japanese script.
A person who is pregnant.

A genre of literature and other fictional media originating from China which features romantic relationships between male characters. Danmei is typically created by, and targeted towards a heterosexual female audience. While danmei works and their adaptations have achieved widespread popularity in China and globally, their legal status remains murky due to Chinese censorship policies.

A genre of literature and other fictional media originating from China which features romantic relationships between male characters. Danmei is typically created by, and targeted towards a heterosexual female audience. While danmei works and their adaptations have achieved widespread popularity in China and globally, their legal status remains murky due to Chinese censorship policies.
Any of various terminology related to LGBTQIA+ people or identities.
A blog related to LGBTQIA+ persons, subjects, and/or culture.
The process of intentionally giving birth without the assistance of a medical birth attendant.
A nonbinary person who can give birth, who is giving birth, or who has given birth.
A book related to LGBTQIA+ persons, subjects, and/or culture.
Natural birth in which the person giving birth has a completely free range of movement (not being confined to a bed, for instance) during labor and the birthing process.
A man who can give birth, who is giving birth, or who has given birth.
Social conflicts which involve differences in transgender-related ideologies, typically somewhat political in nature.
Censorship of any of various kinds of LGBTQ material.
Birth when a fetus is between 34 weeks and 0 days through 36 weeks and 6 days gestational age.
A woman who can give birth, who is giving birth, or who has given birth.
Social conflicts which involve differences in LGBTQ-related ideologies, typically somewhat political in nature.
A person who has multiple racial and/or ethnic backgrounds.
Birth when a fetus is less than 28 weeks gestational age.
A person who can give birth, who is giving birth, or who has given birth.
Social activism and advocacy of and for fat persons, which aims to elimate the social stigma surrounding fatness.

A legal cause of action in some common law countries in which the parents of a congenitally diseased child claim that their doctor failed to properly warn of their risk of conceiving or giving birth to a child with serious genetic or congenital abnormalities. Thus, the plaintiffs claim, the defendant prevented them from making a truly informed decision as to whether or not to have the child. Wrongful birth is a type of medical malpractice tort. It is distinguished from wrongful life, in which the child sues the doctor.
An umbrella term for people who can get pregnant and/or give birth.
Biological parents who are LGBTQIA+.

A birth that takes place in a residence rather than in a hospital or a birthing center. They may be attended by a midwife, or lay attendant with experience in managing home births. Home birth was, until the advent of modern medicine, the de facto method of delivery. The term was coined in the middle of the 19th century as births began to take place in hospitals. Since the beginning of the 20th century, home birth rates have fallen in most developed countries, generally to less than 1% of all births.
Social conflicts which involve differences in feminist ideologies, typically somewhat political in nature.
Censorship of any of various kinds of books.

The birth of an infant in places or situations other than what was planned. In most cases the location of childbirth is planned ahead of time and may be at home, a hospital, a medical facility or a birthing center. In other situations, the birth occurs on the way to these facilities. Oftentimes, no trained medical personnel are present, other times there may be police or other first responders. Emergency measures for delivery are indicated when childbirth is imminent.
Censorship of any of various kinds of LGBTQ books.

The expulsion of a nonviable fetus through the vaginal opening of the decomposing body of a deceased pregnant woman as a result of the increasing pressure of intra-abdominal gases. This kind of postmortem delivery occurs very rarely during the decomposition of a body. The practice of chemical preservation, whereby chemical preservatives and disinfectant solutions are pumped into a body to replace natural body fluids (and the bacteria that reside therein), have made the occurrence of "coffin birth" so rare that the topic is rarely mentioned in medical discourse.
A person who has two racial and/or ethnic backgrounds.
Birth when a fetus is between 32 weeks and less than 37 weeks gestational age.
LGBTQIA+ persons who have two racial and/or ethnic backgrounds.
Birth when a fetus is between 28 weeks and less than 32 weeks gestational age.

An internet group primarily used to describe any form of synchronous conferencing, occasionally even asynchronous conferencing. The term can thus mean any technology ranging from real-time online chat and online interaction with strangers (e.g., online forums) to fully immersive graphical social environments.
The adoption of transgender adults.
The adoption of intersex adults.
The adoption of children by transgender people.
The adoption of children by intersex people.
The adoption of LGBTQ youth.
The adoption of LGBTQ adults.
Biological parenthood in which a parent is LGBTQIA+.
Childbirth before 37 weeks of pregnancy (259 days from the first day of the mother's last menstrual period, or 245 days after fertilization).
Do-it-yourself gender affirming surgery typically undertaken as a result of extreme gatekeeping of gender transition procedures and/or processes.

A form of reclaimed Latine queer identity, derived from the slur "patería" (in turn derived from the slur "pato", akin to the English "faggot"). Specifically reclaimed among Puerto Rican queer people.
The state of being an foster parent.
The event that a fetus is born dead or stillborn.

A fetus of at least 20 weeks gestation, or of a birth weight of at least 350 grams if the gestational age is unknown, that is born without signs of life at the time of delivery, and with an Apgar score of zero at both one and five minutes.
Do-it-yourself transgender hormone replacement therapy typically undertaken as a result of extreme gatekeeping of gender transition procedures and/or processes.

A form of reclaimed Latine queer identity, derived from the slur "jotería" (in turn derived from the slur "joto", akin to the English "faggot"). Specifically reclaimed among Mexican and Chicane queer people.
Foster parenthood in which a parent is LGBTQIA+.
Multiple fetuses birthed live or dead in a single pregnancy regardless of gestational age, and regardless of whether the fetuses were birthed on different dates.
Do-it-yourself gender transition typically undertaken as a result of extreme gatekeeping of gender transition procedures and/or processes.
A blending of the terms "queer" and "Black", referring to the unique intersecting experiences of queer Black identity.
Adoptive parents who are LGBTQIA+.
Any birth that occurs spontaneously prior to 37 weeks of gestation, e.g. due to fetal membrane rupture or spontaneous onset of uterine contractions.
spontaneous preterm birth
Preterm birth from 20 weeks to 36 weeks, 6 days of gestation associated with one of the following: classic preterm labor or preterm premature rupture of membranes.
The adoption of transgender youth.

Human parturition which occurs when a fetus, whatever its gestational age, exits the maternal body and subsequently shows any sign of life, such as voluntary movement, heartbeat, or pulsation of the umbilical cord, for however brief a time and regardless of whether the umbilical cord or placenta are intact.
The adoption of intersex youth.
A chosen family that has bonded together through leather culture and lifestyle.
The number of maternal deaths in a population divided by the number of women of reproductive age, usually expressed per 1,000 women.
Adoptive parenthood in which a parent is LGBTQIA+.

Defined by the World Health Organization as "the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of the pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes."
Art pertaining to, or including parts which relate to, LGBTQIA+ culture, persons, or the LGBTQIA+ community.
Spontaneous labor and birth at term without the use of pharmacologic and/or mechanical interventions for labor stimulation or pain management throughout labor and birth.
Art associated with a particular subculture.
Birth at greater than or equal to 42 weeks and 0 days.
Censorship of any of various kinds of art.
Censorship of any of various kinds of LGBTQ art.

Labor and sometimes delivery that occurs in water, usually a birthing pool. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists does not recommend birthing in water as the safety has not been determined. Proponents believe childbirth in water results in a more relaxed, less painful experience that promotes a midwife-led model of care. Critics argue that the safety of waterbirth has not been scientifically proven and that a wide range of adverse neonatal outcomes have been documented, including increased mother or child infections and the possibility of infant drowning.

The study of the ethical issues emerging from advances in biology and medicine. It is also moral discernment as it relates to medical policy and practice. Bioethics are concerned with the ethical questions that arise in the relationships among life sciences, biotechnology, medicine and medical ethics, politics, law, theology and philosophy.
Someone who shares in the parenting of a child or children.
Someone who shares in the parenting of a child or children.
The killing or assassination of a tyrant or unjust ruler, usually for the common good, and usually by one of the tyrant's subjects.

Having a gender identity which varies sporadically over time. Sometimes "gendergas" is used to refer to persons who have somewhat tenuous relationship with gender and the variance is less male or female and more demiboy or demigirl.
Having a gender identity which does not vary over time in any sense.

A term describing the purchasing power of the LGBTQIA+ community, often especially with respect to political donations. With the rise of the gay rights movement, pink money has gone from being a fringe or marginalized market to a thriving industry in many parts of the Western world such as the United States and United Kingdom. Many businesses now specifically cater to gay customers, including nightclubs, shops, restaurants, and even taxicabs. the demand for these services stems from common discrimination by traditional businesses.

A rarely used classification system (usually used in a joking manner) to describe one's relationship to their gender via one of the states of matter (being built around the present terminology of genderfluid and adding "gendersolid", "gendergas", etc.).

An assisted reproductive technique involving two individuals who produce oocytes. The method uses in vitro fertilization (IVF), a method that means eggs are removed from the ovaries, fertilized in a laboratory, and then one or more of the resulting embryos are placed in the uterus to hopefully create a pregnancy. Reciprocal IVF differs from standard IVF in that two partners are involved: the eggs are taken from one partner, and the other partner carries the pregnancy.
A nonbinary person who is infertile.

A form of assisted reproduction involving two partners who produce oocytes. The method uses in vitro fertilization (IVF), a method that means eggs are removed from the ovaries, fertilized in a laboratory, and then one or more of the resulting embryos are placed in the uterus to hopefully create a pregnancy.
Any of various conditions or statuses related to the number of chromosomal features or entities.
A publication featuring an art form using a single image or a series of static images in fixed sequence.
Any of various religions originating on the Indian subcontinent.
Surgical reconstructions of the thyroid cartilage.
Mosaicism involving a particular cell or cells.
A sequence of drawings arranged in interrelated panels to display brief humor or form a narrative, often serialized, with text in balloons and captions.
Any of various religions originating in East Asia.
A syndrome which occurs due to a 48,XXY,+21.
Mosaicism involving a particular chromosome or chromosomes.
A comic strip related to LGBTQIA+ persons, subjects, and/or culture.
Any of various religions originating in the Americas.
A syndrome which occurs due to a 45,X/47,XY,+21 or 46,X,+21/47,XX,+21 karyotype.
Mosaicism involving a particular gene or genes.
Comics published on a website or mobile application.
Any of various religions originating in Africa (or via African diaspora).
A media campaign that aims to increase public awareness of transgender civil and human rights issues.

The votes cast by gays and lesbians, and is typically considered a voting bloc. Most prevalent in Britain, the concept has already spread to United States, where gays and lesbians are substantially more likely to vote Democratic, and Canada with many other countries like South Africa and Australia starting to acknowledge it. The pink vote is now well-established across countries in Western Europe with gay and lesbian voters being notably more inclined to vote for social democratic parties over right-wing parties and to be far more supportive of EU integration. In addition, there are socio-political movements and political groups formed by LGBTQIA+ people who are linked to political parties.
An aneuploidy of the autosome.
LGBTQIA+ persons who share in the parenting of a child or children.
A belief or behavior that is passed from generation to generation in a family, a culture, or a religion.
A formal indication of a choice of a candidate or candidates or courses of action, expressed typically through a ballot or a show of hands or by voice.

A condition in which some spermatozoa are aneuploid. Risk of sperm aneuploidy is increased by tobacco smoking, occupational exposure to benzene, insecticides, and perfluroinated compounds, among other things.
The state of being a coparent.
Frequent repetition of the same behavior. way of behavior common to many. ordinary manner. habitual practice. method of doing, living or behaving.
A formal group decision-making process by which a population chooses an individual or multiple individuals to hold public office.
A numerical chromosomal condition characterized by the presence of copy number variations in less than five percent of chromosomal arms.
Coparenthood in which the coparent is LGBTQIA+.
Any of various religions originating in the Middle East.

A syndrome caused by a chromosomal deletion larger than 5 million base pairs (5 Mb) spanning several genes that is large enough to be detected by conventional cytogenetic methods or high resolution karyotyping (2–5 Mb).
The amount of goods and services that can be purchased with a unit of currency.
The state of a cell or organism having more than two paired (homologous) sets of chromosomes.
A publication that consists of comics art in the form of sequential juxtaposed panels that represent individual scenes.
An inherited, established or customary religious practice or series of beliefs.

A statistic about an economic activity. Economic indicators allow analysis of economic performance and predictions of future performance. One application of economic indicators is the study of business cycles.
A type of genetic mosaicism where more than one set of genetic information is found specifically within the gamete cells.
A webcomic related to LGBTQIA+ persons, subjects, and/or culture.

The presence of genetically distinct populations of somatic cells in a given organism caused by DNA mutations, epigenetic alterations of DNA, chromosomal conditions or the spontaneous reversion of inherited mutations.
Preterm birth from 20 weeks to 36 weeks, and 6 days of gestation that is necessitated by the medical condition of the mother or fetus.
Inequality based upon digital information access or use, among other things.
A parent who lactates.

Pseudoscientific and highly discriminatory devices which claim to use artificial intellilgence to determine sexual orientation. Such models are often built upon junk science, relying on biological essentialism and discriminatory stereotypes.
A parent who is nongestational.

A device developed in Canada by Frank Robert Wake in the 1950s that was supposed to be able to identify gay men (derogatorily referred to as "fruits"). The subjects were made to view pornography. the device then measured the diameter of the pupils of the eyes (pupillary response test), perspiration, and pulse for a supposed erotic response.
A parent who is gestational.
A hypothetical (and extremely degrading and discriminatory) device which claims to be able to detect the sexual orientation of an individual.
An intersex person who can give birth, who is giving birth, or who has given birth.
A chromosomal condition in that is characterized by an addition of chromosomes that results in a chromosome number that is not an exact multiple of the haploid number.
A person who makes a donation.
A person who makes a donation.

Any of various languages that use the visual-manual modality to convey meaning. Sign languages are expressed through manual articulations in combination with non-manual elements. Sign languages are full-fledged natural languages with their own grammar and lexicon. Sign languages are not universal and they are not mutually intelligible with each other, although there are also striking similarities among sign languages.
A man who is infertile.
Reproduction made possible via any of various assisted reproductive techniques.
A chromosomal condition in which a somatic cell is missing a single member of one or more pairs of homologous chromosomes.
A person who donates any of various medical resources, usually organs, cells, or tissues.
The social stigma associated with mental health, mental health services, mental health conditions, and mental health issues/conditions.
A woman who is infertile.

A term referring to intimate relationships between partners of the same gender, known as aikāne, in pre-colonial Hawaiʻi. These relationships were particularly cherished by aliʻi nui (chiefs) and the male and female kaukaualiʻi performing a hana lawelawe or expected service with no stigma attached.
A chromosomal condition in which the chromosomal number is greater than the normal diploid number.
A person who donates blood for use in transfusion.
Any of various cultures or subcultures defined by disability in any of its various forms and/or having members who have a disability or disabilities.
A person who is infertile.

Pseudoscientific and highly discriminatory devices which claim to use artificial intellilgence to determine gender identity. Such models are often built upon junk science, relying on biological essentialism and discriminatory stereotypes.
A chromosomal condition in which the chromosomal number is greater than the normal triploid number.
A person who donates sperm, usually anonymously, to a sperm bank or fertility clinic.
A person who donates sperm, usually anonymously, to a sperm bank or fertility clinic.

A gestural communication system, often invented spontaneously by a deaf child who lacks accessible linguistic input. Home sign systems often arise in families where a deaf child is raised by hearing parents and is isolated from the deaf community. Because the deaf child does not receive signed or spoken language input, these children are referred to as linguistic isolates.

Pseudoscientific and highly discriminatory devices which claim to use artificial intellilgence to determine gender modality (such as being transgender or cisgender). Such models are often built upon junk science, relying on biological essentialism and discriminatory stereotypes.
Internet chat groups related to the LGBTQIA+ community or any of its various subcommunities.
Process of idea or image formation.
Gender biases coded into technology products, technology sector and digital skills education.
A hypothetical (and extremely degrading and discriminatory) device which claims to be able to detect the gender modality of an individual (such as being cisgender or transgender).
Any of various conditions or statuses related to chromosomal features or entities.
Internet chat groups related to the lesbian community or any of its various subcommunities.
Birth at greater than or equal to 37 weeks using best estimated due date.
The gap between those able to benefit from the digital age and those who are not.
A hypothetical (and extremely degrading and discriminatory) device which claims to be able to detect the gender identity of an individual.

A syndrome caused by a chromosomal deletion smaller than 5 million base pairs (5 Mb) spanning several genes that is too small to be detected by conventional cytogenetic methods or high resolution karyotyping (2–5 Mb). Detection is done by fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH). Larger chromosomal deletion syndromes are detectable using karyotyping techniques.
A book that is requested to be removed from a library or other area as a form of book censorship.
A thought or patterns of thought in which an individual generates a specific idea regarding their own suicide.
Any and all devices related to gender identity, modality, or activities.

The chromosomal constitution of cells which deviate from the normal by the addition or subtraction of chromosomes, chromosome pairs, or chromosome fragments. In a normally diploid cell (diploidy) the loss of a chromosome pair is termed nullisomy (symbol: 2N-2), the loss of a single chromosome is monosomy (symbol: 2N-1), the addition of a chromosome pair is tetrasomy (symbol: 2N+2), the addition of a single chromosome is trisomy (symbol: 2N+1).
A LGBTQ book that is requested to be removed from a library or other area as a form of book censorship.
A thought or patterns of thought in which an individual generates a specific idea regarding their killing someone else (committing a homicide).
A chromosomal condition in which the chromosomal number is less than the normal diploid number.
Blood donors who are LGBTQIA+.
A chromosomal condition in which the chromosomal number is less than the normal triploid number.
A person who donates oocytes (eggs) to a fertility clinic.

The set of social beliefs, behaviors, art, literary traditions, history, values, and shared institutions of communities that are influenced by deafness and which use sign languages as the main means of communication.
An aneuploidy of the allosome.
Belief in multiple deities, which are usually assembled into a pantheon of gods and goddesses, along with their own religions and rituals.

A branch of medicine dealing with disorders of the nervous system. Neurology deals with the diagnosis and treatment of all categories of conditions and disease involving the central and peripheral nervous systems (and their subdivisions, the autonomic and somatic nervous systems), including their coverings, blood vessels, and all effector tissue, such as muscle.
Belief in one god.
Polyploidy in which there are seven sets of chromosomes in the cell nucleus.
The medical specialty that deals with male health, particularly relating to the problems of the male reproductive system and urological problems that are unique to men.

The view that the existence of a god or gods, of the divine or the supernatural is unknown or unknowable. Another definition provided is the view that "human reason is incapable of providing sufficient rational grounds to justify either the belief that God exists or the belief that God does not exist."
Polyploidy in which there are eight sets of chromosomes in the cell nucleus.
A medical specialty concerned with the skin, its structure, functions, diseases, and treatment.

In the broadest sense, an absence of belief in the existence of deities. Less broadly, atheism is a rejection of the belief that any deities exist. In an even narrower sense, atheism is specifically the position that there are no deities.

term: medialization thyroplasty with arytenoid adduction, fixation technique
comment: A combination thyroplasty performed for the purpose of medial vocal cord fixation.

term: medialization thyroplasty with arytenoid adduction, rotation technique
comment: A combination thyroplasty performed for the purpose of medialization of the entire vocal cord (anterior and posterior).
Triploidies observed in humans.

An academic discipline that deals with processes of human communication and behavior, patterns of communication in interpersonal relationships, social interactions and communication in different cultures.
Usage of lasers to tighen up the vocal cords in order to raise vocal pitch.
Human triploidy in which there are 69 sets of chromosomes per cell, including three X chromosomes.
A discipline and field of study that deals with the content, history, and effects of various media. in particular, the mass media.
Any of various vocal cord surgeries which utilize lasers.
Human tetraploidy in which there are 92 sets of chromosomes per cell in a person considered genetically female.
An academic discipline that deals with various theoretical, historical, and critical approaches to films.
A form of reduction glottoplasty in which the vocal cord length is shortened.
Human tetraploidy in which there are 92 sets of chromosomes per cell in a person considered genetically male.

A procedure in which microlaryngoscopy (a surgical procedure that looks at the vocal folds in great detail) is done in conjunction with a carbon dioxide (CO2) laser that vaporizes small portions of the vocal folds. When the vocal fold tissue is in the process of healing and scarring, the vocal folds decrease in mass and increase in stiffness. This results in a rise in vocal pitch.
Polyploidy in which there are ten sets of chromosomes in the cell nucleus.
Statistical interpretation and description of a population with reference to distribution, composition, or structure.
A surgery in which raising in vocal pitch is achieved by shortening the vibrating length of the vocal cords.
Polyploidy in which there are twelve sets of chromosomes in the cell nucleus.

The study and application of beauty treatment. Branches of specialty include hairstyling, skin care, cosmetics, manicures/pedicures, non-permanent hair removal such as waxing and sugaring, and permanent hair removal processes such as electrology and intense pulsed light (IPL).
A procedure which involves using a CO2 laser to vaporize the anterior part of the vocal folds. Then the vocal folds are tensed with sutures, causing the pitch to increase.
Polyploidy which occurs in some tissues of animals that are otherwise diploid.
A subfield of cosmetology focused on utilizing electrolysis for permanant hair removal.
Reconstructive vocal cord surgeries in which the vocal fold length or vocal cord mass is reduced.
Tetraploidies observed in humans.
The study and analysis of the distribution (who, when, and where), patterns and determinants of health and disease conditions in defined populations.
Any surgical procedure that results in the reconstruction of the vocal cords.
Feelings of discomfort or distress related to an individual’s gender identity in relationship to their vocal pitch or timbre (or other characteristics of one's voice).
Any of various religions originating in Oceania.
A comic publication related to LGBTQIA+ persons, subjects, and/or culture.

The collection of beliefs, rituals, and mythology originating in ancient Greece in the form of both popular public religion and cult practices. These groups varied enough for it to be possible to speak of Greek religions or "cults" in the plural, though most of them shared similarities.
Mosaicism involving the allosome.
A graphic novel related to LGBTQIA+ persons, subjects, and/or culture.
Any of various religions originating in ancient Greece and ancient Rome, as well as their Hellenistic descendants.

A surgical procedure used in conditions like adductor spasmodic dysphonia (a condition in which there is distortion of the voice due to excessively tight closure of the glottis on phonation). Generally, lateralization thyroplasty is intended to prevent this tight closure of the glottis at the terminal stage of phonation by lateralizing the position of the vocal cord. During this procedure, an incision is made at midline of the thyroid cartilage. A silicon wedge is used to fix the incised thyroid cartilage in the newly abducted position.
A type of thyroplasty in which a rectangular portion of the thyroid cartilage is mobilized and pushed towards the medial side using a piece of silastic block of proper shape under local anesthesia.

A phonosurgical technique designed to improve the voice by altering the thyroid cartilage of the larynx (the voice box), which houses the vocal cords in order to change the position or the length of the vocal cords.
A genetic mosaic in which some cells are 47,XXY and others are 46,XY.

A book made up of comics content. Although the word "novel" normally refers to long fictional works, the term "graphic novel" is applied broadly and includes fiction, non-fiction, and anthologized work. It is distinguished from the term "comic book", which is generally used for comics periodicals.
Any of a range of both religious and nonreligious attitudes characterized by the absence of espoused belief in a god or gods.
A type of combination thyroplasty in which the main aim is the relaxation of both vocal cords.
Polyploidy in which there are three sets of chromosomes in the cell nucleus.
A comic publication related to gay men, gay male subjects, and/or gay male culture.
A system of beliefs. a set of principles which form the basis of a religion, philosophy, or moral code.
A type of combination thyroplasty in which the main aim is the medialization of both vocal cords.
Polyploidy in which there are four sets of chromosomes in the cell nucleus.

A branch of medicine that deals with the disorders of the heart as well as some parts of the circulatory system. The field includes medical diagnosis and treatment of congenital heart defects, coronary artery disease, heart failure, valvular heart disease and electrophysiology. Physicians who specialize in this field of medicine are called cardiologists, a specialty of internal medicine.
A combination thyroplasty with the main aim being the relaxation and increased mass of one vocal cord.
Polyploidy in which there are five sets of chromosomes in the cell nucleus.

The branch of medicine focused on the digestive system and its disorders. Diseases affecting the gastrointestinal tract, which include the organs from mouth into anus, along the alimentary canal, are the focus of this speciality. Physicians practicing in this field are called gastroenterologists.
Belief in the existence of a supreme being or deities.
A combination thyroplasty performed with the purpose of stretching of the vocal cord with medialization of the affected side.
Mosaicism involving the autosome.
A pornographic comic related to LGBTQIA+ persons, subjects, and/or culture.
Performance of a religious act one or more times.
A medialization thyroplasty (type 1 thyroplasty) performed alongside arytenoid adduction.
A genetic mosaic in which some cells are 45,X and others are 46,XX.
A pornographic comic related to gay men, gay male subjects, and/or gay male culture.

The ancestral ethnic religion of the city of Rome that the Romans used to define themselves as a people, as well as the religious practices of peoples brought under Roman rule, in so far as they became widely followed in Rome and Italy. The Romans thought of themselves as highly religious, and attributed their success as a world power to their collective piety (pietas) in maintaining good relations with the gods. The Romans are known for the great number of deities they honored, a capacity that earned the mockery of early Christian polemicists.
Any of various thyroplasties which combine aspects of other types of thyroplasties.
A genetic mosaic in which some cells are 45,X and others are 46,XY.
A comic publication related to transgender persons, subjects, and/or culture.
A belief which derives from religious ideas, ideas about religion, or considers ideas about supernatural beings or divine intervention.
A type of thyroplasty performed to elevate vocal pitch. This procedure consists of lengthening of the thyroid cartilage. It includes cricothyroid approximation.
A genetic mosaic in which some cells are 46,XXY and others are 46,XX.
A comic publication related to lesbians, lesbian subjects, and/or lesbian culture.

Philosophical thinking that is inspired and directed by a particular religion. It can be done objectively, but may also be done as a persuasion tool by believers in that faith. It is particularly interested in the nature and existence of God, or gods, or the divine.
A procedure performed in order to lower the vocal pitch by shortening the thyroid ala. It is performed by antero-posterior shortening of the thyroid ala.
Polyploidy in which there are six sets of chromosomes in the cell nucleus.
Mystery fiction pertaining especially to LGBTQIA+ persons and/or culture.
A sub-class of determiners which modify a noun by attributing possession (or other sense of belonging) to someone or something.
Detective fiction pertaining especially to LGBTQIA+ persons and/or culture.
A term that is not an adjective but serves the same purpose, as "so" in "It is less so than we had expected".
Genre fiction pertaining especially to LGBTQIA+ persons and/or culture.
A transgender person who identifies as a gender within a given binary gender system or as binary (i.e. trans men identifying as men and trans women identifying as women).
Drama pertaining to, or including parts which relate to, a specific subculture.

Physiologic period, characterized by endocrine, somatic, and psychic changes with the termination of ovarian function in the female. It may also accompany the normal diminution of sexual activity in the male.
Any of various personal narratives by transgender persons.
Drama pertaining especially to transgender persons and/or culture.
A surgical removal performed primarily with a cutting instrument.
A person whose occupation involves performing striptease in a public adult entertainment venue such as a strip club.
A surgical process involving something being removed.
Removal of the breast, pectoral muscles, axillary lymph nodes, and associated skin and subcutaneous tissue.

The removal of a neoplasm as well as some of the breast tissue around the tumor and the lining over the chest muscles below the neoplasm. Usually some of the lymph nodes under the arm are also taken out.
Drama pertaining especially to LGBTQIA+ persons and/or culture.
A language in which pronouns cannot be omitted, even when they are pragmatically or grammatically inferable.
Surgery to remove the part of the breast.
Drama pertaining especially to lesbians and/or lesbian culture.
A language in which certain classes of pronouns may be omitted when they are pragmatically or grammatically inferable.
The national economic policy of conquering a country to exploit its population as labour and its natural resources as raw material.
Drama pertaining especially to gay men and/or gay male culture.
The process by which a nonbinary person or people is made the subject of sexual obsession.

A form of colonialism that seeks to replace the original population of the colonized territory with a new society of settlers. As with all forms of colonialism, it is based on exogenous domination, typically organized or supported by an imperial authority. Settler colonialism is enacted by a variety of means ranging from violent depopulation of the previous inhabitants to more subtle, legal means such as assimilation or recognition of Indigenous identity within a colonial framework.
Drama pertaining especially to bisexual persons and/or culture.
A language whose grammar permits an independent clause to lack an explicit subject. such a clause is then said to have a null subject.
A personal name declared by a court order.
A mosaic karyotype in which some cells are 46,XX and some are 46,XY.
Fiction pertaining especially to transgender persons and/or culture.

An extremely rare karyotype resulting from two errors: (1) a prezygotic error which created a 45,X zygote, and (2) an endoreduplication of the chromosomes resulting in a tetraploidy of the autosomes and diploidy of the sex chromosomes.
Speculative fiction pertaining especially to LGBTQIA+ persons and/or culture.
A mosaic karyotype in which some cells are 46,XX and some are 69,XXX.

A genre of fan fiction that focuses on romantic or sexual relationships between fictional characters of the same sex. While the term "slash" originally only referred to stories where male characters were involved in an explicit sexual relationship as a primary plot element (also known as "m/m slash"), it is now used to refer to any fan story containing a pairing between same-sex characters. Many fans distinguish female-focused slash as a separate genre, commonly referred to as femslash (also known as "f/f slash" or "femmeslash").

A type of mosaicism in which some cells with three copies of each chromosome for a total of 69 chromosomes (called triploid cells) and some cells with the usual 2 copies of each chromosome for a total of 46 chromosomes (called diploid cells).
Any of various subcultures associated primarily with Twitter.

A collection of websites, blogs, and online forums promoting masculinity, strong opposition to feminism, and misogyny. Movements within the manosphere include the men's rights movement, incels (involuntary celibates), Men Going Their Own Way (MGTOW), pick-up artists (PUA), and fathers' rights groups.
A subgenre of crime fiction and mystery fiction in which an investigator or a detective—either professional, amateur or retired—investigates a crime, often murder.
Any of various personal narratives by LGBTQIA+ persons.
A genre of speculative fiction set in a fictional universe, often inspired by real world myth and folklore.

A law (or bill) which originates from a non-legislative organization, which is then sent to multiple legislatures, often with little to no change in language. Such laws often originate from corporations or non-governmental organizations (NGOs) which push particular agendas (such is the case with anti-abortion groups, far-right groups, etc.).
Fantasy fiction pertaining especially to LGBTQIA+ persons and/or culture.
An individual who is a victim of sex trafficking.
An individual who is a victim of human trafficking.

A subgenre of slash fan fiction which focuses on romantic and/or sexual relationships between female fictional characters. Typically, characters featured in femslash are heterosexual in the canon universe. however, similar fan fiction about lesbian or bisexual female characters is commonly labeled as femslash for convenience.
A mosaic karyotype in which some cells are 46,X and some are 90,XX.
A person who is a victim of some form of exploitation.
Fiction pertaining especially to asexual persons and/or culture.
A chromosomal condition in which a fetus has three copies of every chromosome in some cells and two copies of every chromosome in others.

Originally referred to the metaphysical space made of up possible interpretations of words' meanings based on language and context. Today, the term "logosphere" is often used to refer to "the sum-total of ideas, concepts and facts that inhabit the collective texts — digital, printed, handwritten, carved or otherwise — of the human race", therefore the logosphere is a subspace of the infosphere.
Science fiction pertaining especially to LGBTQIA+ persons and/or culture.
An asexual person is a lesbian.
The part of the physical environment that is made up of technological objects manufactured by humans.

A genre of fiction usually involving a mysterious death, crime, or other mysterious circumstance to be solved. Often with a closed circle of suspects, each suspect is usually provided with a credible motive and a reasonable opportunity for committing the crime.
A nonbinary person who identifies as a lesbian.

The part of the environment that is made or modified by humans for use in human activities and human habitats. The anthroposphere can be viewed as a human-generated equivalent to the biosphere. While the biosphere is the total biomass of the Earth and its interaction with its systems, the anthroposphere is the total mass of human-generated systems and materials, including the human population, and its interaction with the Earth's systems. However, while the biosphere is able to efficiently produce and recycle materials through processes like photosynthesis and decomposition, the anthroposphere is highly inefficient at sustaining itself.

A loose subculture of internet humor dedicated to publication of humorous material on Twitter that is disorganized and hard to explain. Related to anti-humor and created primarily by Twitter users who are not professional humorists, Weird Twitter-style jokes may be presented as disorganized thoughts, rather than in a conventional joke format or punctuated sentence structure. Related accounts include originators such as dril and, more tangentially, authors such as poet Patricia Lockwood.
A person belonging to any of various Indigenous peoples of South America.

term: Indigenous person of the United States
comment: The Indigenous peoples of the United States. More than 570 federally recognized tribes live within the United States, about half of which are associated with Indian reservations. The term "American Indian" excludes Native Hawaiians and some Alaskan Natives, while "Native Americans" (as defined by the United States Census) are American Indians, plus Alaska Natives of all ethnicities.

A person belonging to any of various Indigenous peoples within the boundaries of Canada. They comprise the First Nations, Inuit, and Métis. Although "Indian" is a term still commonly used in legal documents, the descriptors "Indian" and "Eskimo" have somewhat fallen into disuse in Canada and some consider them to be pejorative.

term: LGBTQ Indigenous persons of the United States
comment: Indigenous persons of the United States who are LGBTQIA+.
Aboriginal Australians who are LGBTQIA+.
A person belonging to any of various Indigenous peoples of North America.
Inuit who are LGBTQIA+.
Māori who are LGBTQIA+.
A person from any of various Indigenous peoples of Polynesia.

The predominant and Indigenous inhabitants of Melanesia, in a wide area from Maluku Islands and New Guinea to as far east as the islands of Vanuatu and Fiji. Most speak either one of the many languages of the Austronesian language family, especially ones in the Oceanic branch, or from one of the many unrelated families of Papuan languages.
A person belonging to an ethnic group which is the original or earliest known inhabitants of an area, in contrast to groups that have settled, occupied or colonized the area more recently.
Indigenous persons who are LGBTQIA+.
A person belonging to any of various Indigenous peoples of Africa.
A person belonging to any of various Indigenous peoples of the Americas.
A person who engages in dancing that provides erotic entertainment and whose objective is the stimulation of erotic or sexual thoughts or actions in viewers.

A person belonging to any of various Indigenous peoples of the Australian mainland and many of its islands, such as Tasmania, Fraser Island, Hinchinbrook Island, the Tiwi Islands and Groote Eylandt, but excluding the Torres Strait Islands.
The process by which an Asian woman or women is made the subject of sexual obsession.
The process by which a woman or women is made the subject of sexual obsession.
A process by which children of mixed racial and/or ethnic parentage are objectified and fetishized, typically by white people, and usually in relationship to their physical appearance.
A person belonging to any of various Indigenous peoples of Asia.

The process by which children are objectified, i.e. considered as objects or as individuals without rights, "owned" (as least in some sense) by their guardians. This often takes the form of parents disregarding their children's rights to privacy, among other things.
A person belonging to any of various Indigenous peoples of Europe.

term: excision of malignant neoplastic breast tumor
comment: Surgical excision of a malignant neoplastic breast tumor mass.
A person belonging to any of various Indigenous peoples of Oceania.
Surgical excision of a neoplastic breast tumor mass.

A person belonging to any of various peoples who are descended from groups that lived in Australia and surrounding islands before British colonization. They include the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples of Australia.
Surgical excision of a breast tumor mass.
Surgical excision of a breast lump.
The surgical removal of a discrete mass, colloquially called a lump.
Surgical excision of a mass or lesion.

A form of terrorism motivated by nationalism. Nationalist terrorists often oppose what they consider to be occupying, imperial, or otherwise illegitimate powers.
A form of terrorism in which victims "within a country are targeted by a perpetrator with the same citizenship" as the victims.

A kind of variety show featuring music, song, dance, recitation, or drama. It is mainly distinguished by the performance venue, which might be a pub, a casino, a hotel, a restaurant, or a nightclub with a stage for performances. The audience, often dining or drinking, does not typically dance but usually sits at tables. Performances are usually introduced by a master of ceremonies or MC.

The use of the Internet to conduct violent acts that result in, or threaten, the loss of life or significant bodily harm, in order to achieve political or ideological gains through threat or intimidation.

A theatrical genre derived from elements of Victorian burlesque, music hall and minstrel shows. Burlesque in America became popular in the late 1860s and slowly evolved to feature ribald comedy and female nudity. By the early 1930s the striptease element of burlesque overshadowed the comedy and subjected burlesque to extensive local legislation. Burlesque gradually lost popularity beginning in the 1940s. A number of producers sought to capitalize on nostalgia for the entertainment by attempting to recreate the spirit of burlesque in Hollywood films from the 1930s to the 1960s. There has been a resurgence of interest in this format since the 1990s.

A form of theatrical entertainment featuring music, song, dance, recitation, or drama. It is mainly distinguished by the performance venue, which might be a pub, a casino, a hotel, a restaurant, or a nightclub with a stage for performances. The audience, often dining or drinking, does not typically dance but usually sits at tables. Performances are usually introduced by a master of ceremonies or MC. The entertainment, as done by an ensemble of actors and according to its European origins, is often (but not always) oriented towards adult audiences and of a clearly underground nature. In the United States striptease, burlesque, drag shows, or a solo vocalist with a pianist, as well as the venues which offer this entertainment, are often advertised as cabarets.

An assignment of an indeterminate gender marker shortly after birth. Note that "indeterminate" is only available in certain jurisdictions on birth certificates. Further, note that "indeterminate" itself is not a gender, but is a legal gender in this context.
Refers to either (1) femininity as expressed by travestis. or (2) an official legal transfeminine non-binary gender marker allowed through judicial ruling in 2019.
Refers to either (1) femininity as expressed by travestis. or (2) an official legal transfeminine non-binary gender marker allowed through judicial ruling in 2019.

Neo-burlesque shows that feature male-body roles have been dubbed as boylesque. The introduction of boylesque elements can be seen as a key difference between neo-burlesque and earlier, exclusively female-body forms of burlesque, which sometimes incorporated drag-queen roles (i.e. male impersonators of female bodies) but did not directly represent masculinity. Boylesque within the neo-burlesque scene can be traced back to the early 1980s with performers like John Sex.

The revival and updating of the traditional American burlesque performance. Though based on the traditional burlesque art, the new form encompasses a wider range of performance styles. neo-burlesque acts can range from anything from classic striptease to modern dance to theatrical mini-dramas to comedic mayhem.
An assignment of an "other" gender marker shortly after birth. Note that "other" is only available in certain jurisdictions on birth certificates.
