An amended birth certificate which replaces an original birth certificate after an adoption is finalized in most states in the United States (and the District of Columbia). The original birth certificate is then sealed. Adopted persons in ten states have an unrestricted right to obtain a copy of the original birth certificate when they are adults: Alabama, Alaska, Colorado, Hawaii, Kansas, Maine, New Hampshire, New York, Oregon, and Rhode Island. The remaining states and the District of Columbia either require a court order to release a copy of the original birth certificate or have other restrictions, such as permission of biological parent(s) or redaction of information upon request of a biological parent.
LGBTQ people who are Quakers.

A birth cerificate sometimes given out in some hospitals in the United States, which may include the footprints of the newborn. However, these birth certificates are not legally accepted as proof of age or citizenship, and are frequently rejected by the Bureau of Consular Affairs during passport applications. Many Americans believe the souvenir records to be their official birth certificates when, in reality, they hold little legal value.
LGBTQ people who are Restorationist.
LGBTQ people who are Mormon.

A certificate issued in some jurisdictions in the United States for foreign-born intercountry adoptees. The certificate of foreign birth serves as documentary evidence of the child's birth and the child's legal relationship to the adoptive United States parents. These certificates, however, do not serve as evidence of U.S. citizenship and must be supplemented by another document to prove citizenship, such as a Certificate of Citizenship, a United States passport or a Certificate of Naturalization.
An American transition cohort defined by Avery Everhart as beginning with the March 2020 shelter-in-place order due to the COVID-19 epidemic and continuing through 2021.
An American transition cohort defined by Avery Everhart as beginning with the 2017 inauguration of President Donald Trump and extending through the election of President Joe Biden in 2020.
A condition where the sigmoid colon descends (prolapses) into the lower pelvic cavity.
A gender transition cohort specific to the United States.

Protrusion of the rectal mucous membrane through the anus. There are various degrees: incomplete with no displacement of the anal sphincter muscle. complete with displacement of the anal sphincter muscle. complete with no displacement of the anal sphincter muscle but with herniation of the bowel. and internal complete with rectosigmoid or upper rectum intussusception into the lower rectum.
A transgender cohort specifically tied to the intertwining processes of gender transition.
A pelvic organ prolapse that is characterized by the descent of a peritoneal sac containing small bowel into the rectovagnial space causing a bulge in the posterior vaginal wall.

The co-occurence of a urethrocele with a cystocele.
A cohort formed of individual transgender women.
A pelvic organ prolapse that is characterized by the descent of the urethra from the normal anatomic location toward or through the vaginal opening.

A hernia-like condition in which the weakened pelvic muscles cause the urinary bladder to drop from its normal position. Fallen urinary bladder is more common in females with the bladder dropping into the vagina and less common in males with the bladder dropping into the scrotum.
A cohort formed of individual intersex persons.

A type of birth certificate issued from 1963 until November 1979 by the Department of National Defense in Canada to dependents of Canadian Forces members born overseas. These certificates were never accorded legal status, but served as a convenient substitute for the original record of birth from the country of birth. Today, the DND 419 is recognised as a proof of age, but not of citizenship.

An American transition cohort defined by Avery Everhart as beginning with the rise of the social networking website Tumblr. Although Everhart does not specify the timeframe, Tumblr was founded in 2007 and Yahoo! Inc. acquired Tumblr in 2013, which could be considered as "bookending" the "early Tumblr" era.
Vaginal vault prolapse which occurs after a hysterectomy.

A type of Quebec birth certificated issued with regard to a birth that occurred outside of Quebec, under paragraph 137 of the Civil Code of Québec, until their full authenticity is recognized by a Quebec court.

An American transition cohort defined by Avery Everhart as beginning with the rise of the so-called "lesbian-trans turf wars", which succeeded the "Butch/FTM Border Wars" of the late 1990s. Everhart does not give beginning and/or end dates to this cohort, but notes that it was contemporaneous with the "early Tumblr" transition cohort, which probably lasted from about 2007 up until 2013.
A pelvic organ prolapse that is characterized by the descent of the bladder causing a bulge in the anterolateral vaginal walls.
A birth certificate issued in a medical context.

An American transition cohort defined by Avery Everhart as beginning with the publication of "The Transgender Tipping Point" in Time magazine in 2014 and extending to the inauguration of President Donald Trump in 2017.
A pelvic organ prolapse that is characterized by the descent of the bladder causing a bulge in the midline anterior vaginal wall.
A birth certificate issued by a public notary by way of presenting supporting documents.
Urethrocele which is present at birth.

A type of birth certificate which typically includes name, place and date of birth, date of issue, date of registration, registration number, certificate number, and authorised signature(s). Not available in all jurisdictions.

A type of birth certificate which typically includes name, place and date of birth, parental information, date of issue, date of registration, registration number, certificate number, and authorised signature(s). Not available in all jurisdictions.
A type of birth certificate issued to persons born in Denmark and not baptized in the Church of Denmark.
A type of birth certificate issued to persons born in Denmark and baptized in the Church of Denmark.
A type of birth certificate issued to Indonesian-born individuals, per the Denpasar Civil Registry.
A birth certificate originating in a foreign country (often as opposed to country of residence).
A lesbian who is cottagecore or engages with cottagecore, an Internet aesthetic that celebrates a return to traditional skills and crafts such as foraging, baking, and pottery.

A philosophical and cultural movement which was founded by Argentinian-Mexican philosopher Enrique Dussel. Transmodernism is a development in thought following the period of postmodernism. as a movement, it was also developed from modernism, and, in turn, critiques modernity and postmodernity, viewing them as the end of modernism.
An appearance or increased popularity of a specific school of philosophy.
A sexual system in which the presence of both female and hermaphrodite flowers on the same individual of a plant species.
A philosophical movement and an art movement that arose from broad transformations in Eurocentric society during the late 19th and early 20th centuries.
A sexual system in which male and female flowers are present on the same plant. It is common in angiosperms, and occurs in 10% of all plant species.
The ensemble of particular socio-cultural norms, attitudes and practices that arose in the wake of the Renaissance—in the "Age of Reason" of 17th-century thought and the 18th-century "Enlightenment".
A sexual system in a species in which hermaphroditic individuals commonly coexist with male individuals and female individuals.
A society is a group of people who have persistent social interactions, share the same geographical or social territory, and have common motivations.
A sexual system in a species in which an individual organism tends to be either male or female.
A gay man who is Protestant.
A mosaic karyotype in which some cells are 45,X and some are 46,XX.

The characterization of today's highly developed global societies as the continuation (or development) of modernity rather than as an element of the succeeding era known as postmodernity, or the postmodern.
One of the two main sexual systems in bryophytes. In dioicy male and female sex organs are on separate gametophytes.
A lesbian who is Protestant.
A karyotype in which every cell has only one X chromosome.
The economic or cultural state or condition of society which is said to exist after modernity.

A sexual system where males, females, and hermaphrodites exist in the same population. It is present in both plants and animals but is always extremely rare. Trioecy occurs in about 3.6% of flowering plants.
A bisexual person who is Protestant.
A karyotype in which every cell has two X chromosomes.
The manner in which modern society organizes in response to risk. The term is closely associated with several key writers on modernity, in particular Ulrich Beck and Anthony Giddens.
A sexual system in which males and hermaphrodites coexist in a population.
A transgender person who is Protestant.
A mosaic karyotype in which some cells are 45,X and some are 46,XY.
Any society whose economy is based on producing and maintaining crops and farmland.
A sexual system in which females and hermaphrodites coexist in the same population.
A gay man who is Catholic.
An expression coined in 1991 related to the social, political, economic and cultural changes caused by the spread of networked, digital information and communications technologies.

A sexual system in which a species has distinct individual organisms that are either male or female, i.e., they produce only male or only female gametes, either directly (in animals) or indirectly (in plants).
A lesbian who is Catholic.

An LGBTQ subculture (particularly bisexual female subculture and lesbian subculture) following the aesthetic of cottagecore. The subculture's popularity often stems from the drive for an escape from heteronormative society. Others see cottagecore as a way to disentangle and reclaim traditional rural pleasures and surroundings from the homophobia and transphobia they experienced growing up in small towns.
A society driven by the use of technology to enable mass production, supporting a large population with a high capacity for division of labor.
A bisexual person who is Catholic.
Any of various karyotypes observed in humans.
A rare sexual system in angiosperms, in which a plant has both male and hermaphroditic flowers.
A transgender person who is Catholic.
LGBTQ people who are Presbyterian.
A mosaic karyotype in which some cells are 46,XX and some are 46,XX,+12.
A fusion of cyberculture (internet culture) and the psychedelic subculture into a new counterculture during the 1980s and 1990s.

A subculture which originally formed in the mid-1960s, focusing on social, musical, and artistic changes influenced by widespread usage of psychedelic drugs (hallucinogenic drugs whose primary effect is to trigger non-ordinary states of consciousness via serotonin 2A receptor agonism. i.e. LSD, psilocybin, and DMT).
The distribution of biological resources over various time periods, products, operations, or investments.
A culture that describes the many manifestations of the use of computer networks for communication, entertainment, and business, and recreation.
The attempt to control the sex of the offspring to achieve a desired sex at the point of pre-implantation of an embryo.
A subculture that derives from elements of goth, raver, rivethead and cyberpunk fashion.
The attempt to control the sex of the offspring to achieve a desired sex. It can be accomplished in several ways, both pre- and post-implantation of an embryo, as well as at childbirth.
The act of befriending and establishing an emotional connection with a child, and sometimes the family, to lower the child's inhibitions with the objective of sexual abuse.

The act of befriending and establishing an emotional connection with a person, and sometimes that person's friends and family, to lower the person's inhibitions with the objective of sexual abuse.
Customs organized by type or subtype.
Protestant denominations focused on altering social and religious structures through revolutionary or other means and changing value systems in fundamental ways.
A penile scar remaining following circumcision.

A category of autochthonous religious movements which have revitalised within the Baltic people (primarily Lithuanians and Latvians). These movements trace their origins back to the 19th century and they were suppressed under the Soviet Union. after its fall they have witnessed a blossoming alongside the national and cultural identity reawakening of the Baltic peoples, both in their homelands and among expatriate Baltic communities, with close ties to conservation movements.
A sexual system in a species in which an individual organism tends to be male, female, and hermaphroditic.

A millenarian restorationist Christian denomination with nontrinitarian beliefs distinct from mainstream Christianity. The group reports a worldwide membership of approximately 8.68 million adherents involved in evangelism and an annual Memorial attendance of over 20 million. Jehovah's Witnesses are directed by the Governing Body of Jehovah's Witnesses, a group of elders in Warwick, New York, United States, which establishes all doctrines based on its interpretations of the Bible. They believe that the destruction of the present world system at Armageddon is imminent, and that the establishment of God's kingdom over the earth is the only solution for all problems faced by humanity.
A permanent mark left on the skin in the process of wound healing.
Any of various modern Pagan religions developed in Northern Europe.
A pattern of sex allocation or a distribution of male and female function across organisms in a species.
LGBTQ people who are Jehovah's Witnesses.
A system of rules that are created and enforced through social or governmental institutions to regulate behavior.
A network, with some level of complexity, that connects biologically relevant entities.

The second-largest Christian church, with approximately 260 million baptised members. It operates as a communion of autocephalous churches, each governed by its bishops in local synods. Roughly half of Eastern Orthodox Christians live in Russia. The church has no central doctrinal or governmental authority analogous to the Bishop of Rome, but the Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople is recognised by all as primus inter pares ("first among equals") of the bishops.
A realizable entity, such as norm, law, regulation, that is realized in social behavior.
The allocation of resources to spermatid- versus oocyte-based reproduction in a sexual species.
Any of various cultures or subcultures related to computer use and development.
The distribution of an organism's energy budget allocated toward reproduction at any given time.

An informal grouping of Protestant denominations that contrast in history and practice with evangelical, fundamentalist, and charismatic Protestant denominations. Mainline Protestants were a majority of Protestants in the United States until the mid-20th century. A dip in membership across all Christian denominations was more pronounced among mainline groups, with the result that mainline groups no longer comprise the majority.
Conformity to societally-based gender expectations.
The distribution of biological resources in the form of energy budget over various time periods, products, operations, or investments.

Traditions of Protestantism which developed in the 19th century out of a need to adapt Christianity to a modern intellectual context. With the acceptance of Charles Darwin's theory of natural selection, some traditional Christian beliefs, such as parts of the Genesis creation narrative, became difficult to defend. Unable to ground faith exclusively in an appeal to scripture or the person of Jesus Christ, liberals, according to theologian and intellectual historian Alister McGrath, "sought to anchor that faith in common human experience, and interpret it in ways that made sense within the modern worldview." Beginning in Germany, liberal theology was influenced by several strands of thought, including the Enlightenment's high view of human reason and Pietism's emphasis on religious experience and interdenominational tolerance.
Damage to the skin.

An international Protestant Christian denomination. There are 222 member congregations in 37 countries, and the Fellowship has a specific outreach to lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender families and communities.
LGBTQ people who are Eastern Orthodox.

An Internet aesthetic that celebrates a return to traditional skills and crafts such as foraging, baking, and pottery, and is related to similar nostalgic aesthetic movements such as grandmacore, farmcore, goblincore, and faeriecore.

A denominational movement of clergy and laity who self-identify as Catholic (most often as Old Catholic and/or as Independent Catholic) and form "micro-churches claiming apostolic succession and valid sacraments".

A term used from the 1850s by groups which had separated from the Roman Catholic Church over certain doctrines, primarily concerned with papal authority. some of these groups, especially in the Netherlands, had already existed long before the term. These churches are not in full communion with the Holy See. Member churches of the Union of Utrecht of the Old Catholic Churches (UU) are in full communion with the Anglican Communion, and some are members of the World Council of Churches.
A karyotype in which every cell has three X chromosomes and one Y chromosome.

An LGBTQIA+ person who is not out, or has not made their identity known, to others. A person may be closeted to family but not close friends or they may be closeted to everyone, depending on the circumstances.
A karyotype in which every cell has an X chromosomes and three Y chromosomes.
A dyadic relationship in which partners have different HIV statuses.
A karyotype in which every cell has two X chromosomes and two Y chromosomes.
The degree to which an individual has the capacity to obtain, communicate, process, and understand basic health information and services to make health decisions.
Literacy as traditionally defined, i.e. focused around one's ability to read and write.

term: persons organized in relationship to gender
comment: Individuals organized into categories related to gender and its various facets, including gender roles, gender identities, gender marginalization status, gender modality, etc.

A "set of integrated abilities encompassing the reflective discovery of information, the understanding of how information is produced and valued and the use of information in creating new knowledge and participating ethically in communities of learning".

term: person with an F gender marker
comment: A person with an "F" gender marker on any legal document.
Fiction pertaining especially to bisexual persons and/or culture.
A tetraploid karyotype in which the four sex chromosomes are all X.

A metaphysical space made up of all blogs and their interconnections. The term implies that blogs exist together as a connected community (or as a collection of connected communities) or as a social networking service in which everyday authors can publish their opinions.
Fiction pertaining especially to gay men and/or gay male culture.
A kind of triploidy in which there are three copies of every chromosome instead of two.
A metaphysical realm of information, data, knowledge, and communication, populated by informational entities called inforgs (or, informational organisms).

A protest movement that emerged in Sydney in 2013. The campaign involved individuals creating rainbow pedestrian crossings in chalk to protest the removal of a temporary rainbow crossing from Oxford Street in Sydney. The temporary crossing was created by the City of Sydney as part of the 35th-anniversary celebration of the Sydney Mardi Gras. When the crossing was to be removed, the community protests and internet activism campaign emerged. In 2013, NSW’s first permanent rainbow crossing was approved and installed on Lackey St, Summer Hill. In 2019 a permanent Sydney rainbow crossing was unveiled in Taylor Square, on the corner of Bourke and Campbell streets.
Fiction pertaining especially to lesbians and/or lesbian culture.

The sphere of semiosis in which sign processes operate in the set of all interconnected Umwelten. The concept was coined by Yuri Lotman in 1984 and is now applied to many fields, including cultural semiotics generally, biosemiotics, zoosemiotics, geosemiotics, etc.
Any of various pedestrian rainbow crossings which were spread as part of the DIY rainbow crossing movement, a protest movement which emerged in Sydney in 2013.
Fiction pertaining especially to intersex persons and/or culture.
A tetraploid karyotype in which the four sex chromosomes are X, X, Y, and Y.
The metaphysical space where thoughts, theories, ideas, and ideation are regarded to be created, evaluated, and evolved.
A pedestrian road crossing marked with a rainbow, as a means of spreading LGBTQIA+ awareness.
A dyadic relationship in which both partners have the same HIV status.
A karyotype in which every cell has four X chromosomes and one Y chromosome.

A philosophical concept developed and popularized by the Russian and Ukrainian biogeochemist Vladimir Vernadsky, and the French philosopher and Jesuit priest Pierre Teilhard de Chardin. Vernadsky defined the noosphere as the new state of the biosphere and described as the planetary "sphere of reason". The noosphere represents the highest stage of biospheric development, its defining factor being the development of humankind's rational activities.
A place designated for pedestrians to cross a road, street or avenue which is specifically marked.
A nonmarital relationship between two people.
A karyotype in which every cell has five X chromosomes.
Non-physical spaces, i.e. spaces defined in a metaphysical sense, rather than in a physical sense.
A place designated for pedestrians to cross a road, street or avenue.
Fiction pertaining to, or including parts which relate to, a specific subculture.
A karyotype in which every cell has an X chromosome and four Y chromosomes.
An individual's ability to find, evaluate, and compose clear information through writing and other media on various digital platforms.
A place designated for pedestrians to cross.
Fiction pertaining especially to LGBTQIA+ persons and/or culture.
A karyotype in which every cell has three X chromosomes and two Y chromosomes.
The knowledge and ability to use computers and related technology efficiently, with skill levels ranging from elementary use to computer programming and advanced problem solving.
A mating type which occurs in a fungus.
A sexual partner who is abusive, sexually or otherwise.
A karyotype in which every cell has two X chromosomes and two copies of chromosome 21.
A child who is a lesbian.
A karyotype in which every cell has one X chromosome and one Y chromosome.
An online research method originating in ethnography. Netnography involves understanding social interaction in contemporary digital communications contexts.

A branch of critical theory devoted to the study of technological change. Technocriticism treats technological transformation as historically specific changes in personal and social practices of research, invention, regulation, distribution, promotion, appropriation, use, and discourse, rather than as an autonomous or socially indifferent accumulation of useful inventions, or as an uncritical narrative of linear "progress", "development" or "innovation".
A sexual system in which an individual organism is male or female until they grow to a certain size or threshold, after which time they switch to the other sex.

A branch of applied ethics which focuses on the relationship between the creation, organization, dissemination, and use of information, and the ethical standards and moral codes governing human conduct in society.

A sexual system in haploid plants (mainly bryophytes) where both sperm and eggs are produced on the same gametophyte, in contrast with dioicy, where each gametophyte produces only sperm or eggs but never both.
A term used to describe the condition of living in a digital culture, derived from Nicholas Negroponte's book Being Digital in analogy with modernity and post-modernity.
A sexual system for plants when female, hermaphrodite, gynomonoecious plants coexist in the same population.
A marital relationship between two people.
A karyotype in which every cell has two Y chromosomes and one X chromosome.
The ability to reason and to apply simple numerical concepts.

term: person with an M gender marker
comment: A person with an "M" gender marker on any legal document.
Relationships between two people in which at least one of those persons are bisexual.
A karyotype in which every cell has one X chromosome, one Y chromosome, and two copies of chromosome 21.
Literacy as a wider concept and process, held in contrast to alphabetical literacy.

term: person with an X gender marker
comment: A person with an "X" gender marker on any legal document.
Relationships between two people in which at least one person is a gay man.
A karyotype in which every cell has four X chromosomes.
A term used to describe literacy based on word and letter recognition.
Individuals organized by any of various legal gender markers they may have.
Relationships between two people in which at least one person is a lesbian.
A karyotype in which every cell has three X chromosomes and two copies of chromosome 21.
The ability to use printed and written information to function in society, to achieve one's goals, and to develop one's knowledge and potential.
A set of organisms sharing a specified genotype or karyotype.
A male child who is gay.
A karyotype in which every cell has two X chromosomes and one Y chromosome.

An online subculture of people who define themselves as unable to find a romantic or sexual partner despite desiring one. Discussions in incel forums are often characterized by resentment, misogyny, misanthropy, self-pity and self-loathing, racism, a sense of entitlement to sex, and the endorsement of violence against sexually active people. The American nonprofit Southern Poverty Law Center (SPLC) described the subculture as "part of the online male supremacist ecosystem" that is included in their list of hate groups.

term: parent of a gender nonconforming child
comment: A person who is the parent of child who is gender nonconforming.
A relationship involving two people.
A karyotype in which every cell has three X chromosomes.
The particular set of social features common to interaction on the various Internet Relay Chat (IRC) systems across the world, and the culture associated with them.
A child who is gender nonconforming.
A relationship involving three people.
A mosaic karyotype in which some cells are 47,XXY and some are 46,XY.

Any of various systematic and repeatable errors in a computer system that create unfair outcomes, such as privileging one arbitrary group of users over others. Bias can emerge due to many factors, including but not limited to the design of the algorithm or the unintended or unanticipated use or decisions relating to the way data is coded, collected, selected or used to train the algorithm. Algorithmic bias is found across platforms, including but not limited to search engine results and social media platforms, and can have impacts ranging from inadvertent privacy violations to reinforcing social biases of race, gender, sexuality, and ethnicity.
The ratio of males to females (or other sexes) in a population. In most sexually reproducing species which are dimorphic, the ratio tends to be 1:1.
Relationships between two people in which at least one of those persons are LGBTQIA+.
A mosaic karyotype in which some cells are 47,XXY and some are 46,XX.
A sexual system where male, female, and hermaphrodite flowers are on the same plant.
Relationships between two people in which at least one of those persons are transgender.
The culture of a particular nation or state.
A set of the practices, beliefs, and objects that are dominant or prevalent in a society at a given point in time.
Any of various LGBTQIA+ subcultures specific to First Nations peoples of Canada.
Any of various LGBTQIA+ subcultures specific to Native Hawaiian peoples.
A family where at least one parent has children that are not genetically related to the other spouse or partner.
Adoption wherein a parent does not meet the child before adopting.
A defined grouping of transgender lesbians, organizations, and subcultures, united by a common culture and social movements.
A community of persons, typically of African descent, classed based on the social construction of race primarily prevalent in Europe and the Americas.

A community of persons who belong to an ethnic group of Americans with total or partial ancestry from any of the Black racial groups of Africa. The phrase generally refers to descendants of enslaved Black people who are from the United States.
Any of various communities of Afro-American LGBTQIA+ persons.
A defined grouping of nonbinary persons, organizations, and subcultures, united by a common culture and social movements.
Any of various LGBTQIA+ subcultures specific to American Indian peoples.
Any of various communities of Black LGBTQIA+ persons.
A usually urban geographic location with generally recognized boundaries wherein a relatively large number of LGBTQIA+ persons might live and work.
Any of various cultures of Indigenous peoples.
Any of various LGBTQIA+ subcultures specific to Indigenous peoples.
Male persons who engage in romantic and/or sexual activity with members of the same sex.
Social equality for LGBTQIA+ persons.
The political status in which the marriages of same-sex couples and the marriages of opposite-sex couples are recognized as equal by the law.
A transgender person who is Muslim.

The social portion of gender transition during which others are made aware of a person's gender identity. Other parts of social transition include wearing the clothing matching one's gender identity or learning particular gender norm's associated with said identity.
Envy rooted in the absence of a particular anatomical entity.
Sexual intercourse involving penetration of the inguinal canal, typically practiced by transgender women.
The medical portion of gender transition. Some parts of medical transition may include hormone replacement therapy, various gender confirmation surgeries, and voice therapy.

The separation of individuals or groups resulting in the lack of or minimizing of social contact and/or communication. This separation may be accomplished by physical separation, by social barriers and by psychological mechanisms. In the latter, there may be interaction but no real communication.
When institutions give equal opportunity to people of all races.
Social rejection occurs when an individual is deliberately excluded from a social relationship or social interaction.

Social exclusion is the process in which individuals are blocked from (or denied full access to) various rights, opportunities and resources that are normally available to members of a different group, and which are fundamental to social integration and observance of human rights within that particular group.

A person, typically of African descent, classed based on the social construction of race primarily prevalent in Europe and the Americas. Such persons usually (but not always) have a mid to dark brown complexion.

Persons, usually in the United States, who identify as Latine. broadly, all Latin American persons. In this context, persons from countries and dependencies in the Western Hemisphere where Romance languages such as Spanish, Portuguese, and French are predominantly spoken. it is broader than the terms Iberian or Hispanic.
The state of being an adoptive parent.
A Black person who is male.
Black persons categorized by nationality.
Black persons categorized by gender.
A set of words that have similar formal properties.
Any of various classes of lexical items or units (such as words or phrases).
A transgender person who is Christian.
A word that functions as the name of some specific thing or set of things, such as living creatures, objects, places, actions, qualities, states of existence, or ideas.
Black persons categorized by region.

A category of words (or, more generally, of lexical items) that have similar grammatical properties. Words that are assigned to the same part of speech generally display similar syntactic behavior—they play similar roles within the grammatical structure of sentences—and sometimes similar morphology in that they undergo inflection for similar properties.

Caribbean people whose ancestors were taken from Africa via the trans-Atlantic slave trade to the Caribbean Islands between the 15th and 19th centuries to work primarily on various sugar plantations and in domestic households.
A word that substitutes for a noun or noun phrase. It is a particular case of a pro-form.
A word that substitutes for a noun or noun phrase. It is a particular case of a pro-form.

A person who belongs to an ethnic group of Americans with total or partial ancestry from any of the Black racial groups of Africa. The phrase generally refers to descendants of enslaved Black people who are from the United States.

A type of function word or expression that stands in for (expresses the same content as) another word, phrase, clause or sentence where the meaning is recoverable from the context. They are used either to avoid repetitive expressions or in quantification (limiting the variables of a proposition).
A person who is of full or partial Sub-Saharan African descent and who is also a citizen or permanent resident of Canada.
Sexual arousal derived from watching animals copulate.
A code word, series of code words or other signal used by a person to communicate their physical or emotional state, typically when approaching, or crossing, a physical, emotional, or moral boundary.
Any of various sexual attractions relation to emotions or emotionality.
Sexual attraction or arousal from jealousy.

The use of electronic communication technologies such as social media, e-mail, and podcasts for various forms of activism to enable faster and more effective communication by citizen movements, the delivery of particular information to large and specific audiences as well as coordination. Internet technologies are used for cause-related fundraising, community building, lobbying, and organizing.
Social activism and advocacy of and for LGBTQIA+ persons and communities.
Social activism and advocacy for patients and their supporters in health care organizations and associated entities.
The status of being a parent or not being a parent.
The state of being a parent.
Social activism and advocacy for patients and their supporters in medical organizations and associated entities.
Social activism and advocacy for HIV/AIDS patients and their supporters in health care and medical organizations and associated entities involved in HIV/AIDS treatment and research.
A grammatical gender indicating animacy.
A grammatical gender which is neutral, usually in comparison to masculine and feminine.
A transgender person currently engaged in any of various transition processes.
A grammatical gender indicating inanimacy.
A transgender person who would become engaged in any of various transition processes, who has yet to become involved in them.
A transgender person who has previously engaged in the process of surgical gender transition or any of its associated processes.
A word class to which new words are very rarely added.
A transgender person who would like to become engaged in the process of social gender transition or any of its associated processes.
A word class that commonly accepts the addition of new words.
A transgender person who would like to become engaged in the process of surgical gender transition or any of its associated processes.
The class of syntactic words that are fundamentally relation inducing.

A transgender person who has previously engaged in the process of medical gender transition or any of its associated processes, but has not engaged and does not plan on engaging in any surgical aspects of gender transition.
A word or expression that occurs as an utterance on its own and expresses a spontaneous feeling or reaction.
A transgender person who would like to become engaged in the process of medical gender transition or any of its associated processes.
A word (part of speech) that in syntax conveys an action (bring, read, walk, run, learn), an occurrence (happen, become), or a state of being (be, exist, stand).
The study of ethical action. It is the branch of philosophical ethics that investigates the set of questions that arise when considering how one ought to act, morally speaking.
A word whose main role is to modify/ describe a noun or noun phrase. Its semantic role is to change information given by the noun.

A branch of philosophy that studies the ontology and nature of the mind and its relationship with the body. The mind–body problem is a paradigm issue in philosophy of mind, although other issues are addressed, such as the hard problem of consciousness, and the nature of particular mental states.
A word that is used with a noun (as a standalone word or a prefix or suffix) to specify grammatical definiteness of the noun, and in some languages extending to volume or numerical scope.

A word, phrase, or affix that occurs together with a noun or noun phrase and serves to express the reference of that noun or noun phrase in the context. That is, a determiner may indicate whether the noun is referring to a definite or indefinite element of a class, to a closer or more distant element, to an element belonging to a specified person or thing, to a particular number or quantity, etc.

The practical application of moral considerations. It is ethics with respect to real-world actions and their moral considerations in the areas of private and public life, the professions, health, technology, law, and leadership.
A pronoun which indicates a relationship of possession in a broad sense. This can include strict ownership, or a number of other types of relation to a greater or lesser degree analogous to it.

A pronoun that is associated primarily with a particular grammatical person – first person (as I), second person (as you), or third person (as he, she, it, they). Personal pronouns may also take different forms depending on number (usually singular or plural), grammatical or natural gender, case, and formality.
A pronoun which marks a type of subordinate clause called a relative clause while also modifying the referent in the main clause of a sentence.
Europeans who trace at least part of their ancestry to Sub-Saharan Africa, mostly to former colonies.
An anaphoric pronoun that must be coreferential with another nominal (its antecedent) within the same clause.

A word used to indicate which entities are being referred to and to distinguish those entities from others. They are typically deictic. their meaning depending on a particular frame of reference and cannot be understood without context.
A property of items within the grammar of a language. Within each category there are two or more possible values (sometimes called grammemes), which are normally mutually exclusive.
A pronoun which is invented for a specific use or is otherwise a new construction. a pronoun which is a neologism.
Any of various classes of linguistic items or items related to language.

Variation in the human brain regarding sociability, learning, attention, mood and other mental functions in a non-pathological sense. The term is a portmanteau of "neurological" and "diversity" and emerged as a challenge to prevailing views that certain neurodevelopmental disorders are inherently pathological and instead adopts the social model of disability, in which societal barriers are the main contributing factor that disables people.

A specific form of noun class system in which the division of noun classes forms an agreement system with another aspect of the language, such as adjectives, articles, pronouns, or verbs. This system is used in approximately one quarter of the world's languages. In these languages, most or all nouns inherently carry one value of the grammatical category called gender. the values present in a given language (of which there are usually two or three) are called the genders of that language.
A transgender person engaged in the process of medical gender transition or any of its associated processes.
A type of syntactic unit that theories of syntax assume. Word classes, largely corresponding to traditional parts of speech (e.g. noun, verb, preposition, etc.), are syntactic categories.
Transgender persons as defined by transition types and/or processes.
A grammatical gender which is masculine.
A transgender person has previously engaged in any of various transition processes and considers themselves to have completed those processes.
A grammatical gender which is feminine.
A transgender person engaged in the process of social gender transition or any of its associated processes.
LGBTQIA+ cultures in the country of Argentina.

term: LGBTQ culture in the Northern Mariana Islands
comment: LGBTQIA+ cultures in the U.S. commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands.

A representation of the experiences and choices of a given person, and the knowledge that they gain from these experiences and choices. It is a category of qualitative research together with those that focus on society and culture and those that focus on language and communication.
LGBTQIA+ cultures in the country of Brazil.
LGBTQIA+ cultures in the country of Colombia.
Surgical procedures performed on parts of the head and/or neck.
Any of various life experiences specific to members of the lesbian community.
LGBTQIA+ cultures in the country of Chile.
A surgical technique that removes hair follicles from one part of the body, called the donor site, to a bald or balding part of the body known as the recipient site.
Any of various life experiences specific to members of the gay male community.
LGBTQIA+ cultures in the country of Canada.
A pronoun which is associated with a particular grammatical gender or personal gender (the gender of a person).
Any of various life experiences specific to members of a given minority community.
LGBTQIA+ cultures in the country of Peru.
A pronoun which is associated with or otherwise related to a particular grammatical gender and/or personal gender (the gender of a person).
Any of various life experiences specific to members of the LGBTQ community.
LGBTQIA+ cultures in the autonomous territory of Denmark, Greenland.
A pronoun which is associated with either the masculine grammatical gender or a masculine personal gender (the gender of a person).
Any of various life experiences specific to members of the transmasculine community.
LGBTQIA+ cultures in the country of Cuba.
A pronoun which is not associated with a particular grammatical gender or personal gender (the gender of a person).

term: LGBTQ culture in the United States
comment: LGBTQIA+ cultures in the country of the United States.
Any of various life experiences specific to members of the bisexual community.
LGBTQIA+ cultures in the country of Mexico.
A pronoun which is associated with either the feminine grammatical gender or a feminine personal gender (the gender of a person).
Any of various life experiences specific to members of the transgender community.
An article that indicates that its noun is not a particular one identifiable to the listener.
An article used to refer to a particular member of a group or class.
A transgender person who is Jewish.

The other human being in their differences from the self, as being a cumulative, constituting factor in the self-image of a person. as acknowledgement of being real. Usually, the "other" is used in relationship to the quality of "otherness", he state of being different from and alien to the social identity of a person and to the identity of the self. To "other" someone (as a verb) is to reduce them by labeling and defining them as a subaltern native, as someone who belongs to the socially subordinate category of the other.
A type of graft surgery involving the transplantation of skin.
LGBTQIA+ cultures in the overseas collectivity of the French Republic, French Polynesia.

A subculture that began in England during the early 1980s, where it developed from the audience of gothic rock, an offshoot of the post-punk genre. The name, goth subculture, was derived directly from the music genre.
LGBTQIA+ cultures in the subregion of Polynesia.
A subculture based around a particular kind of fashion, fashion sense, or overall aesthetic.
LGBTQIA+ cultures in the U.S. state of Hawaii.

A youth-based subculture with distinct styles, behaviors, and interests. Youth subcultures offer participants an identity outside of that ascribed by social institutions such as family, work, home and school. Youth subcultures that show a systematic hostility to the dominant culture are sometimes described as countercultures.

term: LGBTQ culture in the Society Islands
comment: LGBTQIA+ cultures in the Society Islands, part of French Polynesia.
A type of subculture whose values and norms of behavior differ substantially from those of mainstream society, often in opposition to mainstream cultural mores.

term: LGBTQ culture in the Cook Islands
comment: LGBTQIA+ cultures in the self-governing island country of the Cook Islands.
A personal pronoun that is used typically as a grammatical object: the direct or indirect object of a verb, or the object of a preposition.

A subculture which stems from the goth subculture and incorporates some elements of BDSM subculture. It consists of both active vampirism and psychic vampirism. Active vampirism within the vampire subculture includes both sanguinarian vampirism, which involves blood consumption, and psychic vampirism, whose practitioners believe they are drawing spiritual nourishment from auric or pranic energy.
LGBTQIA+ cultures in the country of Samoa.
A personal pronoun that is used as the subject of a verb.
A contemporary subculture of therianthropy, based on a spiritual or psychological identification, or both, with animals.
LGBTQIA+ cultures in the U.S. unincorporated territory Guam.
Any of various subcultures in which participants claim non-human identities for themselves.
LGBTQIA+ cultures in the Polynesian sovereign state and archipelago of Tonga.

A subculture who socially and spiritually identify as not entirely human. Some otherkin claim that their identity is genetic, while others believe their identity derives from reincarnation, trans-species dysphoria of the soul, ancestry, or metaphor.
LGBTQIA+ cultures in the U.S. state of Massachusetts.

The hue of that portion of the visible spectrum lying between green and indigo, evoked in the human observer by radiant energy with wavelengths of approximately 420 to 490 nanometers. any of a group of colors that may vary in lightness and saturation, whose hue is that of a clear daytime sky.

One of the three primary colors of pigments in painting and traditional color theory, as well as in the RGB color model. It lies between violet and green on the spectrum of visible light. The eye perceives blue when observing light with a dominant wavelength between approximately 450 and 495 nanometres. Most blues contain a slight mixture of other colors. azure contains some green, while ultramarine contains some violet. The clear daytime sky and the deep sea appear blue because of an optical effect known as Rayleigh scattering. An optical effect called Tyndall scattering explains blue eyes. Distant objects appear more blue because of another optical effect called aerial perspective.
Fetishization of a person or culture belonging to a race or ethnic group, including, but not limited to, having strong racial preferences in dating.
LGBTQIA+ cultures in the U.S. state of Minnesota.
LGBTQIA+ cultures in the U.S. state of Michigan.

A pale tint of red that is named after a flower of the same name. It was first used as a color name in the late 17th century. According to surveys in Europe and the United States, pink is the color most often associated with charm, politeness, sensitivity, tenderness, sweetness, childhood, femininity and romance. A combination of pink and white is associated with chastity and innocence, whereas a combination of pink and black links to eroticism and seduction.
Any of a group of colors reddish in hue, of medium to high lightness, and of low to moderate saturation.
LGBTQIA+ cultures in the U.S. state of New Jersey.

Portrayal of lesbian, gay, bisexual, or otherwise queer characters in fiction as heterosexual (straight), making those people appear heterosexual, or altering information about historical figures to make their representation comply with heteronormativity.
LGBTQIA+ cultures in the U.S. state of Mississippi.
Members of the various professions (e.g., physicians) or occupations (e.g., police).
LGBTQIA+ cultures in the U.S. state of North Carolina.

The term is most commonly associated with the police forces of a sovereign state that are authorized to exercise the police power of that state within a defined legal or territorial area of responsibility. Police forces are often defined as being separate from the military and other organizations involved in the defense of the state against foreign aggressors. however, gendarmerie are military units charged with civil policing.

The right which stipulates all people must be able to access the internet in order to exercise and enjoy their rights to freedom of expression and opinion and other fundamental human rights, that states have a responsibility to ensure that internet access is broadly available, and that states may not unreasonably restrict an individual's access to the internet.
Those forms of control which are exerted in less concrete and tangible ways, as through folkways, mores, conventions, and public sentiment.
A chromosome that is additional to the statistically normative karyotype for a given species.
Control which is exerted by the more stable organizations of society, such as established institutions and the law. They are ordinarily embodied in definite codes, usually written.
A chromosome which is present in addition to the normal chromosome complement.
Any of various organizations that are involved in the treatment of substance abuse, physical dependence and addictive behavior.
Any of various organizations that are involved in recovery from various aspects of substance abuse, physical dependence and addictive behavior.
Voluntary associations of people who share a common desire to overcome drug addiction.

Activities of some members of government who act in an organized manner to enforce the law by discovering, deterring, and/or punishing people who violate the rules and norms governing that society. Although the term encompasses police, courts, and corrections, it is most frequently applied to those who directly engage in patrols or surveillance to dissuade and discover criminal activity, and those who investigate crimes and apprehend offenders, a task typically carried out by the police, sheriff or another law enforcement organization.
A partially or completed duplicated urethra resulting from any of various congenital genitourinary conditions.
Any of various organizations composed of and/or primarily for motorcyclists.

A supernumerary chromosome which is preferentially inherited, instead of being subject to Mendelian inheritance models. B chromosomes are many times said to contain no genetic material which alters an organism's appearance or physiology.

An approach to recovery in regard to a mental health issue or substance dependence which emphasizes and supports a person's potential for recovery. It centers recovery as a personal journey rather than a set outcome, and one that may involve developing hope, a secure base and sense of self, supportive relationships, empowerment, social inclusion, coping skills, and meaning.
Organizations which provide mental health services.
Any therapeutic procedure which uses estradiol.
Any therapeutic procedure which uses testosterone cypionate.
Any therapeutic procedure which uses testosterone.

The phase of a sexuoerotic relationship which follows the acceptive phase. the conceptive phase begins with the possibility of conception and gestation.

A profile proposed by William Prendergast in 1979 to describe possible psychological outcomes for children with "inadequate" personalities. Prendergast's model is now largely considered pseudoscientific.
Either a pattern of results from various psychological tests obtained for an individual, or a hypothetical description of a person's psychological characteristics, such as a criminal profile.
Any of various rights which relate to the communication, collection, access, use, and control of information.

Any of various legal rights which allow individuals to access, use, create, and publish digital media or to access and use computers, other electronic devices, and telecommunications networks. The concept is particularly related to the protection and realization of existing rights, such as the right to privacy and freedom of expression, in the context of digital technologies, especially the internet.
The right to identify, obtain and make use of data or information effectively.
The quality of being accessible, or of admitting approach. receptiveness.

A personality profile originating from the mostly obsoleted 1979 William Prendergast developmental-descriptive profile. The profile involves an individual's attempt to cope with their social "inadequacy" via seduction, leading to antisocial behavior. The combination of such a personality with unresolved early sexual trauma was said to lead to a person becoming a "seductive pedophile, a seduction-motivated exhibitionist, a passive homosexual, voyeur, sexually motivated arsonist, or obscene phone caller with seduction fantasies".

The ability for an individual to seek, receive and impart information effectively. This sometimes includes "scientific, Indigenous, and traditional knowledge. freedom of information, building of open knowledge resources, including open Internet and open standards, and open access and availability of data. preservation of digital heritage. respect for cultural and linguistic diversity, such as fostering access to local content in accessible languages. quality education for all, including lifelong and e-learning. diffusion of new media and information literacy and skills, and social inclusion online, including addressing inequalities based on skills, education, gender, age, race, ethnicity, and accessibility by those with disabilities. and the development of connectivity and affordable ICTs, including mobile, the Internet, and broadband infrastructures".

The degree to which individuals are inhibited or facilitated in their ability to gain entry to and to receive care and services from the health care system. Factors influencing this ability include geographic, architectural, transportational, and financial considerations, among others.

A process which is part of Jean Piaget's theory of psychological adaptation (psychological adjustment). It describes the process by which individuals' congitive schemas and perceptions adapt to situations which cause conflict with those schemas or perceptions, without necessarily resolving the basis of conflict or changing the underlying system which causes the conflict.

An organization which is rooted in or based in a specific community, and geared toward serving that community's needs.

The concept covering the physical and mental health conditions experienced by transfeminine people (including transgender women), usually related to social disadvantages or discriminatory acts.

An early-modern African state located in what is now Angola. The Kingdom of Ndongo is first recorded in the sixteenth century. It was one of multiple vassal states to Kongo, though Ndongo was the most powerful of these with a king called the Ngola. Little is known of the kingdom in the early sixteenth century. "Angola" was listed among the titles of the King of Kongo in 1535, so it is likely that it was in somewhat subordinate to Kongo. Its own oral traditions, collected in the late sixteenth century, particularly by the Jesuit Baltasar Barreira, described the founder of the kingdom, Ngola Kiluanje, also known as Ngola Inene, as a migrant from Kongo, chief of a Kimbundu-speaking ethnic group.
Nightlife entertainment which has a primarily LGBTQIA+ audience.
The collection and study of historical information about individuals, families, important events, or everyday life using audiotapes, videotapes, or transcriptions of planned interviews.
Any of various methods of phalloplasty in which the clitoris (and usually the clitoral hood) are left exposed, instead of buried. The clitoris can then be placed in front of or behind the scrotum.
Media which transmit information electronically via media such as films, radio, recorded music, or television.
A person who is marginalized because of some aspect of their gender characteristics.
Any of various services which provide forms of entertainment.
The usage of Twitter hashtags (or any other social media system's hashtags) for the purposes of internet activism.
Any of various entertainment services which seek to amuse.

Any of various phalloplasty techniques in which vaginectomy is not performed, leaving a functional vaginal oriface. This type of phalloplasty often precludes urethral lengthening, as their is a strong likelihood of urinary complications.

Any of various services which are available and generally more popular from the late evening into the early hours of the morning. It includes pubs, bars, nightclubs, parties, live music, concerts, cabarets, theatre, cinemas, and shows.
Phalloplasty in which a penile shaft is constructed without vaginectomy, urethral lengthening, and scrotoplasty being performed.
Any of various communities sharing some linguistic quality or phenomena.
A community which shares a particular language.
A group of people who share a set of linguistic norms and expectations regarding the use of language.
A form of language change regarding the evolution of word usage—usually to the point that the modern meaning is radically different from the original usage.
A change in the syntactic structure of a natural language.
A change in the way something in a language is spelled.
The economic and social conditions that influence individual and group differences in health status.
Beating which has an erotic component. typically considered as a component of various BDSM activities.
Any of various related religious traditions in the Caribbean derived from the African diaspora.
The use of more than one language, either by an individual speaker or by a group of speakers.
The legal act by a person of adopting a new name different from their name at birth, marriage or adoption.
A punishment intended to cause physical pain to a person.
Any of various related religious traditions in the Americas derived from the African diaspora, especially those in the Southern United States.
Any of various processes or habits which allow extension beyond one's "native" or early linguistic habits to include other "newer" habits.
A name that a person or group assumes for a particular purpose, which can differ from their first or true name (orthonym).
The infliction of corporal punishment as a result of a sentence by a court of law.
Any of various religions originating among Indigenous peoples in the Americas.
Any of the various cognitive processes involved in producing and understanding linguistic communication.
Another person's name used as a pseudonym by the author of a work.
The deliberate infliction of physical pain/discomfort and psychological humiliation as a response to undesired behavior by a student or group of students.

Any of various traditional beliefs and practices of African people are a set of highly diverse beliefs that includes various ethnic religions. Generally, these traditions are oral rather than scriptural and passed down from one generation to another through folk tales, songs and festivals, include belief in an amount of higher and lower gods, sometimes including a supreme creator or force, belief in spirits, veneration of the dead, use of magic and traditional African medicine.

A term used in sociolinguistics and stylistics to refer to any system of linguistic expression whose use is governed by situational variables. In some cases, the situational distinctiveness of the language may be easily stated, as in many regional and occupational varieties. in other cases, as in studies of social class, the varieties are more difficult to define, involving the intersection of several variables.

A new religion (in the sociological sense) teaching the essential worth of all religions and the unity of all people. Established by Baháʼu'lláh in the 19th century, it initially grew in Persia and parts of the Middle East, where it has faced ongoing persecution since its inception. It is estimated to have over five million adherents, known as Baháʼís, spread throughout most of the world's countries and territories.

Any set of beliefs about languages as they are used in their social worlds. When recognized and explored, language ideologies expose how the speakers' linguistic beliefs are linked to the broader social and cultural systems to which they belong, illustrating how the systems beget such beliefs. By doing so, language ideologies link implicit and explicit assumptions about a language or language in general to their social experience as well as their political and economic interests.
Assaultive behavior in which a person (who may be considered a victim) is hit or struck repeatedly, with or without a weapon.

A multi-faceted faith centered on a dualistic cosmology of good and evil and an eschatology predicting the ultimate conquest of evil with theological elements of henotheism, monotheism/monism, and polytheism. Ascribed to the teachings of the Iranian-speaking spiritual leader Zoroaster (also known as Zarathustra), it exalts an uncreated and benevolent deity of wisdom, Ahura Mazda (Wise Lord), as its supreme being.

A learning disability involving a math disability can cause such difficulties as learning math concepts (such as quantity, place value, and time), difficulty memorizing math facts, difficulty organizing numbers, and understanding how problems are organized on the page.
To push someone roughly.
Any of various related religions that developed as a result of the African diaspora, primarily in the Americas.
A reading disorder resulting from a developmental reading disability involving the inability to process graphic symbols resulting in impairment of reading ability.

Any of various religions practiced in Ancient Egypt. Most of these religions were polytheistic and centered on the Ancient Egyptians' interactions with many deities believed to be present in, and in control of the world.
A name chosen by a person for themself.
Physical or corporal punishment by a parent or other legal guardian is any act causing deliberate physical pain or discomfort to a minor child in response to some undesired behavior.
Any of various religions originating among Indigenous peoples in South America.
A name used by many different people to protect anonymity.
The use of belts made of strong materials (usually leather) as a whip-like instrument for corporal punishment (see that article for generalities).
Any of various religions originating among Indigenous peoples in North America.
A pseudonym shared by two or more persons, such as coauthors of a work.
Assault which is considered a felony within any of various jurisdictions.
A familiar, invented given name for a person or thing used instead of the actual name of the person or thing.
Variation over time in a language's features. It is studied in several subfields of linguistics: historical linguistics, sociolinguistics, and evolutionary linguistics.
A title associated primarily with nobility.
A title associated primarily with royalty.
A title associated primarily with an empire.
A title which is not honorific in nature.
An honorary title provided as the official designation of a position held in law enforcement associated with certain duties of authority.
A title associated with commercial or military maritime activity.

Severe or complete loss of motor function in all four limbs which may result from brain diseases. spinal cord diseases. peripheral nervous system diseases. neuromuscular diseases. or rarely muscular diseases. The locked-in syndrome is characterized by quadriplegia in combination with cranial muscle paralysis. Consciousness is spared and the only retained voluntary motor activity may be limited eye movements. This condition is usually caused by a lesion in the upper brain stem which injures the descending cortico-spinal and cortico-bulbar tracts.

A Christian theological movement named for its belief that the God in Christianity is one person, as opposed to the Trinity, which in most other branches of Christianity defines God as one being in three persons: the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit. Unitarian Christians, therefore, believe that Jesus was inspired by God in his moral teachings, and He is a savior, but he was not a deity or God incarnate.
Any sound change that alters the distribution of phonemes in a language.

A decreased magnitude of the sensory perception of sound. Hearing loss can be categorized by which part of the auditory system is damaged, as conductive hearing loss, sensorineural hearing loss, and mixed hearing loss. Another axis of classification uses the degree of hearing impairment. The degree of hearing loss is computed by using a three frequency average taken at 500 Hz, 1,000 Hz and 2,000 Hz. The average of these three frequencies is called the Pure Tone Average (PTA). 0-20 dB is considered normal, 21-40 dB mild loss, 41-60 dB moderate loss, 61-70 dB moderately severe loss,71-90 dB severe loss, and greater than 90 dB profound loss. Note that the word deafness is occasionally used to describe partial hearing loss. The World Health Organization uses the word deafness to refer to complete loss of the ability to hear, and hearing impairment to refer to any degree of reduced hearing.

A liberal religion characterized by a "free and responsible search for truth and meaning". Unitarian Universalists assert no creed, but instead are unified by their shared search for spiritual growth, guided by a dynamic, "living tradition".
A sound change which involves the replacement of one speech sound (or, more generally, one phonetic feature value) by a different one

Visual impairment (or vision impairment) is vision loss (of a person) to such a degree as to qualify as an additional support need through a significant limitation of visual capability resulting from either disease, trauma, or congenital or degenerative conditions that cannot be corrected by conventional means, such as refractive correction, medication, or surgery.
An adherent of Unitarianism.
A subculture interested in any of various sports or sporting events, teams, players, coaches, or other individuals involved in the sport or sports.
A change in the pronunciation of a language over time.

A broad concept encompassing various intellectual or cognitive deficits, including intellectual disability, deficits too mild to properly qualify as intellectual disability, various specific conditions (such as specific learning disability), and problems acquired later in life through acquired brain injuries or neurodegenerative diseases like dementia.
An adherent of Unitarian Universalism.
Pornography which is chiefly displayed through the medium of television.
Changes in the lexicon of a language.
The intentional killing of a transgender woman because of her gender, usually used in the context of describing a hate crime.
Any of various media which are generally intended to be humorous or amusing by inducing laughter, especially in theatre, television, film, stand-up comedy, and books.
The intentional killing of a transgender man because of his gender, usually used in the context of describing a hate crime.

Severe or complete loss of motor function in the lower extremities and lower portions of the trunk. A writing disorder that involves a deficiency in the ability to write where the writing is distorted or incorrect, spelling difficulty, poor handwriting or trouble putting thoughts on paper.

Subnormal intellectual functioning which originates during the developmental period. This has multiple potential etiologies, including genetic defects and perinatal insults. Intelligence quotient (IQ) scores are commonly used to determine whether an individual has an intellectual disability. IQ scores between 70 and 79 are in the borderline range. Scores below 67 are in the disabled range.
Any of various religions originating primarily in Western Asia.

Impairment of certain skills such as reading or writing, coordination, self-control, or attention that interfere with the ability to learn. The impairment is not related to a global deficiency of intelligence. The term learning disability is used with different meanings in different contexts. Significant impairments of mental functioning with a reduction in IQ below 70 should be coded as intellectual disability.
A war engaged in by all or most of the principal nations in the world.

A subculture interested in any of various women's sports or sporting events, teams, players, coaches, or other individuals involved in the sport or sports. Alternatively, a subculture of women interested in sports or sporting events, generally.

Disabilities in which there is a delay in development based on that expected for a given age level or stage of development. These impairments or disabilities originate before age 18, may be expected to continue indefinitely, and constitute a substantial impairment.
Any of various forms of sexual play which involve the anus.
Any of various long-term conditions attributed to impairment of the brain and/or neuromuscular system.
Assaultive behavior which is considered criminal under any of various jurisdictions.

The science dealing with the establishment and maintenance of health in the individual and the group. It includes the conditions and practices conducive to health.

An act in which something is exchanged or traded for something else.

A belief among some Christians that the return of the Jews to the Holy Land and the establishment of the state of Israel in 1948 were in accordance with Bible prophecy. Some Christian Zionists believe that the gathering of the Jews in Israel is a prerequisite for the Second Coming of Jesus. The idea has been common in Protestant circles since the Reformation that Christians should actively support a Jewish return to the Land of Israel, along with the parallel idea that the Jews ought to be encouraged to become Christians as a means of fulfilling biblical prophecy.

An ethnic identity is the identification with a certain ethnicity, usually on the basis of a presumed common genealogy or ancestry. Recognition by others as a distinct ethnic group is often a contributing factor to developing this bond of identification. Ethnic groups are also often united by common cultural, behavioral, linguistic, ritualistic, or religious traits.
A person who cleans and buffs shoes and then applies a waxy paste to give a shiny appearance and a protective coating.

The use of combined psychoactive substances to achieve a particular effect. In many cases one drug is used as a base or primary drug, with additional drugs to leaven or compensate for the side effects of the primary drug and make the experience more enjoyable with drug synergy effects, or to supplement for primary drug when supply is low.

An ideology and nationalist movement involving the Jewish people that espouses the re-establishment of and support for a Jewish state centered in the area roughly corresponding to Canaan, the Holy Land, or the region of Palestine.

National identity is an ethical and philosophical concept whereby all humans are divided into groups called nations. Members of a "nation" share a common identity, and usually a common origin, in the sense of ancestry, parentage or descent.
Those sciences which focus on health, or health care, as core parts of their subject matter.
Slang that is specific to, or primarily used within, cannabis subcultures or is otherwise used to refer to cannabis.

A number used by the governments of many countries as a means of tracking their citizens, permanent residents, and temporary residents for the purposes of work, taxation, government benefits, health care, and other governmentally-related functions.
A type of clothing worn by members of an organization while participating in that organization's activity.
A numeric password used in the process of authenticating a user accessing a system.

A polyphyletic term used to describe the diversity of practices in areas generally termed "religion", of persons of Chinese heritage, including the Chinese diaspora. This may include the veneration of forces of nature and ancestors, exorcism of harmful forces, and a belief in the rational order of nature, the universe and reality that can be influenced by human beings and their rulers, as well as spirits and gods.
An occurrence when a person becomes bilingual by first learning one language and then another.
The shift from being bilingual, knowing two different languages, to only speaking one leading language.

The act of beating the human body with special implements such as whips, lashes, rods, switches, the cat o' nine tails, the sjambok, the knout, etc.

An antisemitic canard which falsely accuses Jews of murdering Christian children (or other gentiles) in order to use their blood in the performance of religious rituals. Blood libels typically claim that Jews require human blood for the baking of matzos, an unleavened flatbread which they eat during Passover, although this element of the accusation was allegedly absent in the earliest blood libels in which then-contemporary Jews were accused of reenacting the crucifixion. The accusations often assert that the blood of the children of Christians is especially coveted, and, historically, blood libel claims have been made in order to account for the otherwise unexplained deaths of children.

Any of various sensational reports, misrepresentations, or fabrications that are defamatory towards Judaism as a religion or defamatory towards Jews as an ethnic or religious group. Since at least the Middle Ages, they have formed parts of broader antisemitic conspiracy theories.
A concise, terse, laconic, and/or memorable expression of a general truth or principle.
Substances that cause the adherence of two surfaces. They include glues (properly collagen-derived adhesives), mucilages, sticky pastes, gums, resins, or latex.

A concise, memorable, and usually philosophical aphorism that communicates an important truth derived from experience, custom, or both, and that many people consider true and credible because of its longeval tradition, i.e. being handed down generation to generation, or memetic replication.
Any one of a variety of combinations of backing materials coated with an adhesive.
An adhesive tape that will stick with application of pressure, without the need for a solvent (such as water) or heat for activation.
The sequence of nucleotide residues along an RNA or DNA chain.
Communities based around or in reference to particular facets of sexuality.

A community of men whose goal is seduction and sexual success with women. The community exists through Internet newsletters and blogs, marketing (e.g. banner ads, seminars, one-on-one coaching), forums and groups, as well as local clubs, known as "lairs".
A business serving mostly person belonging to the leather subculture whose primary function is the serving of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises.
Any stimulus involving physical contact with the nipple or nipples that leads to, enhances and maintains sexual arousal, and may lead to orgasm.
Any of various motor actions or behaviors involving the oral region of the body.

A form of argument that attempts to establish a claim by showing that the opposite scenario would lead to absurdity or contradiction. It can be used to disprove a statement by showing that it would inevitably lead to a ridiculous, absurd, or impractical conclusion, or to prove a statement by showing that if it were false, then the result would be absurd or impossible.
The act of forcibly ejecting saliva or other substances from the mouth.

The distribution from an employer of a security (expected return or profits derived solely from others) paid to an employee. The compensation that one receives in exchange for the work or services performed.

A mid-stomach–length garment for the upper body. A jacket typically has sleeves, and fastens in the front or slightly on the side. A jacket is generally lighter, tighter-fitting, and less insulating than a coat.
A false or misleading report or story, especially if deliberately so.

A garment shaped like a jacket with long sleeves that surpass the tips of the wearer's fingers. Its most typical use is restraining people who may cause harm to themselves or others. Once the wearer slides their arms into the sleeves, the person assisting the wearer crosses the sleeves against the chest and ties the ends of the sleeves to the back of the jacket, ensuring the arms are close to the chest with as little movement as possible.

A report created under the auspices of sensationalism, in which events and topics in news stories are selected and worded to excite the greatest number of readers and viewers. This style of news reporting encourages biased or emotionally loaded impressions of events rather than neutrality, and may cause a manipulation to the truth of a story.

Sexual suggestiveness is visual, verbal, written or behavioral material or action with sexual undertones implying sexual intent in order to provoke sexual arousal. The process of deliberately enticing a person, to engage in a relationship, to lead astray, as from duty, rectitude, or the like. to corrupt, to persuade or induce into engaging in sexual behavior.

A device that impairs the freedom of movement of the body in some way.
The minimum income necessary for a worker to meet their basic needs.
The act of deceiving or the fact of being deceived.
Physical restraints used during certain medical procedures to restrain patients with the minimum of discomfort and pain and to prevent them from injuring themselves or others.
The lowest remuneration that employers can legally pay their employees—the price floor below which employees may not sell their labor.
The act of pretending to have beliefs, opinions, virtues, feelings, qualities, or standards that one does not actually have.
Medical restraints used primarily in psychiatry and allied disciplines.
A form of payment from an employer to an employee, which may be specified in an employment contract.
